dialog: Marry, they say my uncle grew so fastThat he could gnaw a crust at two hours old'Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth.Grandam, this would have been a biting jest.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: I pray thee, pretty York, who told thee this?

speaker: YORK
dialog: Grandam, his nurse.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: His nurse! why, she was dead ere thou wert born.

speaker: YORK
dialog: If 'twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: A parlous boy: go to, you are too shrewd.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
dialog: Good madam, be not angry with the child.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Pitchers have ears.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
dialog: Here comes a messenger. What news?

speaker: Messenger
dialog: Such news, my lord, as grieves me to unfold.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: How fares the prince?

speaker: Messenger
dialog: Well, madam, and in health.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: What is thy news then?

speaker: Messenger
dialog: Lord Rivers and Lord Grey are sent to Pomfret,With them Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: Who hath committed them?

speaker: Messenger
dialog: The mighty dukesGloucester and Buckingham.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: For what offence?

speaker: Messenger
dialog: The sum of all I can, I have disclosed;Why or for what these nobles were committedIs all unknown to me, my gracious lady.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Ay me, I see the downfall of our house!The tiger now hath seized the gentle hind;Insulting tyranny begins to jetUpon the innocent and aweless throne:Welcome, destruction, death, and massacre!I see, as in a map, the end of all.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: Accursed and unquiet wrangling days,How many of you have mine eyes beheld!My husband lost his life to get the crown;And often up and down my sons were toss'd,For me to joy and weep their gain and loss:And being seated, and domestic broilsClean over-blown, themselves, the conquerors.Make war upon themselves; blood against blood,Self against self: O, preposterousAnd frantic outrage, end thy damned spleen;Or let me die, to look on death no more!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Come, come, my boy; we will to sanctuary.Madam, farewell.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: I'll go along with you.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: You have no cause.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
dialog: My gracious lady, go;And thither bear your treasure and your goods.For my part, I'll resign unto your graceThe seal I keep: and so betide to meAs well I tender you and all of yours!Come, I'll conduct you to the sanctuary.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Welcome, sweet prince, to London, to your chamber.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Welcome, dear cousin, my thoughts' sovereignThe weary way hath made you melancholy.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: No, uncle; but our crosses on the wayHave made it tedious, wearisome, and heavyI want more uncles here to welcome me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Sweet prince, the untainted virtue of your yearsHath not yet dived into the world's deceitNor more can you distinguish of a manThan of his outward show; which, God he knows,Seldom or never jumpeth with the heart.Those uncles which you want were dangerous;Your grace attended to their sugar'd words,But look'd not on the poison of their hearts :God keep you from them, and from such false friends!

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: God keep me from false friends! but they were none.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: My lord, the mayor of London comes to greet you.

speaker: Lord Mayor
dialog: God bless your grace with health and happy days!

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: I thank you, good my lord; and thank you all.I thought my mother, and my brother York,Would long ere this have met us on the wayFie, what a slug is Hastings, that he comes notTo tell us whether they will come or no!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: And, in good time, here comes the sweating lord.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: Welcome, my lord: what, will our mother come?

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: On what occasion, God he knows, not I,The queen your mother, and your brother York,Have taken sanctuary: the tender princeWould fain have come with me to meet your grace,But by his mother was perforce withheld.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Fie, what an indirect and peevish courseIs this of hers! Lord cardinal, will your gracePersuade the queen to send the Duke of YorkUnto his princely brother presently?If she deny, Lord Hastings, go with him,And from her jealous arms pluck him perforce.

speaker: CARDINAL
dialog: My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak oratoryCan from his mother win the Duke of York,Anon expect him here; but if she be obdurateTo mild entreaties, God in heaven forbidWe should infringe the holy privilegeOf blessed sanctuary! not for all this landWould I be guilty of so deep a sin.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: You are too senseless--obstinate, my lord,Too ceremonious and traditionalWeigh it but with the grossness of this age,You break not sanctuary in seizing him.The benefit thereof is always grantedTo those whose dealings have deserved the place,And those who have the wit to claim the place:This prince hath neither claim'd it nor deserved it;And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it:Then, taking him from thence that is not there,You break no privilege nor charter there.Oft have I heard of sanctuary men;But sanctuary children ne'er till now.

speaker: CARDINAL
dialog: My lord, you shall o'er-rule my mind for once.Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: I go, my lord.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: Good lords, make all the speedy haste you may.Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come,Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Where it seems best unto your royal self.If I may counsel you, some day or twoYour highness shall repose you at the Tower:Then where you please, and shall be thought most fitFor your best health and recreation.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: I do not like the Tower, of any place.Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: He did, my gracious lord, begin that place;Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: Is it upon record, or else reportedSuccessively from age to age, he built it?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Upon record, my gracious lord.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: But say, my lord, it were not register'd,Methinks the truth should live from age to age,As 'twere retail'd to all posterity,Even to the general all-ending day.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: I say, without characters, fame lives long.Thus, like the formal vice, Iniquity,I moralize two meanings in one word.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: That Julius Caesar was a famous man;With what his valour did enrich his wit,His wit set down to make his valour liveDeath makes no conquest of this conqueror;For now he lives in fame, though not in life.I'll tell you what, my cousin Buckingham,--

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: What, my gracious lord?

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: An if I live until I be a man,I'll win our ancient right in France again,Or die a soldier, as I lived a king.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: Richard of York! how fares our loving brother?

speaker: YORK
dialog: Well, my dread lord; so must I call you now.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: Ay, brother, to our grief, as it is yours:Too late he died that might have kept that title,Which by his death hath lost much majesty.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: How fares our cousin, noble Lord of York?

speaker: YORK
dialog: I thank you, gentle uncle. O, my lord,You said that idle weeds are fast in growthThe prince my brother hath outgrown me far.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: He hath, my lord.

speaker: YORK
dialog: And therefore is he idle?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: O, my fair cousin, I must not say so.

speaker: YORK
dialog: Then is he more beholding to you than I.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: He may command me as my sovereign;But you have power in me as in a kinsman.

speaker: YORK
dialog: I pray you, uncle, give me this dagger.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: My dagger, little cousin? with all my heart.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: A beggar, brother?

speaker: YORK
dialog: Of my kind uncle, that I know will give;And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: A greater gift than that I'll give my cousin.

speaker: YORK
dialog: A greater gift! O, that's the sword to it.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: A gentle cousin, were it light enough.

speaker: YORK
dialog: O, then, I see, you will part but with light gifts;In weightier things you'll say a beggar nay.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: It is too heavy for your grace to wear.

speaker: YORK
dialog: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: What, would you have my weapon, little lord?

speaker: YORK
dialog: I would, that I might thank you as you call me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: How?

speaker: YORK
dialog: Little.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: My Lord of York will still be cross in talk:Uncle, your grace knows how to bear with him.

speaker: YORK
dialog: You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me:Uncle, my brother mocks both you and me;Because that I am little, like an ape,He thinks that you should bear me on your shoulders.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: With what a sharp-provided wit he reasons!To mitigate the scorn he gives his uncle,He prettily and aptly taunts himself:So cunning and so young is wonderful.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: My lord, will't please you pass along?Myself and my good cousin BuckinghamWill to your mother, to entreat of herTo meet you at the Tower and welcome you.

speaker: YORK
dialog: What, will you go unto the Tower, my lord?

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: My lord protector needs will have it so.

speaker: YORK
dialog: I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Why, what should you fear?

speaker: YORK
dialog: Marry, my uncle Clarence' angry ghost:My grandam told me he was murdered there.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: I fear no uncles dead.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Nor none that live, I hope.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
dialog: An if they live, I hope I need not fear.But come, my lord; and with a heavy heart,Thinking on them, go I unto the Tower.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Think you, my lord, this little prating YorkWas not incensed by his subtle motherTo taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: No doubt, no doubt; O, 'tis a parlous boy;Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capableHe is all the mother's, from the top to toe.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Well, let them rest. Come hither, Catesby.Thou art sworn as deeply to effect what we intendAs closely to conceal what we impart:Thou know'st our reasons urged upon the way;What think'st thou? is it not an easy matterTo make William Lord Hastings of our mind,For the instalment of this noble dukeIn the seat royal of this famous isle?

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: He for his father's sake so loves the prince,That he will not be won to aught against him.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: What think'st thou, then, of Stanley? what will he?

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: He will do all in all as Hastings doth.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Well, then, no more but this: go, gentle Catesby,And, as it were far off sound thou Lord Hastings,How doth he stand affected to our purpose;And summon him to-morrow to the Tower,To sit about the coronation.If thou dost find him tractable to us,Encourage him, and show him all our reasons:If he be leaden, icy-cold, unwilling,Be thou so too; and so break off your talk,And give us notice of his inclination:For we to-morrow hold divided councils,Wherein thyself shalt highly be employ'd.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Commend me to Lord William: tell him, Catesby,His ancient knot of dangerous adversariesTo-morrow are let blood at Pomfret-castle;And bid my friend, for joy of this good news,Give mistress Shore one gentle kiss the more.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Good Catesby, go, effect this business soundly.

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: My good lords both, with all the heed I may.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: You shall, my lord.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: At Crosby Place, there shall you find us both.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Now, my lord, what shall we do, if we perceiveLord Hastings will not yield to our complots?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Chop off his head, man; somewhat we will do:And, look, when I am king, claim thou of meThe earldom of Hereford, and the moveablesWhereof the king my brother stood possess'd.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: I'll claim that promise at your grace's hands.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: And look to have it yielded with all willingness.Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwardsWe may digest our complots in some form.

speaker: Messenger
dialog: What, ho! my lord!

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: What is't o'clock?

speaker: Messenger
dialog: Upon the stroke of four.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: Cannot thy master sleep these tedious nights?

speaker: Messenger
dialog: So it should seem by that I have to say.First, he commends him to your noble lordship.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: And then?

speaker: Messenger
dialog: And then he sends you wordHe dreamt to-night the boar had razed his helm:Besides, he says there are two councils held;And that may be determined at the onewhich may make you and him to rue at the other.Therefore he sends to know your lordship's pleasure,If presently you will take horse with him,And with all speed post with him toward the north,To shun the danger that his soul divines.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: Go, fellow, go, return unto thy lord;Bid him not fear the separated councilsHis honour and myself are at the one,And at the other is my servant CatesbyWhere nothing can proceed that toucheth usWhereof I shall not have intelligence.Tell him his fears are shallow, wanting instance:And for his dreams, I wonder he is so fondTo trust the mockery of unquiet slumbersTo fly the boar before the boar pursues,Were to incense the boar to follow usAnd make pursuit where he did mean no chase.Go, bid thy master rise and come to meAnd we will both together to the Tower,Where, he shall see, the boar will use us kindly.

speaker: Messenger
dialog: My gracious lord, I'll tell him what you say.

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: Many good morrows to my noble lord!

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: Good morrow, Catesby; you are early stirringWhat news, what news, in this our tottering state?

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: It is a reeling world, indeed, my lord;And I believe twill never stand uprightTim Richard wear the garland of the realm.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: How! wear the garland! dost thou mean the crown?

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: Ay, my good lord.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: I'll have this crown of mine cut from my shouldersEre I will see the crown so foul misplaced.But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it?

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: Ay, on my life; and hopes to find forwardUpon his party for the gain thereof:And thereupon he sends you this good news,That this same very day your enemies,The kindred of the queen, must die at Pomfret.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: Indeed, I am no mourner for that news,Because they have been still mine enemies:But, that I'll give my voice on Richard's side,To bar my master's heirs in true descent,God knows I will not do it, to the death.

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: God keep your lordship in that gracious mind!

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: But I shall laugh at this a twelve-month hence,That they who brought me in my master's hateI live to look upon their tragedy.I tell thee, Catesby--

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: What, my lord?

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: Ere a fortnight make me elder,I'll send some packing that yet think not on it.

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: 'Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord,When men are unprepared and look not for it.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: O monstrous, monstrous! and so falls it outWith Rivers, Vaughan, Grey: and so 'twill doWith some men else, who think themselves as safeAs thou and I; who, as thou know'st, are dearTo princely Richard and to Buckingham.

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: The princes both make high account of you;For they account his head upon the bridge.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: I know they do; and I have well deserved it.Come on, come on; where is your boar-spear, man?Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided?

speaker: STANLEY
dialog: My lord, good morrow; good morrow, Catesby:You may jest on, but, by the holy rood,I do not like these several councils, I.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: My lord,I hold my life as dear as you do yours;And never in my life, I do protest,Was it more precious to me than 'tis now:Think you, but that I know our state secure,I would be so triumphant as I am?

speaker: STANLEY
dialog: The lords at Pomfret, when they rode from London,Were jocund, and supposed their state was sure,And they indeed had no cause to mistrust;But yet, you see how soon the day o'ercast.This sudden stag of rancour I misdoubt:Pray God, I say, I prove a needless coward!What, shall we toward the Tower? the day is spent.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: Come, come, have with you. Wot you what, my lord?To-day the lords you talk of are beheaded.

speaker: LORD STANLEY
dialog: They, for their truth, might better wear their headsThan some that have accused them wear their hats.But come, my lord, let us away.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: Go on before; I'll talk with this good fellow.How now, sirrah! how goes the world with thee?

speaker: Pursuivant
dialog: The better that your lordship please to ask.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: I tell thee, man, 'tis better with me nowThan when I met thee last where now we meet:Then was I going prisoner to the Tower,By the suggestion of the queen's allies;But now, I tell thee--keep it to thyself--This day those enemies are put to death,And I in better state than e'er I was.

speaker: Pursuivant
dialog: God hold it, to your honour's good content!

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: Gramercy, fellow: there, drink that for me.

speaker: Pursuivant
dialog: God save your lordship!

speaker: Priest
dialog: Well met, my lord; I am glad to see your honour.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: I thank thee, good Sir John, with all my heart.I am in your debt for your last exercise;Come the next Sabbath, and I will content you.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: What, talking with a priest, lord chamberlain?Your friends at Pomfret, they do need the priest;Your honour hath no shriving work in hand.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: Good faith, and when I met this holy man,Those men you talk of came into my mind.What, go you toward the Tower?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: I do, my lord; but long I shall not stayI shall return before your lordship thence.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: I'll wait upon your lordship.

speaker: RATCLIFF
dialog: Come, bring forth the prisoners.

speaker: RIVERS
dialog: Sir Richard Ratcliff, let me tell thee this:To-day shalt thou behold a subject dieFor truth, for duty, and for loyalty.

speaker: GREY
dialog: God keep the prince from all the pack of you!A knot you are of damned blood-suckers!

speaker: VAUGHAN
dialog: You live that shall cry woe for this after.

speaker: RATCLIFF
dialog: Dispatch; the limit of your lives is out.

speaker: RIVERS
dialog: O Pomfret, Pomfret! O thou bloody prison,Fatal and ominous to noble peers!Within the guilty closure of thy wallsRichard the second here was hack'd to death;And, for more slander to thy dismal seat,We give thee up our guiltless blood to drink.

speaker: GREY
dialog: Now Margaret's curse is fall'n upon our heads,For standing by when Richard stabb'd her son.

speaker: RIVERS
dialog: Then cursed she Hastings, then cursed she Buckingham,Then cursed she Richard. O, remember, GodTo hear her prayers for them, as now for usAnd for my sister and her princely sons,Be satisfied, dear God, with our true blood,Which, as thou know'st, unjustly must be spilt.

speaker: RATCLIFF
dialog: Make haste; the hour of death is expiate.

speaker: RIVERS
dialog: Come, Grey, come, Vaughan, let us all embrace:And take our leave, until we meet in heaven.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: My lords, at once: the cause why we are metIs, to determine of the coronation.In God's name, speak: when is the royal day?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Are all things fitting for that royal time?

speaker: DERBY
dialog: It is, and wants but nomination.

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
dialog: To-morrow, then, I judge a happy day.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Who knows the lord protector's mind herein?Who is most inward with the royal duke?

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
dialog: Your grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Who, I, my lord I we know each other's faces,But for our hearts, he knows no more of mine,Than I of yours;Nor I no more of his, than you of mine.Lord Hastings, you and he are near in love.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: I thank his grace, I know he loves me well;But, for his purpose in the coronation.I have not sounded him, nor he deliver'dHis gracious pleasure any way therein:But you, my noble lords, may name the time;And in the duke's behalf I'll give my voice,Which, I presume, he'll take in gentle part.

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
dialog: Now in good time, here comes the duke himself.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow.I have been long a sleeper; but, I hope,My absence doth neglect no great designs,Which by my presence might have been concluded.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Had not you come upon your cue, my lordWilliam Lord Hastings had pronounced your part,--I mean, your voice,--for crowning of the king.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder;His lordship knows me well, and loves me well.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: I thank your grace.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: My lord of Ely!

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
dialog: My lord?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: When I was last in Holborn,I saw good strawberries in your garden thereI do beseech you send for some of them.

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
dialog: Marry, and will, my lord, with all my heart.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.Catesby hath sounded Hastings in our business,And finds the testy gentleman so hot,As he will lose his head ere give consentHis master's son, as worshipful as he terms it,Shall lose the royalty of England's throne.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Withdraw you hence, my lord, I'll follow you.

speaker: DERBY
dialog: We have not yet set down this day of triumph.To-morrow, in mine opinion, is too sudden;For I myself am not so well providedAs else I would be, were the day prolong'd.

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
dialog: Where is my lord protector? I have sent for thesestrawberries.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: His grace looks cheerfully and smooth to-day;There's some conceit or other likes him well,When he doth bid good morrow with such a spirit.I think there's never a man in ChristendomThat can less hide his love or hate than he;For by his face straight shall you know his heart.

speaker: DERBY
dialog: What of his heart perceive you in his faceBy any likelihood he show'd to-day?

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: Marry, that with no man here he is offended;For, were he, he had shown it in his looks.

speaker: DERBY
dialog: I pray God he be not, I say.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: I pray you all, tell me what they deserveThat do conspire my death with devilish plotsOf damned witchcraft, and that have prevail'dUpon my body with their hellish charms?

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: The tender love I bear your grace, my lord,Makes me most forward in this noble presenceTo doom the offenders, whatsoever they beI say, my lord, they have deserved death.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Then be your eyes the witness of this ill:See how I am bewitch'd; behold mine armIs, like a blasted sapling, wither'd up:And this is Edward's wife, that monstrous witch,Consorted with that harlot strumpet Shore,That by their witchcraft thus have marked me.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: If they have done this thing, my gracious lord--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: If I thou protector of this damned strumpet--Tellest thou me of 'ifs'?  Thou art a traitor:Off with his head! Now, by Saint Paul I swear,I will not dine until I see the same.Lovel and Ratcliff, look that it be done:The rest, that love me, rise and follow me.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: Woe, woe for England! not a whit for me;For I, too fond, might have prevented this.Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm;But I disdain'd it, and did scorn to fly:Three times to-day my foot-cloth horse did stumble,And startled, when he look'd upon the Tower,As loath to bear me to the slaughter-house.O, now I want the priest that spake to me:I now repent I told the pursuivantAs 'twere triumphing at mine enemies,How they at Pomfret bloodily were butcher'd,And I myself secure in grace and favour.O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curseIs lighted on poor Hastings' wretched head!

speaker: RATCLIFF
dialog: Dispatch, my lord; the duke would be at dinner:Make a short shrift; he longs to see your head.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: O momentary grace of mortal men,Which we more hunt for than the grace of God!Who builds his hopes in air of your good looks,Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast,Ready, with every nod, to tumble downInto the fatal bowels of the deep.

speaker: LOVEL
dialog: Come, come, dispatch; 'tis bootless to exclaim.

speaker: HASTINGS
dialog: O bloody Richard! miserable England!I prophesy the fearful'st time to theeThat ever wretched age hath look'd upon.Come, lead me to the block; bear him my head.They smile at me that shortly shall be dead.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Come, cousin, canst thou quake, and change thy colour,Murder thy breath in the middle of a word,And then begin again, and stop again,As if thou wert distraught and mad with terror?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Tut, I can counterfeit the deep tragedian;Speak and look back, and pry on every side,Tremble and start at wagging of a straw,Intending deep suspicion: ghastly looksAre at my service, like enforced smiles;And both are ready in their offices,At any time, to grace my stratagems.But what, is Catesby gone?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: He is; and, see, he brings the mayor along.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Lord mayor,--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Look to the drawbridge there!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Hark! a drum.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Catesby, o'erlook the walls.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Lord mayor, the reason we have sent--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Look back, defend thee, here are enemies.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: God and our innocency defend and guard us!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Be patient, they are friends, Ratcliff and Lovel.

speaker: LOVEL
dialog: Here is the head of that ignoble traitor,The dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: So dear I loved the man, that I must weep.I took him for the plainest harmless creatureThat breathed upon this earth a Christian;Made him my book wherein my soul recordedThe history of all her secret thoughts:So smooth he daub'd his vice with show of virtue,That, his apparent open guilt omitted,I mean, his conversation with Shore's wife,He lived from all attainder of suspect.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Well, well, he was the covert'st shelter'd traitorThat ever lived.Would you imagine, or almost believe,Were't not that, by great preservation,We live to tell it you, the subtle traitorThis day had plotted, in the council-houseTo murder me and my good Lord of Gloucester?

speaker: Lord Mayor
dialog: What, had he so?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: What, think You we are Turks or infidels?Or that we would, against the form of law,Proceed thus rashly to the villain's death,But that the extreme peril of the case,The peace of England and our persons' safety,Enforced us to this execution?

speaker: Lord Mayor
dialog: Now, fair befall you! he deserved his death;And you my good lords, both have well proceeded,To warn false traitors from the like attempts.I never look'd for better at his hands,After he once fell in with Mistress Shore.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Yet had not we determined he should die,Until your lordship came to see his death;Which now the loving haste of these our friends,Somewhat against our meaning, have prevented:Because, my lord, we would have had you heardThe traitor speak, and timorously confessThe manner and the purpose of his treason;That you might well have signified the sameUnto the citizens, who haply mayMisconstrue us in him and wail his death.

speaker: Lord Mayor
dialog: But, my good lord, your grace's word shall serve,As well as I had seen and heard him speakAnd doubt you not, right noble princes both,But I'll acquaint our duteous citizensWith all your just proceedings in this cause.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: And to that end we wish'd your lord-ship here,To avoid the carping censures of the world.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: But since you come too late of our intents,Yet witness what you hear we did intend:And so, my good lord mayor, we bid farewell.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Go, after, after, cousin Buckingham.The mayor towards Guildhall hies him in all post:There, at your meet'st advantage of the time,Infer the bastardy of Edward's children:Tell them how Edward put to death a citizen,Only for saying he would make his sonHeir to the crown; meaning indeed his house,Which, by the sign thereof was termed so.Moreover, urge his hateful luxuryAnd bestial appetite in change of lust;Which stretched to their servants, daughters, wives,Even where his lustful eye or savage heart,Without control, listed to make his prey.Nay, for a need, thus far come near my person:Tell them, when that my mother went with childOf that unsatiate Edward, noble YorkMy princely father then had wars in FranceAnd, by just computation of the time,Found that the issue was not his begot;Which well appeared in his lineaments,Being nothing like the noble duke my father:But touch this sparingly, as 'twere far off,Because you know, my lord, my mother lives.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Fear not, my lord, I'll play the oratorAs if the golden fee for which I pleadWere for myself: and so, my lord, adieu.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: If you thrive well, bring them to Baynard's Castle;Where you shall find me well accompaniedWith reverend fathers and well-learned bishops.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: I go: and towards three or four o'clockLook for the news that the Guildhall affords.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Go, Lovel, with all speed to Doctor Shaw;Go thou to Friar Penker; bid them bothMeet me within this hour at Baynard's Castle.Now will I in, to take some privy order,To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight;And to give notice, that no manner of personAt any time have recourse unto the princes.

speaker: Scrivener
dialog: This is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings;Which in a set hand fairly is engross'd,That it may be this day read over in Paul's.And mark how well the sequel hangs together:Eleven hours I spent to write it over,For yesternight by Catesby was it brought me;The precedent was full as long a-doing:And yet within these five hours lived Lord Hastings,Untainted, unexamined, free, at libertyHere's a good world the while! Why who's so gross,That seeth not this palpable device?Yet who's so blind, but says he sees it not?Bad is the world; and all will come to nought,When such bad dealings must be seen in thought.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: How now, my lord, what say the citizens?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Now, by the holy mother of our Lord,The citizens are mum and speak not a word.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Touch'd you the bastardy of Edward's children?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: I did; with his contract with Lady Lucy,And his contract by deputy in France;The insatiate greediness of his desires,And his enforcement of the city wives;His tyranny for trifles; his own bastardy,As being got, your father then in France,His resemblance, being not like the duke;Withal I did infer your lineaments,Being the right idea of your father,Both in your form and nobleness of mind;Laid open all your victories in Scotland,Your dicipline in war, wisdom in peace,Your bounty, virtue, fair humility:Indeed, left nothing fitting for the purposeUntouch'd, or slightly handled, in discourseAnd when mine oratory grew to an endI bid them that did love their country's goodCry 'God save Richard, England's royal king!'

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Ah! and did they so?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: No, so God help me, they spake not a word;But, like dumb statues or breathing stones,Gazed each on other, and look'd deadly pale.Which when I saw, I reprehended them;And ask'd the mayor what meant this wilful silence:His answer was, the people were not wontTo be spoke to but by the recorder.Then he was urged to tell my tale again,'Thus saith the duke, thus hath the duke inferr'd;'But nothing spake in warrant from himself.When he had done, some followers of mine own,At the lower end of the hall, hurl'd up their caps,And some ten voices cried 'God save King Richard!'And thus I took the vantage of those few,'Thanks, gentle citizens and friends,' quoth I;'This general applause and loving shoutArgues your wisdoms and your love to Richard:'And even here brake off, and came away.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: What tongueless blocks were they! would not they speak?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: No, by my troth, my lord.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Will not the mayor then and his brethren come?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: The mayor is here at hand: intend some fear;Be not you spoke with, but by mighty suit:And look you get a prayer-book in your hand,And stand betwixt two churchmen, good my lord;For on that ground I'll build a holy descant:And be not easily won to our request:Play the maid's part, still answer nay, and take it.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: I go; and if you plead as well for themAs I can say nay to thee for myself,No doubt well bring it to a happy issue.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Go, go, up to the leads; the lord mayor knocks.Welcome my lord; I dance attendance here;I think the duke will not be spoke withal.Here comes his servant: how now, Catesby,What says he?

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: My lord: he doth entreat your grace;To visit him to-morrow or next day:He is within, with two right reverend fathers,Divinely bent to meditation;And no worldly suit would he be moved,To draw him from his holy exercise.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Return, good Catesby, to thy lord again;Tell him, myself, the mayor and citizens,In deep designs and matters of great moment,No less importing than our general good,Are come to have some conference with his grace.

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: I'll tell him what you say, my lord.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Ah, ha, my lord, this prince is not an Edward!He is not lolling on a lewd day-bed,But on his knees at meditation;Not dallying with a brace of courtezans,But meditating with two deep divines;Not sleeping, to engross his idle body,But praying, to enrich his watchful soul:Happy were England, would this gracious princeTake on himself the sovereignty thereof:But, sure, I fear, we shall ne'er win him to it.

speaker: Lord Mayor
dialog: Marry, God forbid his grace should say us nay!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: I fear he will.How now, Catesby, what says your lord?

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: My lord,He wonders to what end you have assembledSuch troops of citizens to speak with him,His grace not being warn'd thereof before:My lord, he fears you mean no good to him.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Sorry I am my noble cousin shouldSuspect me, that I mean no good to him:By heaven, I come in perfect love to him;And so once more return and tell his grace.When holy and devout religious menAre at their beads, 'tis hard to draw them thence,So sweet is zealous contemplation.

speaker: Lord Mayor
dialog: See, where he stands between two clergymen!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Two props of virtue for a Christian prince,To stay him from the fall of vanity:And, see, a book of prayer in his hand,True ornaments to know a holy man.Famous Plantagenet, most gracious prince,Lend favourable ears to our request;And pardon us the interruptionOf thy devotion and right Christian zeal.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: My lord, there needs no such apology:I rather do beseech you pardon me,Who, earnest in the service of my God,Neglect the visitation of my friends.But, leaving this, what is your grace's pleasure?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Even that, I hope, which pleaseth God above,And all good men of this ungovern'd isle.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: I do suspect I have done some offenceThat seems disgracious in the city's eyes,And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: You have, my lord: would it might please your grace,At our entreaties, to amend that fault!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Else wherefore breathe I in a Christian land?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Then know, it is your fault that you resignThe supreme seat, the throne majestical,The scepter'd office of your ancestors,Your state of fortune and your due of birth,The lineal glory of your royal house,To the corruption of a blemished stock:Whilst, in the mildness of your sleepy thoughts,Which here we waken to our country's good,This noble isle doth want her proper limbs;Her face defaced with scars of infamy,Her royal stock graft with ignoble plants,And almost shoulder'd in the swallowing gulfOf blind forgetfulness and dark oblivion.Which to recure, we heartily solicitYour gracious self to take on you the chargeAnd kingly government of this your land,Not as protector, steward, substitute,Or lowly factor for another's gain;But as successively from blood to blood,Your right of birth, your empery, your own.For this, consorted with the citizens,Your very worshipful and loving friends,And by their vehement instigation,In this just suit come I to move your grace.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: I know not whether to depart in silence,Or bitterly to speak in your reproof.Best fitteth my degree or your conditionIf not to answer, you might haply thinkTongue-tied ambition, not replying, yieldedTo bear the golden yoke of sovereignty,Which fondly you would here impose on me;If to reprove you for this suit of yours,So season'd with your faithful love to me.Then, on the other side, I cheque'd my friends.Therefore, to speak, and to avoid the first,And then, in speaking, not to incur the last,Definitively thus I answer you.Your love deserves my thanks; but my desertUnmeritable shuns your high request.First if all obstacles were cut away,And that my path were even to the crown,As my ripe revenue and due by birthYet so much is my poverty of spirit,So mighty and so many my defects,As I had rather hide me from my greatness,Being a bark to brook no mighty sea,Than in my greatness covet to be hid,And in the vapour of my glory smother'd.But, God be thank'd, there's no need of me,And much I need to help you, if need were;The royal tree hath left us royal fruit,Which, mellow'd by the stealing hours of time,Will well become the seat of majesty,And make, no doubt, us happy by his reign.On him I lay what you would lay on me,The right and fortune of his happy stars;Which God defend that I should wring from him!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: My lord, this argues conscience in your grace;But the respects thereof are nice and trivial,All circumstances well considered.You say that Edward is your brother's son:So say we too, but not by Edward's wife;For first he was contract to Lady Lucy--Your mother lives a witness to that vow--And afterward by substitute betroth'dTo Bona, sister to the King of France.These both put by a poor petitioner,A care-crazed mother of a many children,A beauty-waning and distressed widow,Even in the afternoon of her best days,Made prize and purchase of his lustful eye,Seduced the pitch and height of all his thoughtsTo base declension and loathed bigamyBy her, in his unlawful bed, he gotThis Edward, whom our manners term the prince.More bitterly could I expostulate,Save that, for reverence to some alive,I give a sparing limit to my tongue.Then, good my lord, take to your royal selfThis proffer'd benefit of dignity;If non to bless us and the land withal,Yet to draw forth your noble ancestryFrom the corruption of abusing times,Unto a lineal true-derived course.

speaker: Lord Mayor
dialog: Do, good my lord, your citizens entreat you.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Refuse not, mighty lord, this proffer'd love.

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: O, make them joyful, grant their lawful suit!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Alas, why would you heap these cares on me?I am unfit for state and majesty;I do beseech you, take it not amiss;I cannot nor I will not yield to you.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: If you refuse it,--as, in love and zeal,Loath to depose the child, Your brother's son;As well we know your tenderness of heartAnd gentle, kind, effeminate remorse,Which we have noted in you to your kin,And egally indeed to all estates,--Yet whether you accept our suit or no,Your brother's son shall never reign our king;But we will plant some other in the throne,To the disgrace and downfall of your house:And in this resolution here we leave you.--Come, citizens: 'zounds! I'll entreat no more.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: O, do not swear, my lord of Buckingham.

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: Call them again, my lord, and accept their suit.

speaker: ANOTHER
dialog: Do, good my lord, lest all the land do rue it.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Would you enforce me to a world of care?Well, call them again. I am not made of stone,But penetrable to your. kind entreats,Albeit against my conscience and my soul.Cousin of Buckingham, and you sage, grave men,Since you will buckle fortune on my back,To bear her burthen, whether I will or no,I must have patience to endure the load:But if black scandal or foul-faced reproachAttend the sequel of your imposition,Your mere enforcement shall acquittance meFrom all the impure blots and stains thereof;For God he knows, and you may partly see,How far I am from the desire thereof.

speaker: Lord Mayor
dialog: God bless your grace! we see it, and will say it.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: In saying so, you shall but say the truth.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Then I salute you with this kingly title:Long live Richard, England's royal king!

speaker: Lord Mayor
dialog: Amen.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: To-morrow will it please you to be crown'd?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Even when you please, since you will have it so.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: To-morrow, then, we will attend your grace:And so most joyfully we take our leave.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
dialog: Come, let us to our holy task again.Farewell, good cousin; farewell, gentle friends.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: Who meets us here?  my niece PlantagenetLed in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester?Now, for my life, she's wandering to the Tower,On pure heart's love to greet the tender princes.Daughter, well met.

speaker: LADY ANNE
dialog: God give your graces bothA happy and a joyful time of day!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: As much to you, good sister! Whither away?

speaker: LADY ANNE
dialog: No farther than the Tower; and, as I guess,Upon the like devotion as yourselves,To gratulate the gentle princes there.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Kind sister, thanks: we'll enter all together.And, in good time, here the lieutenant comes.Master lieutenant, pray you, by your leave,How doth the prince, and my young son of York?

speaker: BRAKENBURY
dialog: Right well, dear madam. By your patience,I may not suffer you to visit them;The king hath straitly charged the contrary.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: The king! why, who's that?

speaker: BRAKENBURY
dialog: I cry you mercy: I mean the lord protector.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: The Lord protect him from that kingly title!Hath he set bounds betwixt their love and me?I am their mother; who should keep me from them?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: I am their fathers mother; I will see them.

speaker: LADY ANNE
dialog: Their aunt I am in law, in love their mother:Then bring me to their sights; I'll bear thy blameAnd take thy office from thee, on my peril.

speaker: BRAKENBURY
dialog: No, madam, no; I may not leave it so:I am bound by oath, and therefore pardon me.

speaker: LORD STANLEY
dialog: Let me but meet you, ladies, one hour hence,And I'll salute your grace of York as mother,And reverend looker on, of two fair queens.Come, madam, you must straight to Westminster,There to be crowned Richard's royal queen.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: O, cut my lace in sunder, that my pent heartMay have some scope to beat, or else I swoonWith this dead-killing news!

speaker: LADY ANNE
dialog: Despiteful tidings! O unpleasing news!

speaker: DORSET
dialog: Be of good cheer: mother, how fares your grace?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: O Dorset, speak not to me, get thee hence!Death and destruction dog thee at the heels;Thy mother's name is ominous to children.If thou wilt outstrip death, go cross the seas,And live with Richmond, from the reach of hellGo, hie thee, hie thee from this slaughter-house,Lest thou increase the number of the dead;And make me die the thrall of Margaret's curse,Nor mother, wife, nor England's counted queen.

speaker: LORD STANLEY
dialog: Full of wise care is this your counsel, madam.Take all the swift advantage of the hours;You shall have letters from me to my sonTo meet you on the way, and welcome you.Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: O ill-dispersing wind of misery!O my accursed womb, the bed of death!A cockatrice hast thou hatch'd to the world,Whose unavoided eye is murderous.

speaker: LORD STANLEY
dialog: Come, madam, come; I in all haste was sent.

speaker: LADY ANNE
dialog: And I in all unwillingness will go.I would to God that the inclusive vergeOf golden metal that must round my browWere red-hot steel, to sear me to the brain!Anointed let me be with deadly venom,And die, ere men can say, God save the queen!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Go, go, poor soul, I envy not thy gloryTo feed my humour, wish thyself no harm.

speaker: LADY ANNE
dialog: No! why?  When he that is my husband nowCame to me, as I follow'd Henry's corse,When scarce the blood was well wash'd from his handsWhich issued from my other angel husbandAnd that dead saint which then I weeping follow'd;O, when, I say, I look'd on Richard's face,This was my wish: 'Be thou,' quoth I, ' accursed,For making me, so young, so old a widow!And, when thou wed'st, let sorrow haunt thy bed;And be thy wife--if any be so mad--As miserable by the life of theeAs thou hast made me by my dear lord's death!Lo, ere I can repeat this curse again,Even in so short a space, my woman's heartGrossly grew captive to his honey wordsAnd proved the subject of my own soul's curse,Which ever since hath kept my eyes from rest;For never yet one hour in his bedHave I enjoy'd the golden dew of sleep,But have been waked by his timorous dreams.Besides, he hates me for my father Warwick;And will, no doubt, shortly be rid of me.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Poor heart, adieu! I pity thy complaining.

speaker: LADY ANNE
dialog: No more than from my soul I mourn for yours.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Farewell, thou woful welcomer of glory!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Stay, yet look back with me unto the Tower.Pity, you ancient stones, those tender babesWhom envy hath immured within your walls!Rough cradle for such little pretty ones!Rude ragged nurse, old sullen playfellowFor tender princes, use my babies well!So foolish sorrow bids your stones farewell.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Stand all apart Cousin of Buckingham!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: My gracious sovereign?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Give me thy hand.Thus high, by thy adviceAnd thy assistance, is King Richard seated;But shall we wear these honours for a day?Or shall they last, and we rejoice in them?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Still live they and for ever may they last!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: O Buckingham, now do I play the touch,To try if thou be current gold indeedYoung Edward lives: think now what I would say.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Say on, my loving lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Why, Buckingham, I say, I would be king,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Why, so you are, my thrice renowned liege.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Ha! am I king? 'tis so: but Edward lives.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: True, noble prince.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: O bitter consequence,That Edward still should live! 'True, noble prince!'Cousin, thou wert not wont to be so dull:Shall I be plain? I wish the bastards dead;And I would have it suddenly perform'd.What sayest thou? speak suddenly; be brief.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Your grace may do your pleasure.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Tut, tut, thou art all ice, thy kindness freezeth:Say, have I thy consent that they shall die?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: I will converse with iron-witted foolsAnd unrespective boys: none are for meThat look into me with considerate eyes:High-reaching Buckingham grows circumspect.Boy!

speaker: Page
dialog: My lord?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Know'st thou not any whom corrupting goldWould tempt unto a close exploit of death?

speaker: Page
dialog: My lord, I know a discontented gentleman,Whose humble means match not his haughty mind:Gold were as good as twenty orators,And will, no doubt, tempt him to any thing.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: What is his name?

speaker: Page
dialog: His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: I partly know the man: go, call him hither.The deep-revolving witty BuckinghamNo more shall be the neighbour to my counsel:Hath he so long held out with me untired,And stops he now for breath?How now! what news with you?

speaker: STANLEY
dialog: My lord, I hear the Marquis Dorset's fledTo Richmond, in those parts beyond the seaWhere he abides.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Catesby!

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: My lord?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Rumour it abroadThat Anne, my wife, is sick and like to die:I will take order for her keeping close.Inquire me out some mean-born gentleman,Whom I will marry straight to Clarence' daughter:The boy is foolish, and I fear not him.Look, how thou dream'st! I say again, give outThat Anne my wife is sick and like to die:About it; for it stands me much upon,To stop all hopes whose growth may damage me.I must be married to my brother's daughter,Or else my kingdom stands on brittle glass.Murder her brothers, and then marry her!Uncertain way of gain! But I am inSo far in blood that sin will pluck on sin:Tear-falling pity dwells not in this eye.Is thy name Tyrrel?

speaker: TYRREL
dialog: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Art thou, indeed?

speaker: TYRREL
dialog: Prove me, my gracious sovereign.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Darest thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?

speaker: TYRREL
dialog: Ay, my lord;But I had rather kill two enemies.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Why, there thou hast it: two deep enemies,Foes to my rest and my sweet sleep's disturbersAre they that I would have thee deal upon:Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.

speaker: TYRREL
dialog: Let me have open means to come to them,And soon I'll rid you from the fear of them.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Thou sing'st sweet music. Hark, come hither, TyrrelGo, by this token: rise, and lend thine ear:There is no more but so: say it is done,And I will love thee, and prefer thee too.

speaker: TYRREL
dialog: 'Tis done, my gracious lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Shall we hear from thee, Tyrrel, ere we sleep?

speaker: TYRREL
dialog: Ye shall, my Lord.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: My Lord, I have consider'd in my mindThe late demand that you did sound me in.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Well, let that pass. Dorset is fled to Richmond.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: I hear that news, my lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Stanley, he is your wife's son well, look to it.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: My lord, I claim your gift, my due by promise,For which your honour and your faith is pawn'd;The earldom of Hereford and the moveablesThe which you promised I should possess.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Stanley, look to your wife; if she conveyLetters to Richmond, you shall answer it.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: What says your highness to my just demand?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: As I remember, Henry the SixthDid prophesy that Richmond should be king,When Richmond was a little peevish boy.A king, perhaps, perhaps,--

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: My lord!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: How chance the prophet could not at that timeHave told me, I being by, that I should kill him?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: My lord, your promise for the earldom,--

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Richmond! When last I was at Exeter,The mayor in courtesy show'd me the castle,And call'd it Rougemont: at which name I started,Because a bard of Ireland told me onceI should not live long after I saw Richmond.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: My Lord!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Ay, what's o'clock?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: I am thus bold to put your grace in mindOf what you promised me.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Well, but what's o'clock?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Upon the stroke of ten.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Well, let it strike.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Why let it strike?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Because that, like a Jack, thou keep'st the strokeBetwixt thy begging and my meditation.I am not in the giving vein to-day.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Why, then resolve me whether you will or no.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Tut, tut,Thou troublest me; am not in the vein.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
dialog: Is it even so? rewards he my true serviceWith such deep contempt made I him king for this?O, let me think on Hastings, and be goneTo Brecknock, while my fearful head is on!

speaker: TYRREL
dialog: The tyrannous and bloody deed is done.The most arch of piteous massacreThat ever yet this land was guilty of.Dighton and Forrest, whom I did subornTo do this ruthless piece of butchery,Although they were flesh'd villains, bloody dogs,Melting with tenderness and kind compassionWept like two children in their deaths' sad stories.'Lo, thus' quoth Dighton, 'lay those tender babes:''Thus, thus,' quoth Forrest, 'girdling one anotherWithin their innocent alabaster arms:Their lips were four red roses on a stalk,Which in their summer beauty kiss'd each other.A book of prayers on their pillow lay;Which once,' quoth Forrest, 'almost changed my mind;But O! the devil'--there the villain stopp'dWhilst Dighton thus told on: 'We smotheredThe most replenished sweet work of nature,That from the prime creation e'er she framed.'Thus both are gone with conscience and remorse;They could not speak; and so I left them both,To bring this tidings to the bloody king.And here he comes.All hail, my sovereign liege!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Kind Tyrrel, am I happy in thy news?

speaker: TYRREL
dialog: If to have done the thing you gave in chargeBeget your happiness, be happy then,For it is done, my lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: But didst thou see them dead?

speaker: TYRREL
dialog: I did, my lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: And buried, gentle Tyrrel?

speaker: TYRREL
dialog: The chaplain of the Tower hath buried them;But how or in what place I do not know.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Come to me, Tyrrel, soon at after supper,And thou shalt tell the process of their death.Meantime, but think how I may do thee good,And be inheritor of thy desire.Farewell till soon.The son of Clarence have I pent up close;His daughter meanly have I match'd in marriage;The sons of Edward sleep in Abraham's bosom,And Anne my wife hath bid the world good night.Now, for I know the Breton Richmond aimsAt young Elizabeth, my brother's daughter,And, by that knot, looks proudly o'er the crown,To her I go, a jolly thriving wooer.

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: My lord!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Good news or bad, that thou comest in so bluntly?

speaker: CATESBY
dialog: Bad news, my lord: Ely is fled to Richmond;And Buckingham, back'd with the hardy Welshmen,Is in the field, and still his power increaseth.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Ely with Richmond troubles me more nearThan Buckingham and his rash-levied army.Come, I have heard that fearful commentingIs leaden servitor to dull delay;Delay leads impotent and snail-paced beggaryThen fiery expedition be my wing,Jove's Mercury, and herald for a king!Come, muster men: my counsel is my shield;We must be brief when traitors brave the field.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
dialog: So, now prosperity begins to mellowAnd drop into the rotten mouth of death.Here in these confines slily have I lurk'd,To watch the waning of mine adversaries.A dire induction am I witness to,And will to France, hoping the consequenceWill prove as bitter, black, and tragical.Withdraw thee, wretched Margaret: who comes here?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Ah, my young princes! ah, my tender babes!My unblown flowers, new-appearing sweets!If yet your gentle souls fly in the airAnd be not fix'd in doom perpetual,Hover about me with your airy wingsAnd hear your mother's lamentation!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
dialog: Hover about her; say, that right for rightHath dimm'd your infant morn to aged night.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: So many miseries have crazed my voice,That my woe-wearied tongue is mute and dumb,Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
dialog: Plantagenet doth quit Plantagenet.Edward for Edward pays a dying debt.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Wilt thou, O God, fly from such gentle lambs,And throw them in the entrails of the wolf?When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
dialog: When holy Harry died, and my sweet son.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: Blind sight, dead life, poor mortal living ghost,Woe's scene, world's shame, grave's due by life usurp'd,Brief abstract and record of tedious days,Rest thy unrest on England's lawful earth,Unlawfully made drunk with innocents' blood!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: O, that thou wouldst as well afford a graveAs thou canst yield a melancholy seat!Then would I hide my bones, not rest them here.O, who hath any cause to mourn but I?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
dialog: If ancient sorrow be most reverend,Give mine the benefit of seniory,And let my woes frown on the upper hand.If sorrow can admit society,Tell o'er your woes again by viewing mine:I had an Edward, till a Richard kill'd him;I had a Harry, till a Richard kill'd him:Thou hadst an Edward, till a Richard kill'd him;Thou hadst a Richard, till a Richard killed him;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: I had a Richard too, and thou didst kill him;I had a Rutland too, thou holp'st to kill him.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
dialog: Thou hadst a Clarence too, and Richard kill'd him.From forth the kennel of thy womb hath creptA hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death:That dog, that had his teeth before his eyes,To worry lambs and lap their gentle blood,That foul defacer of God's handiwork,That excellent grand tyrant of the earth,That reigns in galled eyes of weeping souls,Thy womb let loose, to chase us to our graves.O upright, just, and true-disposing God,How do I thank thee, that this carnal curPreys on the issue of his mother's body,And makes her pew-fellow with others' moan!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: O Harry's wife, triumph not in my woes!God witness with me, I have wept for thine.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
dialog: Bear with me; I am hungry for revenge,And now I cloy me with beholding it.Thy Edward he is dead, that stabb'd my Edward:Thy other Edward dead, to quit my Edward;Young York he is but boot, because both theyMatch not the high perfection of my loss:Thy Clarence he is dead that kill'd my Edward;And the beholders of this tragic play,The adulterate Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey,Untimely smother'd in their dusky graves.Richard yet lives, hell's black intelligencer,Only reserved their factor, to buy soulsAnd send them thither: but at hand, at hand,Ensues his piteous and unpitied end:Earth gapes, hell burns, fiends roar, saints pray.To have him suddenly convey'd away.Cancel his bond of life, dear God, I prey,That I may live to say, The dog is dead!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: O, thou didst prophesy the time would comeThat I should wish for thee to help me curseThat bottled spider, that foul bunch-back'd toad!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
dialog: I call'd thee then vain flourish of my fortune;I call'd thee then poor shadow, painted queen;The presentation of but what I was;The flattering index of a direful pageant;One heaved a-high, to be hurl'd down below;A mother only mock'd with two sweet babes;A dream of what thou wert, a breath, a bubble,A sign of dignity, a garish flag,To be the aim of every dangerous shot,A queen in jest, only to fill the scene.Where is thy husband now? where be thy brothers?Where are thy children? wherein dost thou, joy?Who sues to thee and cries 'God save the queen'?Where be the bending peers that flatter'd thee?Where be the thronging troops that follow'd thee?Decline all this, and see what now thou art:For happy wife, a most distressed widow;For joyful mother, one that wails the name;For queen, a very caitiff crown'd with care;For one being sued to, one that humbly sues;For one that scorn'd at me, now scorn'd of me;For one being fear'd of all, now fearing one;For one commanding all, obey'd of none.Thus hath the course of justice wheel'd about,And left thee but a very prey to time;Having no more but thought of what thou wert,To torture thee the more, being what thou art.Thou didst usurp my place, and dost thou notUsurp the just proportion of my sorrow?Now thy proud neck bears half my burthen'd yoke;From which even here I slip my weary neck,And leave the burthen of it all on thee.Farewell, York's wife, and queen of sad mischance:These English woes will make me smile in France.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: O thou well skill'd in curses, stay awhile,And teach me how to curse mine enemies!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
dialog: Forbear to sleep the nights, and fast the days;Compare dead happiness with living woe;Think that thy babes were fairer than they were,And he that slew them fouler than he is:Bettering thy loss makes the bad causer worse:Revolving this will teach thee how to curse.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: My words are dull; O, quicken them with thine!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
dialog: Thy woes will make them sharp, and pierce like mine.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: Why should calamity be full of words?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Windy attorneys to their client woes,Airy succeeders of intestate joys,Poor breathing orators of miseries!Let them have scope: though what they do impartHelp not all, yet do they ease the heart.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: If so, then be not tongue-tied: go with me.And in the breath of bitter words let's smotherMy damned son, which thy two sweet sons smother'd.I hear his drum: be copious in exclaims.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Who intercepts my expedition?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: O, she that might have intercepted thee,By strangling thee in her accursed wombFrom all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Hidest thou that forehead with a golden crown,Where should be graven, if that right were right,The slaughter of the prince that owed that crown,And the dire death of my two sons and brothers?Tell me, thou villain slave, where are my children?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: Thou toad, thou toad, where is thy brother Clarence?And little Ned Plantagenet, his son?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Where is kind Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: A flourish, trumpets! strike alarum, drums!Let not the heavens hear these tell-tale womenRail on the Lord's enointed: strike, I say!Either be patient, and entreat me fair,Or with the clamorous report of warThus will I drown your exclamations.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: Art thou my son?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Ay, I thank God, my father, and yourself.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: Then patiently hear my impatience.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Madam, I have a touch of your condition,Which cannot brook the accent of reproof.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: O, let me speak!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Do then: but I'll not hear.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: I will be mild and gentle in my speech.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: And brief, good mother; for I am in haste.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: Art thou so hasty? I have stay'd for thee,God knows, in anguish, pain and agony.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: And came I not at last to comfort you?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: No, by the holy rood, thou know'st it well,Thou camest on earth to make the earth my hell.A grievous burthen was thy birth to me;Tetchy and wayward was thy infancy;Thy school-days frightful, desperate, wild, and furious,Thy prime of manhood daring, bold, and venturous,Thy age confirm'd, proud, subdued, bloody,treacherous,More mild, but yet more harmful, kind in hatred:What comfortable hour canst thou name,That ever graced me in thy company?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Faith, none, but Humphrey Hour, that call'dyour graceTo breakfast once forth of my company.If I be so disgracious in your sight,Let me march on, and not offend your grace.Strike the drum.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: I prithee, hear me speak.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: You speak too bitterly.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: Hear me a word;For I shall never speak to thee again.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: So.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
dialog: Either thou wilt die, by God's just ordinance,Ere from this war thou turn a conqueror,Or I with grief and extreme age shall perishAnd never look upon thy face again.Therefore take with thee my most heavy curse;Which, in the day of battle, tire thee moreThan all the complete armour that thou wear'st!My prayers on the adverse party fight;And there the little souls of Edward's childrenWhisper the spirits of thine enemiesAnd promise them success and victory.Bloody thou art, bloody will be thy end;Shame serves thy life and doth thy death attend.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Though far more cause, yet much less spirit to curseAbides in me; I say amen to all.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Stay, madam; I must speak a word with you.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: I have no more sons of the royal bloodFor thee to murder: for my daughters, Richard,They shall be praying nuns, not weeping queens;And therefore level not to hit their lives.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: You have a daughter call'd Elizabeth,Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: And must she die for this? O, let her live,And I'll corrupt her manners, stain her beauty;Slander myself as false to Edward's bed;Throw over her the veil of infamy:So she may live unscarr'd of bleeding slaughter,I will confess she was not Edward's daughter.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Wrong not her birth, she is of royal blood.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: To save her life, I'll say she is not so.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Her life is only safest in her birth.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: And only in that safety died her brothers.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Lo, at their births good stars were opposite.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: No, to their lives bad friends were contrary.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: All unavoided is the doom of destiny.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: True, when avoided grace makes destiny:My babes were destined to a fairer death,If grace had bless'd thee with a fairer life.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: You speak as if that I had slain my cousins.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Cousins, indeed; and by their uncle cozen'dOf comfort, kingdom, kindred, freedom, life.Whose hand soever lanced their tender hearts,Thy head, all indirectly, gave direction:No doubt the murderous knife was dull and bluntTill it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart,To revel in the entrails of my lambs.But that still use of grief makes wild grief tame,My tongue should to thy ears not name my boysTill that my nails were anchor'd in thine eyes;And I, in such a desperate bay of death,Like a poor bark, of sails and tackling reft,Rush all to pieces on thy rocky bosom.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Madam, so thrive I in my enterpriseAnd dangerous success of bloody wars,As I intend more good to you and yours,Than ever you or yours were by me wrong'd!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: What good is cover'd with the face of heaven,To be discover'd, that can do me good?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: The advancement of your children, gentle lady.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Up to some scaffold, there to lose their heads?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: No, to the dignity and height of honourThe high imperial type of this earth's glory.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Flatter my sorrows with report of it;Tell me what state, what dignity, what honour,Canst thou demise to any child of mine?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Even all I have; yea, and myself and all,Will I withal endow a child of thine;So in the Lethe of thy angry soulThou drown the sad remembrance of those wrongsWhich thou supposest I have done to thee.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Be brief, lest that be process of thy kindnessLast longer telling than thy kindness' date.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Then know, that from my soul I love thy daughter.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: My daughter's mother thinks it with her soul.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: What do you think?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: That thou dost love my daughter from thy soul:So from thy soul's love didst thou love her brothers;And from my heart's love I do thank thee for it.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Be not so hasty to confound my meaning:I mean, that with my soul I love thy daughter,And mean to make her queen of England.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Say then, who dost thou mean shall be her king?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Even he that makes her queen who should be else?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: What, thou?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: I, even I: what think you of it, madam?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: How canst thou woo her?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: That would I learn of you,As one that are best acquainted with her humour.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: And wilt thou learn of me?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Madam, with all my heart.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Send to her, by the man that slew her brothers,A pair of bleeding-hearts; thereon engraveEdward and York; then haply she will weep:Therefore present to her--as sometime MargaretDid to thy father, steep'd in Rutland's blood,--A handkerchief; which, say to her, did drainThe purple sap from her sweet brother's bodyAnd bid her dry her weeping eyes therewith.If this inducement force her not to love,Send her a story of thy noble acts;Tell her thou madest away her uncle Clarence,Her uncle Rivers; yea, and, for her sake,Madest quick conveyance with her good aunt Anne.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Come, come, you mock me; this is not the wayTo win our daughter.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: There is no other wayUnless thou couldst put on some other shape,And not be Richard that hath done all this.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Say that I did all this for love of her.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Nay, then indeed she cannot choose but hate thee,Having bought love with such a bloody spoil.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Look, what is done cannot be now amended:Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes,Which after hours give leisure to repent.If I did take the kingdom from your sons,To make amends, Ill give it to your daughter.If I have kill'd the issue of your womb,To quicken your increase, I will begetMine issue of your blood upon your daughterA grandam's name is little less in loveThan is the doting title of a mother;They are as children but one step below,Even of your mettle, of your very blood;Of an one pain, save for a night of groansEndured of her, for whom you bid like sorrow.Your children were vexation to your youth,But mine shall be a comfort to your age.The loss you have is but a son being king,And by that loss your daughter is made queen.I cannot make you what amends I would,Therefore accept such kindness as I can.Dorset your son, that with a fearful soulLeads discontented steps in foreign soil,This fair alliance quickly shall call homeTo high promotions and great dignity:The king, that calls your beauteous daughter wife.Familiarly shall call thy Dorset brother;Again shall you be mother to a king,And all the ruins of distressful timesRepair'd with double riches of content.What! we have many goodly days to see:The liquid drops of tears that you have shedShall come again, transform'd to orient pearl,Advantaging their loan with interestOf ten times double gain of happiness.Go, then my mother, to thy daughter goMake bold her bashful years with your experience;Prepare her ears to hear a wooer's talePut in her tender heart the aspiring flameOf golden sovereignty; acquaint the princessWith the sweet silent hours of marriage joysAnd when this arm of mine hath chastisedThe petty rebel, dull-brain'd Buckingham,Bound with triumphant garlands will I comeAnd lead thy daughter to a conqueror's bed;To whom I will retail my conquest won,And she shall be sole victress, Caesar's Caesar.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: What were I best to say? her father's brotherWould be her lord? or shall I say, her uncle?Or, he that slew her brothers and her uncles?Under what title shall I woo for thee,That God, the law, my honour and her love,Can make seem pleasing to her tender years?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Infer fair England's peace by this alliance.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Which she shall purchase with still lasting war.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Say that the king, which may command, entreats.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: That at her hands which the king's King forbids.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Say, she shall be a high and mighty queen.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: To wail the tide, as her mother doth.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Say, I will love her everlastingly.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: But how long shall that title 'ever' last?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Sweetly in force unto her fair life's end.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: But how long fairly shall her sweet lie last?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: So long as heaven and nature lengthens it.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: So long as hell and Richard likes of it.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Say, I, her sovereign, am her subject love.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: But she, your subject, loathes such sovereignty.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Be eloquent in my behalf to her.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: An honest tale speeds best being plainly told.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Then in plain terms tell her my loving tale.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Plain and not honest is too harsh a style.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: O no, my reasons are too deep and dead;Too deep and dead, poor infants, in their grave.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Harp not on that string, madam; that is past.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Harp on it still shall I till heart-strings break.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Now, by my George, my garter, and my crown,--

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Profaned, dishonour'd, and the third usurp'd.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: I swear--

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: By nothing; for this is no oath:The George, profaned, hath lost his holy honour;The garter, blemish'd, pawn'd his knightly virtue;The crown, usurp'd, disgraced his kingly glory.if something thou wilt swear to be believed,Swear then by something that thou hast not wrong'd.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Now, by the world--

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: 'Tis full of thy foul wrongs.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: My father's death--

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Thy life hath that dishonour'd.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Then, by myself--

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Thyself thyself misusest.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Why then, by God--

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: God's wrong is most of all.If thou hadst fear'd to break an oath by Him,The unity the king thy brother madeHad not been broken, nor my brother slain:If thou hadst fear'd to break an oath by Him,The imperial metal, circling now thy brow,Had graced the tender temples of my child,And both the princes had been breathing here,Which now, two tender playfellows to dust,Thy broken faith hath made a prey for worms.What canst thou swear by now?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: The time to come.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: That thou hast wronged in the time o'erpast;For I myself have many tears to washHereafter time, for time past wrong'd by thee.The children live, whose parents thou hastslaughter'd,Ungovern'd youth, to wail it in their age;The parents live, whose children thou hast butcher'd,Old wither'd plants, to wail it with their age.Swear not by time to come; for that thou hastMisused ere used, by time misused o'erpast.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: As I intend to prosper and repent,So thrive I in my dangerous attemptOf hostile arms! myself myself confound!Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours!Day, yield me not thy light; nor, night, thy rest!Be opposite all planets of good luckTo my proceedings, if, with pure heart's love,Immaculate devotion, holy thoughts,I tender not thy beauteous princely daughter!In her consists my happiness and thine;Without her, follows to this land and me,To thee, herself, and many a Christian soul,Death, desolation, ruin and decay:It cannot be avoided but by this;It will not be avoided but by this.Therefore, good mother,--I must can you so--Be the attorney of my love to her:Plead what I will be, not what I have been;Not my deserts, but what I will deserve:Urge the necessity and state of times,And be not peevish-fond in great designs.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Shall I be tempted of the devil thus?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Ay, if the devil tempt thee to do good.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Shall I forget myself to be myself?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: Ay, if yourself's remembrance wrong yourself.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: But thou didst kill my children.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: But in your daughter's womb I bury them:Where in that nest of spicery they shall breedSelves of themselves, to your recomforture.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
dialog: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
dialog: And be a happy mother by the deed.
