dialog: Go, Cleomenes;Yourself, assisted with your honour'd friends,Bring them to our embracement. Still, 'tis strangeHe thus should steal upon us.

speaker: PAULINA
dialog: Had our prince,Jewel of children, seen this hour, he had pair'dWell with this lord: there was not full a monthBetween their births.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: Prithee, no more; cease; thou know'stHe dies to me again when talk'd of: sure,When I shall see this gentleman, thy speechesWill bring me to consider that which mayUnfurnish me of reason. They are come.Your mother was most true to wedlock, prince;For she did print your royal father off,Conceiving you: were I but twenty-one,Your father's image is so hit in you,His very air, that I should call you brother,As I did him, and speak of something wildlyBy us perform'd before. Most dearly welcome!And your fair princess,--goddess!--O, alas!I lost a couple, that 'twixt heaven and earthMight thus have stood begetting wonder asYou, gracious couple, do: and then I lost--All mine own folly--the society,Amity too, of your brave father, whom,Though bearing misery, I desire my lifeOnce more to look on him.

speaker: FLORIZEL
dialog: By his commandHave I here touch'd Sicilia and from himGive you all greetings that a king, at friend,Can send his brother: and, but infirmityWhich waits upon worn times hath something seizedHis wish'd ability, he had himselfThe lands and waters 'twixt your throne and hisMeasured to look upon you; whom he loves--He bade me say so--more than all the sceptresAnd those that bear them living.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: O my brother,Good gentleman! the wrongs I have done thee stirAfresh within me, and these thy offices,So rarely kind, are as interpretersOf my behind-hand slackness. Welcome hither,As is the spring to the earth. And hath he tooExposed this paragon to the fearful usage,At least ungentle, of the dreadful Neptune,To greet a man not worth her pains, much lessThe adventure of her person?

speaker: FLORIZEL
dialog: Good my lord,She came from Libya.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: Where the warlike Smalus,That noble honour'd lord, is fear'd and loved?

speaker: FLORIZEL
dialog: Most royal sir, from thence; from him, whose daughterHis tears proclaim'd his, parting with her: thence,A prosperous south-wind friendly, we have cross'd,To execute the charge my father gave meFor visiting your highness: my best trainI have from your Sicilian shores dismiss'd;Who for Bohemia bend, to signifyNot only my success in Libya, sir,But my arrival and my wife's in safetyHere where we are.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: The blessed godsPurge all infection from our air whilst youDo climate here! You have a holy father,A graceful gentleman; against whose person,So sacred as it is, I have done sin:For which the heavens, taking angry note,Have left me issueless; and your father's blest,As he from heaven merits it, with youWorthy his goodness. What might I have been,Might I a son and daughter now have look'd on,Such goodly things as you!

speaker: Lord
dialog: Most noble sir,That which I shall report will bear no credit,Were not the proof so nigh. Please you, great sir,Bohemia greets you from himself by me;Desires you to attach his son, who has--His dignity and duty both cast off--Fled from his father, from his hopes, and withA shepherd's daughter.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: Where's Bohemia? speak.

speaker: Lord
dialog: Here in your city; I now came from him:I speak amazedly; and it becomesMy marvel and my message. To your courtWhiles he was hastening, in the chase, it seems,Of this fair couple, meets he on the wayThe father of this seeming lady andHer brother, having both their country quittedWith this young prince.

speaker: FLORIZEL
dialog: Camillo has betray'd me;Whose honour and whose honesty till nowEndured all weathers.

speaker: Lord
dialog: Lay't so to his charge:He's with the king your father.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: Who? Camillo?

speaker: Lord
dialog: Camillo, sir; I spake with him; who nowHas these poor men in question. Never saw IWretches so quake: they kneel, they kiss the earth;Forswear themselves as often as they speak:Bohemia stops his ears, and threatens themWith divers deaths in death.

speaker: PERDITA
dialog: O my poor father!The heaven sets spies upon us, will not haveOur contract celebrated.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: You are married?

speaker: FLORIZEL
dialog: We are not, sir, nor are we like to be;The stars, I see, will kiss the valleys first:The odds for high and low's alike.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: My lord,Is this the daughter of a king?

speaker: FLORIZEL
dialog: She is,When once she is my wife.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: That 'once' I see by your good father's speedWill come on very slowly. I am sorry,Most sorry, you have broken from his likingWhere you were tied in duty, and as sorryYour choice is not so rich in worth as beauty,That you might well enjoy her.

speaker: FLORIZEL
dialog: Dear, look up:Though Fortune, visible an enemy,Should chase us with my father, power no jotHath she to change our loves. Beseech you, sir,Remember since you owed no more to timeThan I do now: with thought of such affections,Step forth mine advocate; at your requestMy father will grant precious things as trifles.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: Would he do so, I'ld beg your precious mistress,Which he counts but a trifle.

speaker: PAULINA
dialog: Sir, my liege,Your eye hath too much youth in't: not a month'Fore your queen died, she was more worth such gazesThan what you look on now.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: I thought of her,Even in these looks I made.But your petitionIs yet unanswer'd. I will to your father:Your honour not o'erthrown by your desires,I am friend to them and you: upon which errandI now go toward him; therefore follow meAnd mark what way I make: come, good my lord.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
dialog: Beseech you, sir, were you present at this relation?

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: I was by at the opening of the fardel, heard the oldshepherd deliver the manner how he found it:whereupon, after a little amazedness, we were allcommanded out of the chamber; only this methought Iheard the shepherd say, he found the child.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
dialog: I would most gladly know the issue of it.

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: I make a broken delivery of the business; but thechanges I perceived in the king and Camillo werevery notes of admiration: they seemed almost, withstaring on one another, to tear the cases of theireyes; there was speech in their dumbness, languagein their very gesture; they looked as they had heardof a world ransomed, or one destroyed: a notablepassion of wonder appeared in them; but the wisestbeholder, that knew no more but seeing, could notsay if the importance were joy or sorrow; but in theextremity of the one, it must needs be.Here comes a gentleman that haply knows more.The news, Rogero?

speaker: Second Gentleman
dialog: Nothing but bonfires: the oracle is fulfilled; theking's daughter is found: such a deal of wonder isbroken out within this hour that ballad-makerscannot be able to express it.Here comes the Lady Paulina's steward: he candeliver you more. How goes it now, sir? this newswhich is called true is so like an old tale, thatthe verity of it is in strong suspicion: has the kingfound his heir?

speaker: Third Gentleman
dialog: Most true, if ever truth were pregnant bycircumstance: that which you hear you'll swear yousee, there is such unity in the proofs. The mantleof Queen Hermione's, her jewel about the neck of it,the letters of Antigonus found with it which theyknow to be his character, the majesty of thecreature in resemblance of the mother, the affectionof nobleness which nature shows above her breeding,and many other evidences proclaim her with allcertainty to be the king's daughter. Did you seethe meeting of the two kings?

speaker: Second Gentleman
dialog: No.

speaker: Third Gentleman
dialog: Then have you lost a sight, which was to be seen,cannot be spoken of. There might you have beheld onejoy crown another, so and in such manner that itseemed sorrow wept to take leave of them, for theirjoy waded in tears. There was casting up of eyes,holding up of hands, with countenances of suchdistraction that they were to be known by garment,not by favour. Our king, being ready to leap out ofhimself for joy of his found daughter, as if thatjoy were now become a loss, cries 'O, thy mother,thy mother!' then asks Bohemia forgiveness; thenembraces his son-in-law; then again worries he hisdaughter with clipping her; now he thanks the oldshepherd, which stands by like a weather-bittenconduit of many kings' reigns. I never heard of suchanother encounter, which lames report to follow itand undoes description to do it.

speaker: Second Gentleman
dialog: What, pray you, became of Antigonus, that carriedhence the child?

speaker: Third Gentleman
dialog: Like an old tale still, which will have matter torehearse, though credit be asleep and not an earopen. He was torn to pieces with a bear: thisavouches the shepherd's son; who has not only hisinnocence, which seems much, to justify him, but ahandkerchief and rings of his that Paulina knows.

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: What became of his bark and his followers?

speaker: Third Gentleman
dialog: Wrecked the same instant of their master's death andin the view of the shepherd: so that all theinstruments which aided to expose the child wereeven then lost when it was found. But O, the noblecombat that 'twixt joy and sorrow was fought inPaulina! She had one eye declined for the loss ofher husband, another elevated that the oracle wasfulfilled: she lifted the princess from the earth,and so locks her in embracing, as if she would pinher to her heart that she might no more be in dangerof losing.

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: The dignity of this act was worth the audience ofkings and princes; for by such was it acted.

speaker: Third Gentleman
dialog: One of the prettiest touches of all and that whichangled for mine eyes, caught the water though notthe fish, was when, at the relation of the queen'sdeath, with the manner how she came to't bravelyconfessed and lamented by the king, howattentiveness wounded his daughter; till, from onesign of dolour to another, she did, with an 'Alas,'I would fain say, bleed tears, for I am sure myheart wept blood. Who was most marble there changedcolour; some swooned, all sorrowed: if all the worldcould have seen 't, the woe had been universal.

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: Are they returned to the court?

speaker: Third Gentleman
dialog: No: the princess hearing of her mother's statue,which is in the keeping of Paulina,--a piece manyyears in doing and now newly performed by that rareItalian master, Julio Romano, who, had he himselfeternity and could put breath into his work, wouldbeguile Nature of her custom, so perfectly he is herape: he so near to Hermione hath done Hermione thatthey say one would speak to her and stand in hope ofanswer: thither with all greediness of affectionare they gone, and there they intend to sup.

speaker: Second Gentleman
dialog: I thought she had some great matter there in hand;for she hath privately twice or thrice a day, eversince the death of Hermione, visited that removedhouse. Shall we thither and with our company piecethe rejoicing?

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: Who would be thence that has the benefit of access?every wink of an eye some new grace will be born:our absence makes us unthrifty to our knowledge.Let's along.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
dialog: Now, had I not the dash of my former life in me,would preferment drop on my head. I brought the oldman and his son aboard the prince: told him I heardthem talk of a fardel and I know not what: but heat that time, overfond of the shepherd's daughter,so he then took her to be, who began to be muchsea-sick, and himself little better, extremity ofweather continuing, this mystery remainedundiscovered. But 'tis all one to me; for had Ibeen the finder out of this secret, it would nothave relished among my other discredits.Here come those I have done good to against my will,and already appearing in the blossoms of their fortune.

speaker: Shepherd
dialog: Come, boy; I am past moe children, but thy sons anddaughters will be all gentlemen born.

speaker: Clown
dialog: You are well met, sir. You denied to fight with methis other day, because I was no gentleman born.See you these clothes? say you see them not andthink me still no gentleman born: you were best saythese robes are not gentlemen born: give me thelie, do, and try whether I am not now a gentleman born.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
dialog: I know you are now, sir, a gentleman born.

speaker: Clown
dialog: Ay, and have been so any time these four hours.

speaker: Shepherd
dialog: And so have I, boy.

speaker: Clown
dialog: So you have: but I was a gentleman born before myfather; for the king's son took me by the hand, andcalled me brother; and then the two kings called myfather brother; and then the prince my brother andthe princess my sister called my father father; andso we wept, and there was the first gentleman-liketears that ever we shed.

speaker: Shepherd
dialog: We may live, son, to shed many more.

speaker: Clown
dialog: Ay; or else 'twere hard luck, being in sopreposterous estate as we are.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
dialog: I humbly beseech you, sir, to pardon me all thefaults I have committed to your worship and to giveme your good report to the prince my master.

speaker: Shepherd
dialog: Prithee, son, do; for we must be gentle, now we aregentlemen.

speaker: Clown
dialog: Thou wilt amend thy life?

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
dialog: Ay, an it like your good worship.

speaker: Clown
dialog: Give me thy hand: I will swear to the prince thouart as honest a true fellow as any is in Bohemia.

speaker: Shepherd
dialog: You may say it, but not swear it.

speaker: Clown
dialog: Not swear it, now I am a gentleman? Let boors andfranklins say it, I'll swear it.

speaker: Shepherd
dialog: How if it be false, son?

speaker: Clown
dialog: If it be ne'er so false, a true gentleman may swearit in the behalf of his friend: and I'll swear tothe prince thou art a tall fellow of thy hands andthat thou wilt not be drunk; but I know thou art notall fellow of thy hands and that thou wilt bedrunk: but I'll swear it, and I would thou wouldstbe a tall fellow of thy hands.

speaker: AUTOLYCUS
dialog: I will prove so, sir, to my power.

speaker: Clown
dialog: Ay, by any means prove a tall fellow: if I do notwonder how thou darest venture to be drunk, notbeing a tall fellow, trust me not. Hark! the kingsand the princes, our kindred, are going to see thequeen's picture. Come, follow us: we'll be thygood masters.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: O grave and good Paulina, the great comfortThat I have had of thee!

speaker: PAULINA
dialog: What, sovereign sir,I did not well I meant well. All my servicesYou have paid home: but that you have vouchsafed,With your crown'd brother and these your contractedHeirs of your kingdoms, my poor house to visit,It is a surplus of your grace, which neverMy life may last to answer.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: O Paulina,We honour you with trouble: but we cameTo see the statue of our queen: your galleryHave we pass'd through, not without much contentIn many singularities; but we saw notThat which my daughter came to look upon,The statue of her mother.

speaker: PAULINA
dialog: As she lived peerless,So her dead likeness, I do well believe,Excels whatever yet you look'd uponOr hand of man hath done; therefore I keep itLonely, apart. But here it is: prepareTo see the life as lively mock'd as everStill sleep mock'd death: behold, and say 'tis well.I like your silence, it the more shows offYour wonder: but yet speak; first, you, my liege,Comes it not something near?

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: Her natural posture!Chide me, dear stone, that I may say indeedThou art Hermione; or rather, thou art sheIn thy not chiding, for she was as tenderAs infancy and grace. But yet, Paulina,Hermione was not so much wrinkled, nothingSo aged as this seems.

speaker: POLIXENES
dialog: O, not by much.

speaker: PAULINA
dialog: So much the more our carver's excellence;Which lets go by some sixteen years and makes herAs she lived now.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: As now she might have done,So much to my good comfort, as it isNow piercing to my soul. O, thus she stood,Even with such life of majesty, warm life,As now it coldly stands, when first I woo'd her!I am ashamed: does not the stone rebuke meFor being more stone than it? O royal piece,There's magic in thy majesty, which hasMy evils conjured to remembrance andFrom thy admiring daughter took the spirits,Standing like stone with thee.

speaker: PERDITA
dialog: And give me leave,And do not say 'tis superstition, thatI kneel and then implore her blessing. Lady,Dear queen, that ended when I but began,Give me that hand of yours to kiss.

speaker: PAULINA
dialog: O, patience!The statue is but newly fix'd, the colour's Not dry.

speaker: CAMILLO
dialog: My lord, your sorrow was too sore laid on,Which sixteen winters cannot blow away,So many summers dry; scarce any joyDid ever so long live; no sorrowBut kill'd itself much sooner.

speaker: POLIXENES
dialog: Dear my brother,Let him that was the cause of this have powerTo take off so much grief from you as heWill piece up in himself.

speaker: PAULINA
dialog: Indeed, my lord,If I had thought the sight of my poor imageWould thus have wrought you,--for the stone is mine--I'ld not have show'd it.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: Do not draw the curtain.

speaker: PAULINA
dialog: No longer shall you gaze on't, lest your fancyMay think anon it moves.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: Let be, let be.Would I were dead, but that, methinks, already--What was he that did make it? See, my lord,Would you not deem it breathed? and that those veinsDid verily bear blood?

speaker: POLIXENES
dialog: Masterly done:The very life seems warm upon her lip.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: The fixture of her eye has motion in't,As we are mock'd with art.

speaker: PAULINA
dialog: I'll draw the curtain:My lord's almost so far transported thatHe'll think anon it lives.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: O sweet Paulina,Make me to think so twenty years together!No settled senses of the world can matchThe pleasure of that madness. Let 't alone.

speaker: PAULINA
dialog: I am sorry, sir, I have thus far stirr'd you: butI could afflict you farther.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: Do, Paulina;For this affliction has a taste as sweetAs any cordial comfort. Still, methinks,There is an air comes from her: what fine chiselCould ever yet cut breath? Let no man mock me,For I will kiss her.

speaker: PAULINA
dialog: Good my lord, forbear:The ruddiness upon her lip is wet;You'll mar it if you kiss it, stain your ownWith oily painting. Shall I draw the curtain?

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: No, not these twenty years.

speaker: PERDITA
dialog: So long could IStand by, a looker on.

speaker: PAULINA
dialog: Either forbear,Quit presently the chapel, or resolve youFor more amazement. If you can behold it,I'll make the statue move indeed, descendAnd take you by the hand; but then you'll think--Which I protest against--I am assistedBy wicked powers.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: What you can make her do,I am content to look on: what to speak,I am content to hear; for 'tis as easyTo make her speak as move.

speaker: PAULINA
dialog: It is requiredYou do awake your faith. Then all stand still;On: those that think it is unlawful businessI am about, let them depart.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: Proceed:No foot shall stir.

speaker: PAULINA
dialog: Music, awake her; strike!'Tis time; descend; be stone no more; approach;Strike all that look upon with marvel. Come,I'll fill your grave up: stir, nay, come away,Bequeath to death your numbness, for from himDear life redeems you. You perceive she stirs:Start not; her actions shall be holy asYou hear my spell is lawful: do not shun herUntil you see her die again; for thenYou kill her double. Nay, present your hand:When she was young you woo'd her; now in ageIs she become the suitor?

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: O, she's warm!If this be magic, let it be an artLawful as eating.

speaker: POLIXENES
dialog: She embraces him.

speaker: CAMILLO
dialog: She hangs about his neck:If she pertain to life let her speak too.

speaker: POLIXENES
dialog: Ay, and make't manifest where she has lived,Or how stolen from the dead.

speaker: PAULINA
dialog: That she is living,Were it but told you, should be hooted atLike an old tale: but it appears she lives,Though yet she speak not. Mark a little while.Please you to interpose, fair madam: kneelAnd pray your mother's blessing. Turn, good lady;Our Perdita is found.

speaker: HERMIONE
dialog: You gods, look downAnd from your sacred vials pour your gracesUpon my daughter's head! Tell me, mine own.Where hast thou been preserved? where lived? how foundThy father's court? for thou shalt hear that I,Knowing by Paulina that the oracleGave hope thou wast in being, have preservedMyself to see the issue.

speaker: PAULINA
dialog: There's time enough for that;Lest they desire upon this push to troubleYour joys with like relation. Go together,You precious winners all; your exultationPartake to every one. I, an old turtle,Will wing me to some wither'd bough and thereMy mate, that's never to be found again,Lament till I am lost.

speaker: LEONTES
dialog: O, peace, Paulina!Thou shouldst a husband take by my consent,As I by thine a wife: this is a match,And made between's by vows. Thou hast found mine;But how, is to be question'd; for I saw her,As I thought, dead, and have in vain said manyA prayer upon her grave. I'll not seek far--For him, I partly know his mind--to find theeAn honourable husband. Come, Camillo,And take her by the hand, whose worth and honestyIs richly noted and here justifiedBy us, a pair of kings. Let's from this place.What! look upon my brother: both your pardons,That e'er I put between your holy looksMy ill suspicion. This is your son-in-law,And son unto the king, who, heavens directing,Is troth-plight to your daughter. Good Paulina,Lead us from hence, where we may leisurelyEach one demand an answer to his partPerform'd in this wide gap of time since firstWe were dissever'd: hastily lead away.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Escalus.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: My lord.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Of government the properties to unfold,Would seem in me to affect speech and discourse;Since I am put to know that your own scienceExceeds, in that, the lists of all adviceMy strength can give you: then no more remains,But that to your sufficiency, as your Worth is able,And let them work. The nature of our people,Our city's institutions, and the termsFor common justice, you're as pregnant inAs art and practise hath enriched anyThat we remember. There is our commission,From which we would not have you warp. Call hither,I say, bid come before us Angelo.What figure of us think you he will bear?For you must know, we have with special soulElected him our absence to supply,Lent him our terror, dress'd him with our love,And given his deputation all the organsOf our own power: what think you of it?

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: If any in Vienna be of worthTo undergo such ample grace and honour,It is Lord Angelo.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Look where he comes.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Always obedient to your grace's will,I come to know your pleasure.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Angelo,There is a kind of character in thy life,That to the observer doth thy historyFully unfold. Thyself and thy belongingsAre not thine own so proper as to wasteThyself upon thy virtues, they on thee.Heaven doth with us as we with torches do,Not light them for themselves; for if our virtuesDid not go forth of us, 'twere all alikeAs if we had them not. Spirits are not finely touch'dBut to fine issues, nor Nature never lendsThe smallest scruple of her excellenceBut, like a thrifty goddess, she determinesHerself the glory of a creditor,Both thanks and use. But I do bend my speechTo one that can my part in him advertise;Hold therefore, Angelo:--In our remove be thou at full ourself;Mortality and mercy in ViennaLive in thy tongue and heart: old Escalus,Though first in question, is thy secondary.Take thy commission.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Now, good my lord,Let there be some more test made of my metal,Before so noble and so great a figureBe stamp'd upon it.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: No more evasion:We have with a leaven'd and prepared choiceProceeded to you; therefore take your honours.Our haste from hence is of so quick conditionThat it prefers itself and leaves unquestion'dMatters of needful value. We shall write to you,As time and our concernings shall importune,How it goes with us, and do look to knowWhat doth befall you here. So, fare you well;To the hopeful execution do I leave youOf your commissions.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Yet give leave, my lord,That we may bring you something on the way.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: My haste may not admit it;Nor need you, on mine honour, have to doWith any scruple; your scope is as mine ownSo to enforce or qualify the lawsAs to your soul seems good. Give me your hand:I'll privily away. I love the people,But do not like to stage me to their eyes:Through it do well, I do not relish wellTheir loud applause and Aves vehement;Nor do I think the man of safe discretionThat does affect it. Once more, fare you well.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: The heavens give safety to your purposes!

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Lead forth and bring you back in happiness!

speaker: DUKE
dialog: I thank you. Fare you well.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: I shall desire you, sir, to give me leaveTo have free speech with you; and it concerns meTo look into the bottom of my place:A power I have, but of what strength and natureI am not yet instructed.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: 'Tis so with me. Let us withdraw together,And we may soon our satisfaction haveTouching that point.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: I'll wait upon your honour.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: If the duke with the other dukes come not tocomposition with the King of Hungary, why then allthe dukes fall upon the king.

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: Heaven grant us its peace, but not the King ofHungary's!

speaker: Second Gentleman
dialog: Amen.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Thou concludest like the sanctimonious pirate, thatwent to sea with the Ten Commandments, but scrapedone out of the table.

speaker: Second Gentleman
dialog: 'Thou shalt not steal'?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Ay, that he razed.

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: Why, 'twas a commandment to command the captain andall the rest from their functions: they put forthto steal. There's not a soldier of us all, that, inthe thanksgiving before meat, do relish the petitionwell that prays for peace.

speaker: Second Gentleman
dialog: I never heard any soldier dislike it.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: I believe thee; for I think thou never wast wheregrace was said.

speaker: Second Gentleman
dialog: No? a dozen times at least.

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: What, in metre?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: In any proportion or in any language.

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: I think, or in any religion.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Ay, why not? Grace is grace, despite of allcontroversy: as, for example, thou thyself art awicked villain, despite of all grace.

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: Well, there went but a pair of shears between us.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: I grant; as there may between the lists and thevelvet. Thou art the list.

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: And thou the velvet: thou art good velvet; thou'rta three-piled piece, I warrant thee: I had as liefbe a list of an English kersey as be piled, as thouart piled, for a French velvet. Do I speakfeelingly now?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: I think thou dost; and, indeed, with most painfulfeeling of thy speech: I will, out of thine ownconfession, learn to begin thy health; but, whilst Ilive, forget to drink after thee.

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: I think I have done myself wrong, have I not?

speaker: Second Gentleman
dialog: Yes, that thou hast, whether thou art tainted or free.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Behold, behold. where Madam Mitigation comes! Ihave purchased as many diseases under her roof as come to--

speaker: Second Gentleman
dialog: To what, I pray?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Judge.

speaker: Second Gentleman
dialog: To three thousand dolours a year.

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: Ay, and more.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: A French crown more.

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: Thou art always figuring diseases in me; but thouart full of error; I am sound.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Nay, not as one would say, healthy; but so sound asthings that are hollow: thy bones are hollow;impiety has made a feast of thee.

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: How now! which of your hips has the most profound sciatica?

speaker: MISTRESS OVERDONE
dialog: Well, well; there's one yonder arrested and carriedto prison was worth five thousand of you all.

speaker: Second Gentleman
dialog: Who's that, I pray thee?

speaker: MISTRESS OVERDONE
dialog: Marry, sir, that's Claudio, Signior Claudio.

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: Claudio to prison? 'tis not so.

speaker: MISTRESS OVERDONE
dialog: Nay, but I know 'tis so: I saw him arrested, sawhim carried away; and, which is more, within thesethree days his head to be chopped off.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: But, after all this fooling, I would not have it so.Art thou sure of this?

speaker: MISTRESS OVERDONE
dialog: I am too sure of it: and it is for getting MadamJulietta with child.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Believe me, this may be: he promised to meet me twohours since, and he was ever precise inpromise-keeping.

speaker: Second Gentleman
dialog: Besides, you know, it draws something near to thespeech we had to such a purpose.

speaker: First Gentleman
dialog: But, most of all, agreeing with the proclamation.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Away! let's go learn the truth of it.

speaker: MISTRESS OVERDONE
dialog: Thus, what with the war, what with the sweat, whatwith the gallows and what with poverty, I amcustom-shrunk.How now! what's the news with you?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Yonder man is carried to prison.

speaker: MISTRESS OVERDONE
dialog: Well; what has he done?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: A woman.

speaker: MISTRESS OVERDONE
dialog: But what's his offence?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Groping for trouts in a peculiar river.

speaker: MISTRESS OVERDONE
dialog: What, is there a maid with child by him?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: No, but there's a woman with maid by him. You havenot heard of the proclamation, have you?

speaker: MISTRESS OVERDONE
dialog: What proclamation, man?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: All houses in the suburbs of Vienna must be plucked down.

speaker: MISTRESS OVERDONE
dialog: And what shall become of those in the city?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: They shall stand for seed: they had gone down too,but that a wise burgher put in for them.

speaker: MISTRESS OVERDONE
dialog: But shall all our houses of resort in the suburbs bepulled down?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: To the ground, mistress.

speaker: MISTRESS OVERDONE
dialog: Why, here's a change indeed in the commonwealth!What shall become of me?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Come; fear you not: good counsellors lack noclients: though you change your place, you need notchange your trade; I'll be your tapster still.Courage! there will be pity taken on you: you thathave worn your eyes almost out in the service, youwill be considered.

speaker: MISTRESS OVERDONE
dialog: What's to do here, Thomas tapster? let's withdraw.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Here comes Signior Claudio, led by the provost toprison; and there's Madam Juliet.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Fellow, why dost thou show me thus to the world?Bear me to prison, where I am committed.

speaker: Provost
dialog: I do it not in evil disposition,But from Lord Angelo by special charge.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Thus can the demigod AuthorityMake us pay down for our offence by weightThe words of heaven; on whom it will, it will;On whom it will not, so; yet still 'tis just.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Why, how now, Claudio! whence comes this restraint?

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: From too much liberty, my Lucio, liberty:As surfeit is the father of much fast,So every scope by the immoderate useTurns to restraint. Our natures do pursue,Like rats that ravin down their proper bane,A thirsty evil; and when we drink we die.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: If could speak so wisely under an arrest, I wouldsend for certain of my creditors: and yet, to saythe truth, I had as lief have the foppery of freedomas the morality of imprisonment. What's thyoffence, Claudio?

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: What but to speak of would offend again.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: What, is't murder?

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: No.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Lechery?

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Call it so.

speaker: Provost
dialog: Away, sir! you must go.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: One word, good friend. Lucio, a word with you.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: A hundred, if they'll do you any good.Is lechery so look'd after?

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Thus stands it with me: upon a true contractI got possession of Julietta's bed:You know the lady; she is fast my wife,Save that we do the denunciation lackOf outward order: this we came not to,Only for propagation of a dowerRemaining in the coffer of her friends,From whom we thought it meet to hide our loveTill time had made them for us. But it chancesThe stealth of our most mutual entertainmentWith character too gross is writ on Juliet.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: With child, perhaps?

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Unhappily, even so.And the new deputy now for the duke--Whether it be the fault and glimpse of newness,Or whether that the body public beA horse whereon the governor doth ride,Who, newly in the seat, that it may knowHe can command, lets it straight feel the spur;Whether the tyranny be in his place,Or in his emmence that fills it up,I stagger in:--but this new governorAwakes me all the enrolled penaltiesWhich have, like unscour'd armour, hung by the wallSo long that nineteen zodiacs have gone roundAnd none of them been worn; and, for a name,Now puts the drowsy and neglected actFreshly on me: 'tis surely for a name.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: I warrant it is: and thy head stands so tickle onthy shoulders that a milkmaid, if she be in love,may sigh it off. Send after the duke and appeal tohim.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: I have done so, but he's not to be found.I prithee, Lucio, do me this kind service:This day my sister should the cloister enterAnd there receive her approbation:Acquaint her with the danger of my state:Implore her, in my voice, that she make friendsTo the strict deputy; bid herself assay him:I have great hope in that; for in her youthThere is a prone and speechless dialect,Such as move men; beside, she hath prosperous artWhen she will play with reason and discourse,And well she can persuade.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: I pray she may; as well for the encouragement of thelike, which else would stand under grievousimposition, as for the enjoying of thy life, who Iwould be sorry should be thus foolishly lost at agame of tick-tack. I'll to her.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: I thank you, good friend Lucio.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Within two hours.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Come, officer, away!

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: No, holy father; throw away that thought;Believe not that the dribbling dart of loveCan pierce a complete bosom. Why I desire theeTo give me secret harbour, hath a purposeMore grave and wrinkled than the aims and endsOf burning youth.

speaker: FRIAR THOMAS
dialog: May your grace speak of it?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: My holy sir, none better knows than youHow I have ever loved the life removedAnd held in idle price to haunt assembliesWhere youth, and cost, and witless bravery keeps.I have deliver'd to Lord Angelo,A man of stricture and firm abstinence,My absolute power and place here in Vienna,And he supposes me travell'd to Poland;For so I have strew'd it in the common ear,And so it is received. Now, pious sir,You will demand of me why I do this?

speaker: FRIAR THOMAS
dialog: Gladly, my lord.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: We have strict statutes and most biting laws.The needful bits and curbs to headstrong weeds,Which for this nineteen years we have let slip;Even like an o'ergrown lion in a cave,That goes not out to prey. Now, as fond fathers,Having bound up the threatening twigs of birch,Only to stick it in their children's sightFor terror, not to use, in time the rodBecomes more mock'd than fear'd; so our decrees,Dead to infliction, to themselves are dead;And liberty plucks justice by the nose;The baby beats the nurse, and quite athwartGoes all decorum.

speaker: FRIAR THOMAS
dialog: It rested in your graceTo unloose this tied-up justice when you pleased:And it in you more dreadful would have seem'dThan in Lord Angelo.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: I do fear, too dreadful:Sith 'twas my fault to give the people scope,'Twould be my tyranny to strike and gall themFor what I bid them do: for we bid this be done,When evil deeds have their permissive passAnd not the punishment. Therefore indeed, my father,I have on Angelo imposed the office;Who may, in the ambush of my name, strike home,And yet my nature never in the fightTo do in slander. And to behold his sway,I will, as 'twere a brother of your order,Visit both prince and people: therefore, I prithee,Supply me with the habit and instruct meHow I may formally in person bear meLike a true friar. More reasons for this actionAt our more leisure shall I render you;Only, this one: Lord Angelo is precise;Stands at a guard with envy; scarce confessesThat his blood flows, or that his appetiteIs more to bread than stone: hence shall we see,If power change purpose, what our seemers be.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: And have you nuns no farther privileges?

speaker: FRANCISCA
dialog: Are not these large enough?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Yes, truly; I speak not as desiring more;But rather wishing a more strict restraintUpon the sisterhood, the votarists of Saint Clare.

speaker: FRANCISCA
dialog: It is a man's voice. Gentle Isabella,Turn you the key, and know his business of him;You may, I may not; you are yet unsworn.When you have vow'd, you must not speak with menBut in the presence of the prioress:Then, if you speak, you must not show your face,Or, if you show your face, you must not speak.He calls again; I pray you, answer him.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Peace and prosperity! Who is't that calls

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Hail, virgin, if you be, as those cheek-rosesProclaim you are no less! Can you so stead meAs bring me to the sight of Isabella,A novice of this place and the fair sisterTo her unhappy brother Claudio?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Why 'her unhappy brother'? let me ask,The rather for I now must make you knowI am that Isabella and his sister.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Gentle and fair, your brother kindly greets you:Not to be weary with you, he's in prison.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Woe me! for what?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: For that which, if myself might be his judge,He should receive his punishment in thanks:He hath got his friend with child.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Sir, make me not your story.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: It is true.I would not--though 'tis my familiar sinWith maids to seem the lapwing and to jest,Tongue far from heart--play with all virgins so:I hold you as a thing ensky'd and sainted.By your renouncement an immortal spirit,And to be talk'd with in sincerity,As with a saint.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: You do blaspheme the good in mocking me.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Do not believe it. Fewness and truth, 'tis thus:Your brother and his lover have embraced:As those that feed grow full, as blossoming timeThat from the seedness the bare fallow bringsTo teeming foison, even so her plenteous wombExpresseth his full tilth and husbandry.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Some one with child by him? My cousin Juliet?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Is she your cousin?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Adoptedly; as school-maids change their namesBy vain though apt affection.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: She it is.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: O, let him marry her.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: This is the point.The duke is very strangely gone from hence;Bore many gentlemen, myself being one,In hand and hope of action: but we do learnBy those that know the very nerves of state,His givings-out were of an infinite distanceFrom his true-meant design. Upon his place,And with full line of his authority,Governs Lord Angelo; a man whose bloodIs very snow-broth; one who never feelsThe wanton stings and motions of the sense,But doth rebate and blunt his natural edgeWith profits of the mind, study and fast.He--to give fear to use and liberty,Which have for long run by the hideous law,As mice by lions--hath pick'd out an act,Under whose heavy sense your brother's lifeFalls into forfeit: he arrests him on it;And follows close the rigour of the statute,To make him an example. All hope is gone,Unless you have the grace by your fair prayerTo soften Angelo: and that's my pith of business'Twixt you and your poor brother.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Doth he so seek his life?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Has censured himAlready; and, as I hear, the provost hathA warrant for his execution.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Alas! what poor ability's in meTo do him good?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Assay the power you have.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: My power? Alas, I doubt--

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Our doubts are traitorsAnd make us lose the good we oft might winBy fearing to attempt. Go to Lord Angelo,And let him learn to know, when maidens sue,Men give like gods; but when they weep and kneel,All their petitions are as freely theirsAs they themselves would owe them.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: I'll see what I can do.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: But speedily.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: I will about it straight;No longer staying but to give the motherNotice of my affair. I humbly thank you:Commend me to my brother: soon at nightI'll send him certain word of my success.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: I take my leave of you.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Good sir, adieu.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: We must not make a scarecrow of the law,Setting it up to fear the birds of prey,And let it keep one shape, till custom make itTheir perch and not their terror.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Ay, but yetLet us be keen, and rather cut a little,Than fall, and bruise to death. Alas, this gentlemanWhom I would save, had a most noble father!Let but your honour know,Whom I believe to be most strait in virtue,That, in the working of your own affections,Had time cohered with place or place with wishing,Or that the resolute acting of your bloodCould have attain'd the effect of your own purpose,Whether you had not sometime in your lifeErr'd in this point which now you censure him,And pull'd the law upon you.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: 'Tis one thing to be tempted, Escalus,Another thing to fall. I not deny,The jury, passing on the prisoner's life,May in the sworn twelve have a thief or twoGuiltier than him they try. What's open made to justice,That justice seizes: what know the lawsThat thieves do pass on thieves? 'Tis very pregnant,The jewel that we find, we stoop and take'tBecause we see it; but what we do not seeWe tread upon, and never think of it.You may not so extenuate his offenceFor I have had such faults; but rather tell me,When I, that censure him, do so offend,Let mine own judgment pattern out my death,And nothing come in partial. Sir, he must die.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Be it as your wisdom will.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Where is the provost?

speaker: Provost
dialog: Here, if it like your honour.

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: Come, bring them away: if these be good people ina commonweal that do nothing but use their abuses incommon houses, I know no law: bring them away.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: How now, sir! What's your name? and what's the matter?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: If it Please your honour, I am the poor duke'sconstable, and my name is Elbow: I do lean uponjustice, sir, and do bring in here before your goodhonour two notorious benefactors.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Benefactors? Well; what benefactors are they? arethey not malefactors?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: If it? please your honour, I know not well what theyare: but precise villains they are, that I am sureof; and void of all profanation in the world thatgood Christians ought to have.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: This comes off well; here's a wise officer.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Go to: what quality are they of? Elbow is yourname? why dost thou not speak, Elbow?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: He cannot, sir; he's out at elbow.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: What are you, sir?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: He, sir! a tapster, sir; parcel-bawd; one thatserves a bad woman; whose house, sir, was, as theysay, plucked down in the suburbs; and now sheprofesses a hot-house, which, I think, is a very ill house too.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: How know you that?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: My wife, sir, whom I detest before heaven and your honour,--

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: How? thy wife?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: Ay, sir; whom, I thank heaven, is an honest woman,--

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Dost thou detest her therefore?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: I say, sir, I will detest myself also, as well asshe, that this house, if it be not a bawd's house,it is pity of her life, for it is a naughty house.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: How dost thou know that, constable?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: Marry, sir, by my wife; who, if she had been a womancardinally given, might have been accused infornication, adultery, and all uncleanliness there.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: By the woman's means?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: Ay, sir, by Mistress Overdone's means: but as shespit in his face, so she defied him.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Sir, if it please your honour, this is not so.

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: Prove it before these varlets here, thou honourableman; prove it.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Do you hear how he misplaces?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Sir, she came in great with child; and longing,saving your honour's reverence, for stewed prunes;sir, we had but two in the house, which at that verydistant time stood, as it were, in a fruit-dish, adish of some three-pence; your honours have seensuch dishes; they are not China dishes, but verygood dishes,--

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Go to, go to: no matter for the dish, sir.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: No, indeed, sir, not of a pin; you are therein inthe right: but to the point. As I say, thisMistress Elbow, being, as I say, with child, andbeing great-bellied, and longing, as I said, forprunes; and having but two in the dish, as I said,Master Froth here, this very man, having eaten therest, as I said, and, as I say, paying for them veryhonestly; for, as you know, Master Froth, I couldnot give you three-pence again.

speaker: FROTH
dialog: No, indeed.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Very well: you being then, if you be remembered,cracking the stones of the foresaid prunes,--

speaker: FROTH
dialog: Ay, so I did indeed.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Why, very well; I telling you then, if you beremembered, that such a one and such a one were pastcure of the thing you wot of, unless they kept verygood diet, as I told you,--

speaker: FROTH
dialog: All this is true.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Why, very well, then,--

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Come, you are a tedious fool: to the purpose. Whatwas done to Elbow's wife, that he hath cause tocomplain of? Come me to what was done to her.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Sir, your honour cannot come to that yet.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: No, sir, nor I mean it not.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Sir, but you shall come to it, by your honour'sleave. And, I beseech you, look into Master Frothhere, sir; a man of four-score pound a year; whosefather died at Hallowmas: was't not at Hallowmas,Master Froth?

speaker: FROTH
dialog: All-hallond eve.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Why, very well; I hope here be truths. He, sir,sitting, as I say, in a lower chair, sir; 'twas inthe Bunch of Grapes, where indeed you have a delightto sit, have you not?

speaker: FROTH
dialog: I have so; because it is an open room and good for winter.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Why, very well, then; I hope here be truths.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: This will last out a night in Russia,When nights are longest there: I'll take my leave.And leave you to the hearing of the cause;Hoping you'll find good cause to whip them all.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: I think no less. Good morrow to your lordship.Now, sir, come on: what was done to Elbow's wife, once more?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Once, sir? there was nothing done to her once.

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: I beseech you, sir, ask him what this man did to my wife.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: I beseech your honour, ask me.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Well, sir; what did this gentleman to her?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: I beseech you, sir, look in this gentleman's face.Good Master Froth, look upon his honour; 'tis for agood purpose. Doth your honour mark his face?

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Ay, sir, very well.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Nay; I beseech you, mark it well.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Well, I do so.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Doth your honour see any harm in his face?

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Why, no.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: I'll be supposed upon a book, his face is the worstthing about him. Good, then; if his face be theworst thing about him, how could Master Froth do theconstable's wife any harm? I would know that ofyour honour.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: He's in the right. Constable, what say you to it?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: First, an it like you, the house is a respectedhouse; next, this is a respected fellow; and hismistress is a respected woman.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: By this hand, sir, his wife is a more respectedperson than any of us all.

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: Varlet, thou liest; thou liest, wicked varlet! thetime has yet to come that she was ever respectedwith man, woman, or child.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Sir, she was respected with him before he married with her.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Which is the wiser here? Justice or Iniquity? Isthis true?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: O thou caitiff! O thou varlet! O thou wickedHannibal! I respected with her before I was marriedto her! If ever I was respected with her, or shewith me, let not your worship think me the poorduke's officer. Prove this, thou wicked Hannibal, orI'll have mine action of battery on thee.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: If he took you a box o' the ear, you might have youraction of slander too.

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: Marry, I thank your good worship for it. What is'tyour worship's pleasure I shall do with this wicked caitiff?

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Truly, officer, because he hath some offences in himthat thou wouldst discover if thou couldst, let himcontinue in his courses till thou knowest what theyare.

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: Marry, I thank your worship for it. Thou seest, thouwicked varlet, now, what's come upon thee: thou artto continue now, thou varlet; thou art to continue.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Where were you born, friend?

speaker: FROTH
dialog: Here in Vienna, sir.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Are you of fourscore pounds a year?

speaker: FROTH
dialog: Yes, an't please you, sir.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: So. What trade are you of, sir?

speaker: POMPHEY
dialog: Tapster; a poor widow's tapster.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Your mistress' name?

speaker: POMPHEY
dialog: Mistress Overdone.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Hath she had any more than one husband?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Nine, sir; Overdone by the last.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Nine! Come hither to me, Master Froth. MasterFroth, I would not have you acquainted withtapsters: they will draw you, Master Froth, and youwill hang them. Get you gone, and let me hear nomore of you.

speaker: FROTH
dialog: I thank your worship. For mine own part, I nevercome into any room in a tap-house, but I am drawnin.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Well, no more of it, Master Froth: farewell.Come you hither to me, Master tapster. What's yourname, Master tapster?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Pompey.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: What else?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Bum, sir.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Troth, and your bum is the greatest thing about you;so that in the beastliest sense you are Pompey theGreat. Pompey, you are partly a bawd, Pompey,howsoever you colour it in being a tapster, are younot? come, tell me true: it shall be the better for you.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Truly, sir, I am a poor fellow that would live.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: How would you live, Pompey? by being a bawd? Whatdo you think of the trade, Pompey? is it a lawful trade?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: If the law would allow it, sir.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: But the law will not allow it, Pompey; nor it shallnot be allowed in Vienna.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Does your worship mean to geld and splay all theyouth of the city?

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: No, Pompey.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Truly, sir, in my poor opinion, they will to't then.If your worship will take order for the drabs andthe knaves, you need not to fear the bawds.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: There are pretty orders beginning, I can tell you:it is but heading and hanging.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: If you head and hang all that offend that way butfor ten year together, you'll be glad to give out acommission for more heads: if this law hold inVienna ten year, I'll rent the fairest house in itafter three-pence a bay: if you live to see thiscome to pass, say Pompey told you so.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Thank you, good Pompey; and, in requital of yourprophecy, hark you: I advise you, let me not findyou before me again upon any complaint whatsoever;no, not for dwelling where you do: if I do, Pompey,I shall beat you to your tent, and prove a shrewdCaesar to you; in plain dealing, Pompey, I shallhave you whipt: so, for this time, Pompey, fare you well.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: I thank your worship for your good counsel:but I shall follow it as the flesh and fortune shallbetter determine.Whip me? No, no; let carman whip his jade:The valiant heart is not whipt out of his trade.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Come hither to me, Master Elbow; come hither, Masterconstable. How long have you been in this place of constable?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: Seven year and a half, sir.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: I thought, by your readiness in the office, you hadcontinued in it some time. You say, seven years together?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: And a half, sir.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Alas, it hath been great pains to you. They do youwrong to put you so oft upon 't: are there not menin your ward sufficient to serve it?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: Faith, sir, few of any wit in such matters: as theyare chosen, they are glad to choose me for them; Ido it for some piece of money, and go through withall.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Look you bring me in the names of some six or seven,the most sufficient of your parish.

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: To your worship's house, sir?

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: To my house. Fare you well.What's o'clock, think you?

speaker: Justice
dialog: Eleven, sir.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: I pray you home to dinner with me.

speaker: Justice
dialog: I humbly thank you.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: It grieves me for the death of Claudio;But there's no remedy.

speaker: Justice
dialog: Lord Angelo is severe.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: It is but needful:Mercy is not itself, that oft looks so;Pardon is still the nurse of second woe:But yet,--poor Claudio! There is no remedy.Come, sir.

speaker: Servant
dialog: He's hearing of a cause; he will come straightI'll tell him of you.

speaker: Provost
dialog: Pray you, do.I'll knowHis pleasure; may be he will relent. Alas,He hath but as offended in a dream!All sects, all ages smack of this vice; and heTo die for't!

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Now, what's the matter. Provost?

speaker: Provost
dialog: Is it your will Claudio shall die tomorrow?

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Did not I tell thee yea? hadst thou not order?Why dost thou ask again?

speaker: Provost
dialog: Lest I might be too rash:Under your good correction, I have seen,When, after execution, judgment hathRepented o'er his doom.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Go to; let that be mine:Do you your office, or give up your place,And you shall well be spared.

speaker: Provost
dialog: I crave your honour's pardon.What shall be done, sir, with the groaning Juliet?She's very near her hour.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Dispose of herTo some more fitter place, and that with speed.

speaker: Servant
dialog: Here is the sister of the man condemn'dDesires access to you.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Hath he a sister?

speaker: Provost
dialog: Ay, my good lord; a very virtuous maid,And to be shortly of a sisterhood,If not already.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Well, let her be admitted.See you the fornicatress be removed:Let have needful, but not lavish, means;There shall be order for't.

speaker: Provost
dialog: God save your honour!

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Stay a little while.You're welcome: what's your will?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: I am a woeful suitor to your honour,Please but your honour hear me.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Well; what's your suit?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: There is a vice that most I do abhor,And most desire should meet the blow of justice;For which I would not plead, but that I must;For which I must not plead, but that I amAt war 'twixt will and will not.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Well; the matter?

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Condemn the fault and not the actor of it?Why, every fault's condemn'd ere it be done:Mine were the very cipher of a function,To fine the faults whose fine stands in record,And let go by the actor.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: O just but severe law!I had a brother, then. Heaven keep your honour!

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Maiden, no remedy.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Yes; I do think that you might pardon him,And neither heaven nor man grieve at the mercy.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: I will not do't.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: But can you, if you would?

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Look, what I will not, that I cannot do.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: But might you do't, and do the world no wrong,If so your heart were touch'd with that remorseAs mine is to him?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Too late? why, no; I, that do speak a word.May call it back again. Well, believe this,No ceremony that to great ones 'longs,Not the king's crown, nor the deputed sword,The marshal's truncheon, nor the judge's robe,Become them with one half so good a graceAs mercy does.If he had been as you and you as he,You would have slipt like him; but he, like you,Would not have been so stern.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Pray you, be gone.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Your brother is a forfeit of the law,And you but waste your words.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Alas, alas!Why, all the souls that were were forfeit once;And He that might the vantage best have tookFound out the remedy. How would you be,If He, which is the top of judgment, shouldBut judge you as you are? O, think on that;And mercy then will breathe within your lips,Like man new made.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Be you content, fair maid;It is the law, not I condemn your brother:Were he my kinsman, brother, or my son,It should be thus with him: he must die tomorrow.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: To-morrow! O, that's sudden! Spare him, spare him!He's not prepared for death. Even for our kitchensWe kill the fowl of season: shall we serve heavenWith less respect than we do ministerTo our gross selves? Good, good my lord, bethink you;Who is it that hath died for this offence?There's many have committed it.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Yet show some pity.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: I show it most of all when I show justice;For then I pity those I do not know,Which a dismiss'd offence would after gall;And do him right that, answering one foul wrong,Lives not to act another. Be satisfied;Your brother dies to-morrow; be content.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Thou'rt i' the right, girl; more o, that.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: That in the captain's but a choleric word,Which in the soldier is flat blasphemy.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Gentle my lord, turn back.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: I will bethink me: come again tomorrow.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Hark how I'll bribe you: good my lord, turn back.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: How! bribe me?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Not with fond shekels of the tested gold,Or stones whose rates are either rich or poorAs fancy values them; but with true prayersThat shall be up at heaven and enter thereEre sun-rise, prayers from preserved souls,From fasting maids whose minds are dedicateTo nothing temporal.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Well; come to me to-morrow.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: At any time 'fore noon.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: 'Save your honour!

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: From thee, even from thy virtue!What's this, what's this? Is this her fault or mine?The tempter or the tempted, who sins most?Ha!Not she: nor doth she tempt: but it is IThat, lying by the violet in the sun,Do as the carrion does, not as the flower,Corrupt with virtuous season. Can it beThat modesty may more betray our senseThan woman's lightness? Having waste ground enough,Shall we desire to raze the sanctuaryAnd pitch our evils there? O, fie, fie, fie!What dost thou, or what art thou, Angelo?Dost thou desire her foully for those thingsThat make her good? O, let her brother live!Thieves for their robbery have authorityWhen judges steal themselves. What, do I love her,That I desire to hear her speak again,And feast upon her eyes? What is't I dream on?O cunning enemy, that, to catch a saint,With saints dost bait thy hook! Most dangerousIs that temptation that doth goad us onTo sin in loving virtue: never could the strumpet,With all her double vigour, art and nature,Once stir my temper; but this virtuous maidSubdues me quite. Even till now,When men were fond, I smiled and wonder'd how.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Hail to you, provost! so I think you are.

speaker: Provost
dialog: I am the provost. What's your will, good friar?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Bound by my charity and my blest order,I come to visit the afflicted spiritsHere in the prison. Do me the common rightTo let me see them and to make me knowThe nature of their crimes, that I may ministerTo them accordingly.

speaker: Provost
dialog: I would do more than that, if more were needful.Look, here comes one: a gentlewoman of mine,Who, falling in the flaws of her own youth,Hath blister'd her report: she is with child;And he that got it, sentenced; a young manMore fit to do another such offenceThan die for this.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: When must he die?

speaker: Provost
dialog: As I do think, to-morrow.I have provided for you: stay awhile,And you shall be conducted.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Repent you, fair one, of the sin you carry?

speaker: JULIET
dialog: I do; and bear the shame most patiently.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: I'll teach you how you shall arraign your conscience,And try your penitence, if it be sound,Or hollowly put on.

speaker: JULIET
dialog: I'll gladly learn.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Love you the man that wrong'd you?

speaker: JULIET
dialog: Yes, as I love the woman that wrong'd him.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: So then it seems your most offenceful actWas mutually committed?

speaker: JULIET
dialog: Mutually.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Then was your sin of heavier kind than his.

speaker: JULIET
dialog: I do confess it, and repent it, father.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: 'Tis meet so, daughter: but lest you do repent,As that the sin hath brought you to this shame,Which sorrow is always towards ourselves, not heaven,Showing we would not spare heaven as we love it,But as we stand in fear,--

speaker: JULIET
dialog: I do repent me, as it is an evil,And take the shame with joy.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: There rest.Your partner, as I hear, must die to-morrow,And I am going with instruction to him.Grace go with you, Benedicite!

speaker: JULIET
dialog: Must die to-morrow! O injurious love,That respites me a life, whose very comfortIs still a dying horror!

speaker: Provost
dialog: 'Tis pity of him.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: When I would pray and think, I think and prayTo several subjects. Heaven hath my empty words;Whilst my invention, hearing not my tongue,Anchors on Isabel: Heaven in my mouth,As if I did but only chew his name;And in my heart the strong and swelling evilOf my conception. The state, whereon I studiedIs like a good thing, being often read,Grown fear'd and tedious; yea, my gravity,Wherein--let no man hear me--I take pride,Could I with boot change for an idle plume,Which the air beats for vain. O place, O form,How often dost thou with thy case, thy habit,Wrench awe from fools and tie the wiser soulsTo thy false seeming! Blood, thou art blood:Let's write good angel on the devil's horn:'Tis not the devil's crest.How now! who's there?

speaker: Servant
dialog: One Isabel, a sister, desires access to you.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Teach her the way.O heavens!Why does my blood thus muster to my heart,Making both it unable for itself,And dispossessing all my other partsOf necessary fitness?So play the foolish throngs with one that swoons;Come all to help him, and so stop the airBy which he should revive: and even soThe general, subject to a well-wish'd king,Quit their own part, and in obsequious fondnessCrowd to his presence, where their untaught loveMust needs appear offence.How now, fair maid?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: I am come to know your pleasure.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: That you might know it, would much better please meThan to demand what 'tis. Your brother cannot live.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Even so. Heaven keep your honour!

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Yet may he live awhile; and, it may be,As long as you or I yet he must die.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Under your sentence?

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Yea.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: When, I beseech you? that in his reprieve,Longer or shorter, he may be so fittedThat his soul sicken not.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Ha! fie, these filthy vices! It were as goodTo pardon him that hath from nature stolenA man already made, as to remitTheir saucy sweetness that do coin heaven's imageIn stamps that are forbid: 'tis all as easyFalsely to take away a life true madeAs to put metal in restrained meansTo make a false one.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: 'Tis set down so in heaven, but not in earth.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Say you so? then I shall pose you quickly.Which had you rather, that the most just lawNow took your brother's life; or, to redeem him,Give up your body to such sweet uncleannessAs she that he hath stain'd?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Sir, believe this,I had rather give my body than my soul.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: I talk not of your soul: our compell'd sinsStand more for number than for accompt.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: How say you?

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Nay, I'll not warrant that; for I can speakAgainst the thing I say. Answer to this:I, now the voice of the recorded law,Pronounce a sentence on your brother's life:Might there not be a charity in sinTo save this brother's life?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Please you to do't,I'll take it as a peril to my soul,It is no sin at all, but charity.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Pleased you to do't at peril of your soul,Were equal poise of sin and charity.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: That I do beg his life, if it be sin,Heaven let me bear it! you granting of my suit,If that be sin, I'll make it my morn prayerTo have it added to the faults of mine,And nothing of your answer.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Nay, but hear me.Your sense pursues not mine: either you are ignorant,Or seem so craftily; and that's not good.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Let me be ignorant, and in nothing good,But graciously to know I am no better.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Thus wisdom wishes to appear most brightWhen it doth tax itself; as these black masksProclaim an enshield beauty ten times louderThan beauty could, display'd. But mark me;To be received plain, I'll speak more gross:Your brother is to die.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: So.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: And his offence is so, as it appears,Accountant to the law upon that pain.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: True.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Admit no other way to save his life,--As I subscribe not that, nor any other,But in the loss of question,--that you, his sister,Finding yourself desired of such a person,Whose credit with the judge, or own great place,Could fetch your brother from the manaclesOf the all-building law; and that there wereNo earthly mean to save him, but that eitherYou must lay down the treasures of your bodyTo this supposed, or else to let him suffer;What would you do?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: As much for my poor brother as myself:That is, were I under the terms of death,The impression of keen whips I'ld wear as rubies,And strip myself to death, as to a bedThat longing have been sick for, ere I'ld yieldMy body up to shame.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Then must your brother die.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: And 'twere the cheaper way:Better it were a brother died at once,Than that a sister, by redeeming him,Should die for ever.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Were not you then as cruel as the sentenceThat you have slander'd so?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Ignomy in ransom and free pardonAre of two houses: lawful mercyIs nothing kin to foul redemption.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: You seem'd of late to make the law a tyrant;And rather proved the sliding of your brotherA merriment than a vice.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: O, pardon me, my lord; it oft falls out,To have what we would have, we speak not what we mean:I something do excuse the thing I hate,For his advantage that I dearly love.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: We are all frail.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Else let my brother die,If not a feodary, but only heOwe and succeed thy weakness.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Nay, women are frail too.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Ay, as the glasses where they view themselves;Which are as easy broke as they make forms.Women! Help Heaven! men their creation marIn profiting by them. Nay, call us ten times frail;For we are soft as our complexions are,And credulous to false prints.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: I think it well:And from this testimony of your own sex,--Since I suppose we are made to be no strongerThan faults may shake our frames,--let me be bold;I do arrest your words. Be that you are,That is, a woman; if you be more, you're none;If you be one, as you are well express'dBy all external warrants, show it now,By putting on the destined livery.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: I have no tongue but one: gentle my lord,Let me entreat you speak the former language.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Plainly conceive, I love you.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: My brother did love Juliet,And you tell me that he shall die for it.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: He shall not, Isabel, if you give me love.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: I know your virtue hath a licence in't,Which seems a little fouler than it is,To pluck on others.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Believe me, on mine honour,My words express my purpose.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Ha! little honour to be much believed,And most pernicious purpose! Seeming, seeming!I will proclaim thee, Angelo; look for't:Sign me a present pardon for my brother,Or with an outstretch'd throat I'll tell the world aloudWhat man thou art.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Who will believe thee, Isabel?My unsoil'd name, the austereness of my life,My vouch against you, and my place i' the state,Will so your accusation overweigh,That you shall stifle in your own reportAnd smell of calumny. I have begun,And now I give my sensual race the rein:Fit thy consent to my sharp appetite;Lay by all nicety and prolixious blushes,That banish what they sue for; redeem thy brotherBy yielding up thy body to my will;Or else he must not only die the death,But thy unkindness shall his death draw outTo lingering sufferance. Answer me to-morrow,Or, by the affection that now guides me most,I'll prove a tyrant to him. As for you,Say what you can, my false o'erweighs your true.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: To whom should I complain? Did I tell this,Who would believe me? O perilous mouths,That bear in them one and the self-same tongue,Either of condemnation or approof;Bidding the law make court'sy to their will:Hooking both right and wrong to the appetite,To follow as it draws! I'll to my brother:Though he hath fallen by prompture of the blood,Yet hath he in him such a mind of honour.That, had he twenty heads to tender downOn twenty bloody blocks, he'ld yield them up,Before his sister should her body stoopTo such abhorr'd pollution.Then, Isabel, live chaste, and, brother, die:More than our brother is our chastity.I'll tell him yet of Angelo's request,And fit his mind to death, for his soul's rest.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: So then you hope of pardon from Lord Angelo?

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: The miserable have no other medicineBut only hope:I've hope to live, and am prepared to die.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Be absolute for death; either death or lifeShall thereby be the sweeter. Reason thus with life:If I do lose thee, I do lose a thingThat none but fools would keep: a breath thou art,Servile to all the skyey influences,That dost this habitation, where thou keep'st,Hourly afflict: merely, thou art death's fool;For him thou labour'st by thy flight to shunAnd yet runn'st toward him still. Thou art not noble;For all the accommodations that thou bear'stAre nursed by baseness. Thou'rt by no means valiant;For thou dost fear the soft and tender forkOf a poor worm. Thy best of rest is sleep,And that thou oft provokest; yet grossly fear'stThy death, which is no more. Thou art not thyself;For thou exist'st on many a thousand grainsThat issue out of dust. Happy thou art not;For what thou hast not, still thou strivest to get,And what thou hast, forget'st. Thou art not certain;For thy complexion shifts to strange effects,After the moon. If thou art rich, thou'rt poor;For, like an ass whose back with ingots bows,Thou bear's thy heavy riches but a journey,And death unloads thee. Friend hast thou none;For thine own bowels, which do call thee sire,The mere effusion of thy proper loins,Do curse the gout, serpigo, and the rheum,For ending thee no sooner. Thou hast nor youth nor age,But, as it were, an after-dinner's sleep,Dreaming on both; for all thy blessed youthBecomes as aged, and doth beg the almsOf palsied eld; and when thou art old and rich,Thou hast neither heat, affection, limb, nor beauty,To make thy riches pleasant. What's yet in thisThat bears the name of life? Yet in this lifeLie hid moe thousand deaths: yet death we fear,That makes these odds all even.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: I humbly thank you.To sue to live, I find I seek to die;And, seeking death, find life: let it come on.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Dear sir, ere long I'll visit you again.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Most holy sir, I thank you.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: My business is a word or two with Claudio.

speaker: Provost
dialog: And very welcome. Look, signior, here's your sister.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Provost, a word with you.

speaker: Provost
dialog: As many as you please.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Bring me to hear them speak, where I may be concealed.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Now, sister, what's the comfort?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Why,As all comforts are; most good, most good indeed.Lord Angelo, having affairs to heaven,Intends you for his swift ambassador,Where you shall be an everlasting leiger:Therefore your best appointment make with speed;To-morrow you set on.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Is there no remedy?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: None, but such remedy as, to save a head,To cleave a heart in twain.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: But is there any?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Yes, brother, you may live:There is a devilish mercy in the judge,If you'll implore it, that will free your life,But fetter you till death.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Perpetual durance?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Ay, just; perpetual durance, a restraint,Though all the world's vastidity you had,To a determined scope.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: But in what nature?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: In such a one as, you consenting to't,Would bark your honour from that trunk you bear,And leave you naked.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Let me know the point.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: O, I do fear thee, Claudio; and I quake,Lest thou a feverous life shouldst entertain,And six or seven winters more respectThan a perpetual honour. Darest thou die?The sense of death is most in apprehension;And the poor beetle, that we tread upon,In corporal sufferance finds a pang as greatAs when a giant dies.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Why give you me this shame?Think you I can a resolution fetchFrom flowery tenderness? If I must die,I will encounter darkness as a bride,And hug it in mine arms.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: There spake my brother; there my father's graveDid utter forth a voice. Yes, thou must die:Thou art too noble to conserve a lifeIn base appliances. This outward-sainted deputy,Whose settled visage and deliberate wordNips youth i' the head and follies doth emmewAs falcon doth the fowl, is yet a devilHis filth within being cast, he would appearA pond as deep as hell.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: The prenzie Angelo!

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: O, 'tis the cunning livery of hell,The damned'st body to invest and coverIn prenzie guards! Dost thou think, Claudio?If I would yield him my virginity,Thou mightst be freed.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: O heavens! it cannot be.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Yes, he would give't thee, from this rank offence,So to offend him still. This night's the timeThat I should do what I abhor to name,Or else thou diest to-morrow.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Thou shalt not do't.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: O, were it but my life,I'ld throw it down for your deliveranceAs frankly as a pin.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Thanks, dear Isabel.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Be ready, Claudio, for your death tomorrow.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Yes. Has he affections in him,That thus can make him bite the law by the nose,When he would force it? Sure, it is no sin,Or of the deadly seven, it is the least.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Which is the least?

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: If it were damnable, he being so wise,Why would he for the momentary trickBe perdurably fined? O Isabel!

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: What says my brother?

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Death is a fearful thing.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: And shamed life a hateful.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Ay, but to die, and go we know not where;To lie in cold obstruction and to rot;This sensible warm motion to becomeA kneaded clod; and the delighted spiritTo bathe in fiery floods, or to resideIn thrilling region of thick-ribbed ice;To be imprison'd in the viewless winds,And blown with restless violence round aboutThe pendent world; or to be worse than worstOf those that lawless and incertain thoughtImagine howling: 'tis too horrible!The weariest and most loathed worldly lifeThat age, ache, penury and imprisonmentCan lay on nature is a paradiseTo what we fear of death.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Alas, alas!

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Sweet sister, let me live:What sin you do to save a brother's life,Nature dispenses with the deed so farThat it becomes a virtue.

speaker: ISABELLA
