dialog: O you beast!O faithless coward! O dishonest wretch!Wilt thou be made a man out of my vice?Is't not a kind of incest, to take lifeFrom thine own sister's shame? What should I think?Heaven shield my mother play'd my father fair!For such a warped slip of wildernessNe'er issued from his blood. Take my defiance!Die, perish! Might but my bending downReprieve thee from thy fate, it should proceed:I'll pray a thousand prayers for thy death,No word to save thee.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Nay, hear me, Isabel.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: O, fie, fie, fie!Thy sin's not accidental, but a trade.Mercy to thee would prove itself a bawd:'Tis best thou diest quickly.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: O hear me, Isabella!

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Vouchsafe a word, young sister, but one word.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: What is your will?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Might you dispense with your leisure, I would by andby have some speech with you: the satisfaction Iwould require is likewise your own benefit.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: I have no superfluous leisure; my stay must bestolen out of other affairs; but I will attend you awhile.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Son, I have overheard what hath passed between youand your sister. Angelo had never the purpose tocorrupt her; only he hath made an essay of hervirtue to practise his judgment with the dispositionof natures: she, having the truth of honour in her,hath made him that gracious denial which he is mostglad to receive. I am confessor to Angelo, and Iknow this to be true; therefore prepare yourself todeath: do not satisfy your resolution with hopesthat are fallible: tomorrow you must die; go toyour knees and make ready.

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: Let me ask my sister pardon. I am so out of lovewith life that I will sue to be rid of it.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Hold you there: farewell.Provost, a word with you!

speaker: Provost
dialog: What's your will, father

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: That now you are come, you will be gone. Leave meawhile with the maid: my mind promises with myhabit no loss shall touch her by my company.

speaker: Provost
dialog: In good time.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: The hand that hath made you fair hath made you good:the goodness that is cheap in beauty makes beautybrief in goodness; but grace, being the soul ofyour complexion, shall keep the body of it everfair. The assault that Angelo hath made to you,fortune hath conveyed to my understanding; and, butthat frailty hath examples for his falling, I shouldwonder at Angelo. How will you do to content thissubstitute, and to save your brother?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: I am now going to resolve him: I had rather mybrother die by the law than my son should beunlawfully born. But, O, how much is the good dukedeceived in Angelo! If ever he return and I canspeak to him, I will open my lips in vain, ordiscover his government.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: That shall not be much amiss: Yet, as the matternow stands, he will avoid your accusation; he madetrial of you only. Therefore fasten your ear on myadvisings: to the love I have in doing good aremedy presents itself. I do make myself believethat you may most uprighteously do a poor wrongedlady a merited benefit; redeem your brother fromthe angry law; do no stain to your own graciousperson; and much please the absent duke, ifperadventure he shall ever return to have hearing ofthis business.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Let me hear you speak farther. I have spirit to doanything that appears not foul in the truth of my spirit.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Virtue is bold, and goodness never fearful. Haveyou not heard speak of Mariana, the sister ofFrederick the great soldier who miscarried at sea?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: I have heard of the lady, and good words went with her name.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: She should this Angelo have married; was affiancedto her by oath, and the nuptial appointed: betweenwhich time of the contract and limit of thesolemnity, her brother Frederick was wrecked at sea,having in that perished vessel the dowry of hissister. But mark how heavily this befell to thepoor gentlewoman: there she lost a noble andrenowned brother, in his love toward her ever mostkind and natural; with him, the portion and sinew ofher fortune, her marriage-dowry; with both, hercombinate husband, this well-seeming Angelo.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Can this be so? did Angelo so leave her?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Left her in her tears, and dried not one of themwith his comfort; swallowed his vows whole,pretending in her discoveries of dishonour: in few,bestowed her on her own lamentation, which she yetwears for his sake; and he, a marble to her tears,is washed with them, but relents not.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: What a merit were it in death to take this poor maidfrom the world! What corruption in this life, thatit will let this man live! But how out of this can she avail?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: It is a rupture that you may easily heal: and thecure of it not only saves your brother, but keepsyou from dishonour in doing it.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Show me how, good father.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: This forenamed maid hath yet in her the continuanceof her first affection: his unjust unkindness, thatin all reason should have quenched her love, hath,like an impediment in the current, made it moreviolent and unruly. Go you to Angelo; answer hisrequiring with a plausible obedience; agree withhis demands to the point; only refer yourself tothis advantage, first, that your stay with him maynot be long; that the time may have all shadow andsilence in it; and the place answer to convenience.This being granted in course,--and now followsall,--we shall advise this wronged maid to stead upyour appointment, go in your place; if the encounteracknowledge itself hereafter, it may compel him toher recompense: and here, by this, is your brothersaved, your honour untainted, the poor Marianaadvantaged, and the corrupt deputy scaled. The maidwill I frame and make fit for his attempt. If youthink well to carry this as you may, the doublenessof the benefit defends the deceit from reproof.What think you of it?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: The image of it gives me content already; and Itrust it will grow to a most prosperous perfection.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: It lies much in your holding up. Haste you speedilyto Angelo: if for this night he entreat you to hisbed, give him promise of satisfaction. I willpresently to Saint Luke's: there, at the moatedgrange, resides this dejected Mariana. At thatplace call upon me; and dispatch with Angelo, thatit may be quickly.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: I thank you for this comfort. Fare you well, good father.

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: Nay, if there be no remedy for it, but that you willneeds buy and sell men and women like beasts, weshall have all the world drink brown and white bastard.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: O heavens! what stuff is here

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: 'Twas never merry world since, of two usuries, themerriest was put down, and the worser allowed byorder of law a furred gown to keep him warm; andfurred with fox and lamb-skins too, to signify, thatcraft, being richer than innocency, stands for the facing.

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: Come your way, sir. 'Bless you, good father friar.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: And you, good brother father. What offence haththis man made you, sir?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: Marry, sir, he hath offended the law: and, sir, wetake him to be a thief too, sir; for we have foundupon him, sir, a strange picklock, which we havesent to the deputy.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Fie, sirrah! a bawd, a wicked bawd!The evil that thou causest to be done,That is thy means to live. Do thou but thinkWhat 'tis to cram a maw or clothe a backFrom such a filthy vice: say to thyself,From their abominable and beastly touchesI drink, I eat, array myself, and live.Canst thou believe thy living is a life,So stinkingly depending? Go mend, go mend.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Indeed, it does stink in some sort, sir; but yet,sir, I would prove--

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Nay, if the devil have given thee proofs for sin,Thou wilt prove his. Take him to prison, officer:Correction and instruction must both workEre this rude beast will profit.

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: He must before the deputy, sir; he has given himwarning: the deputy cannot abide a whoremaster: ifhe be a whoremonger, and comes before him, he wereas good go a mile on his errand.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: That we were all, as some would seem to be,From our faults, as faults from seeming, free!

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: His neck will come to your waist,--a cord, sir.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: I spy comfort; I cry bail. Here's a gentleman and afriend of mine.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: How now, noble Pompey! What, at the wheels ofCaesar? art thou led in triumph? What, is therenone of Pygmalion's images, newly made woman, to behad now, for putting the hand in the pocket andextracting it clutch'd? What reply, ha? Whatsayest thou to this tune, matter and method? Is'tnot drowned i' the last rain, ha? What sayestthou, Trot? Is the world as it was, man? Which isthe way? Is it sad, and few words? or how? Thetrick of it?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Still thus, and thus; still worse!

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: How doth my dear morsel, thy mistress? Procures shestill, ha?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Troth, sir, she hath eaten up all her beef, and sheis herself in the tub.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Why, 'tis good; it is the right of it; it must beso: ever your fresh whore and your powdered bawd:an unshunned consequence; it must be so. Art goingto prison, Pompey?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Yes, faith, sir.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Why, 'tis not amiss, Pompey. Farewell: go, say Isent thee thither. For debt, Pompey? or how?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: For being a bawd, for being a bawd.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Well, then, imprison him: if imprisonment be thedue of a bawd, why, 'tis his right: bawd is hedoubtless, and of antiquity too; bawd-born.Farewell, good Pompey. Commend me to the prison,Pompey: you will turn good husband now, Pompey; youwill keep the house.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: I hope, sir, your good worship will be my bail.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: No, indeed, will I not, Pompey; it is not the wear.I will pray, Pompey, to increase your bondage: Ifyou take it not patiently, why, your mettle is themore. Adieu, trusty Pompey. 'Bless you, friar.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: And you.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Does Bridget paint still, Pompey, ha?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: Come your ways, sir; come.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: You will not bail me, then, sir?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Then, Pompey, nor now. What news abroad, friar?what news?

speaker: ELBOW
dialog: Come your ways, sir; come.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Go to kennel, Pompey; go.What news, friar, of the duke?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: I know none. Can you tell me of any?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Some say he is with the Emperor of Russia; othersome, he is in Rome: but where is he, think you?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: I know not where; but wheresoever, I wish him well.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: It was a mad fantastical trick of him to steal fromthe state, and usurp the beggary he was never bornto. Lord Angelo dukes it well in his absence; heputs transgression to 't.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: He does well in 't.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: A little more lenity to lechery would do no harm inhim: something too crabbed that way, friar.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: It is too general a vice, and severity must cure it.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Yes, in good sooth, the vice is of a great kindred;it is well allied: but it is impossible to extirpit quite, friar, till eating and drinking be putdown. They say this Angelo was not made by man andwoman after this downright way of creation: is ittrue, think you?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: How should he be made, then?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Some report a sea-maid spawned him; some, that hewas begot between two stock-fishes. But it iscertain that when he makes water his urine iscongealed ice; that I know to be true: and he is amotion generative; that's infallible.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: You are pleasant, sir, and speak apace.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Why, what a ruthless thing is this in him, for therebellion of a codpiece to take away the life of aman! Would the duke that is absent have done this?Ere he would have hanged a man for the getting ahundred bastards, he would have paid for the nursinga thousand: he had some feeling of the sport: heknew the service, and that instructed him to mercy.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: I never heard the absent duke much detected forwomen; he was not inclined that way.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: O, sir, you are deceived.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: 'Tis not possible.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Who, not the duke? yes, your beggar of fifty; andhis use was to put a ducat in her clack-dish: theduke had crotchets in him. He would be drunk too;that let me inform you.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: You do him wrong, surely.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Sir, I was an inward of his. A shy fellow was theduke: and I believe I know the cause of hiswithdrawing.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: What, I prithee, might be the cause?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: No, pardon; 'tis a secret must be locked within theteeth and the lips: but this I can let youunderstand, the greater file of the subject held theduke to be wise.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Wise! why, no question but he was.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: A very superficial, ignorant, unweighing fellow.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Either this is the envy in you, folly, or mistaking:the very stream of his life and the business he hathhelmed must upon a warranted need give him a betterproclamation. Let him be but testimonied in his ownbringings-forth, and he shall appear to theenvious a scholar, a statesman and a soldier.Therefore you speak unskilfully: or if yourknowledge be more it is much darkened in your malice.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Sir, I know him, and I love him.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Love talks with better knowledge, and knowledge withdearer love.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Come, sir, I know what I know.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: I can hardly believe that, since you know not whatyou speak. But, if ever the duke return, as ourprayers are he may, let me desire you to make youranswer before him. If it be honest you have spoke,you have courage to maintain it: I am bound to callupon you; and, I pray you, your name?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Sir, my name is Lucio; well known to the duke.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: He shall know you better, sir, if I may live toreport you.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: I fear you not.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: O, you hope the duke will return no more; or youimagine me too unhurtful an opposite. But indeed Ican do you little harm; you'll forswear this again.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: I'll be hanged first: thou art deceived in me,friar. But no more of this. Canst thou tell ifClaudio die to-morrow or no?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Why should he die, sir?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Why? For filling a bottle with a tundish. I wouldthe duke we talk of were returned again: theungenitured agent will unpeople the province withcontinency; sparrows must not build in hishouse-eaves, because they are lecherous. The dukeyet would have dark deeds darkly answered; he wouldnever bring them to light: would he were returned!Marry, this Claudio is condemned for untrussing.Farewell, good friar: I prithee, pray for me. Theduke, I say to thee again, would eat mutton onFridays. He's not past it yet, and I say to thee,he would mouth with a beggar, though she smelt brownbread and garlic: say that I said so. Farewell.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: No might nor greatness in mortalityCan censure 'scape; back-wounding calumnyThe whitest virtue strikes. What king so strongCan tie the gall up in the slanderous tongue?But who comes here?

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Go; away with her to prison!

speaker: MISTRESS OVERDONE
dialog: Good my lord, be good to me; your honour is accounteda merciful man; good my lord.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Double and treble admonition, and still forfeit inthe same kind! This would make mercy swear and playthe tyrant.

speaker: Provost
dialog: A bawd of eleven years' continuance, may it pleaseyour honour.

speaker: MISTRESS OVERDONE
dialog: My lord, this is one Lucio's information against me.Mistress Kate Keepdown was with child by him in theduke's time; he promised her marriage: his childis a year and a quarter old, come Philip and Jacob:I have kept it myself; and see how he goes about to abuse me!

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: That fellow is a fellow of much licence: let him becalled before us. Away with her to prison! Go to;no more words.Provost, my brother Angelo will not be altered;Claudio must die to-morrow: let him be furnishedwith divines, and have all charitable preparation.if my brother wrought by my pity, it should not beso with him.

speaker: Provost
dialog: So please you, this friar hath been with him, andadvised him for the entertainment of death.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Good even, good father.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Bliss and goodness on you!

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Of whence are you?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Not of this country, though my chance is nowTo use it for my time: I am a brotherOf gracious order, late come from the SeeIn special business from his holiness.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: What news abroad i' the world?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: None, but that there is so great a fever ongoodness, that the dissolution of it must cure it:novelty is only in request; and it is as dangerousto be aged in any kind of course, as it is virtuousto be constant in any undertaking. There is scarcetruth enough alive to make societies secure; butsecurity enough to make fellowships accurst: muchupon this riddle runs the wisdom of the world. Thisnews is old enough, yet it is every day's news. Ipray you, sir, of what disposition was the duke?

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: One that, above all other strifes, contendedespecially to know himself.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: What pleasure was he given to?

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Rather rejoicing to see another merry, than merry atany thing which professed to make him rejoice: agentleman of all temperance. But leave we him tohis events, with a prayer they may prove prosperous;and let me desire to know how you find Claudioprepared. I am made to understand that you havelent him visitation.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: He professes to have received no sinister measurefrom his judge, but most willingly humbles himselfto the determination of justice: yet had he framedto himself, by the instruction of his frailty, manydeceiving promises of life; which I by my goodleisure have discredited to him, and now is heresolved to die.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: You have paid the heavens your function, and theprisoner the very debt of your calling. I havelaboured for the poor gentleman to the extremestshore of my modesty: but my brother justice have Ifound so severe, that he hath forced me to tell himhe is indeed Justice.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: If his own life answer the straitness of hisproceeding, it shall become him well; wherein if hechance to fail, he hath sentenced himself.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: I am going to visit the prisoner. Fare you well.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: Break off thy song, and haste thee quick away:Here comes a man of comfort, whose adviceHath often still'd my brawling discontent.I cry you mercy, sir; and well could wishYou had not found me here so musical:Let me excuse me, and believe me so,My mirth it much displeased, but pleased my woe.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: 'Tis good; though music oft hath such a charmTo make bad good, and good provoke to harm.I pray, you, tell me, hath any body inquiredfor me here to-day? much upon this time haveI promised here to meet.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: You have not been inquired after:I have sat here all day.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: I do constantly believe you. The time is come evennow. I shall crave your forbearance a little: maybe I will call upon you anon, for some advantage to yourself.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: I am always bound to you.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Very well met, and well come.What is the news from this good deputy?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: He hath a garden circummured with brick,Whose western side is with a vineyard back'd;And to that vineyard is a planched gate,That makes his opening with this bigger key:This other doth command a little doorWhich from the vineyard to the garden leads;There have I made my promiseUpon the heavy middle of the nightTo call upon him.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: But shall you on your knowledge find this way?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: I have ta'en a due and wary note upon't:With whispering and most guilty diligence,In action all of precept, he did show meThe way twice o'er.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Are there no other tokensBetween you 'greed concerning her observance?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: No, none, but only a repair i' the dark;And that I have possess'd him my most stayCan be but brief; for I have made him knowI have a servant comes with me along,That stays upon me, whose persuasion isI come about my brother.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: 'Tis well borne up.I have not yet made known to MarianaA word of this. What, ho! within! come forth!I pray you, be acquainted with this maid;She comes to do you good.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: I do desire the like.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Do you persuade yourself that I respect you?

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: Good friar, I know you do, and have found it.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Take, then, this your companion by the hand,Who hath a story ready for your ear.I shall attend your leisure: but make haste;The vaporous night approaches.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: Will't please you walk aside?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: O place and greatness! millions of false eyesAre stuck upon thee: volumes of reportRun with these false and most contrarious questsUpon thy doings: thousand escapes of witMake thee the father of their idle dreamsAnd rack thee in their fancies.Welcome, how agreed?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: She'll take the enterprise upon her, father,If you advise it.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: It is not my consent,But my entreaty too.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Little have you to sayWhen you depart from him, but, soft and low,'Remember now my brother.'

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: Fear me not.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Nor, gentle daughter, fear you not at all.He is your husband on a pre-contract:To bring you thus together, 'tis no sin,Sith that the justice of your title to himDoth flourish the deceit. Come, let us go:Our corn's to reap, for yet our tithe's to sow.

speaker: Provost
dialog: Come hither, sirrah. Can you cut off a man's head?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: If the man be a bachelor, sir, I can; but if he be amarried man, he's his wife's head, and I can nevercut off a woman's head.

speaker: Provost
dialog: Come, sir, leave me your snatches, and yield me adirect answer. To-morrow morning are to die Claudioand Barnardine. Here is in our prison a commonexecutioner, who in his office lacks a helper: ifyou will take it on you to assist him, it shallredeem you from your gyves; if not, you shall haveyour full time of imprisonment and your deliverancewith an unpitied whipping, for you have been anotorious bawd.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Sir, I have been an unlawful bawd time out of mind;but yet I will be content to be a lawful hangman. Iwould be glad to receive some instruction from myfellow partner.

speaker: Provost
dialog: What, ho! Abhorson! Where's Abhorson, there?

speaker: ABHORSON
dialog: Do you call, sir?

speaker: Provost
dialog: Sirrah, here's a fellow will help you to-morrow inyour execution. If you think it meet, compound withhim by the year, and let him abide here with you; ifnot, use him for the present and dismiss him. Hecannot plead his estimation with you; he hath been a bawd.

speaker: ABHORSON
dialog: A bawd, sir? fie upon him! he will discredit our mystery.

speaker: Provost
dialog: Go to, sir; you weigh equally; a feather will turnthe scale.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Pray, sir, by your good favour,--for surely, sir, agood favour you have, but that you have a hanginglook,--do you call, sir, your occupation a mystery?

speaker: ABHORSON
dialog: Ay, sir; a mystery

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Painting, sir, I have heard say, is a mystery; andyour whores, sir, being members of my occupation,using painting, do prove my occupation a mystery:but what mystery there should be in hanging, if Ishould be hanged, I cannot imagine.

speaker: ABHORSON
dialog: Sir, it is a mystery.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Proof?

speaker: ABHORSON
dialog: Every true man's apparel fits your thief: if it betoo little for your thief, your true man thinks itbig enough; if it be too big for your thief, yourthief thinks it little enough: so every true man'sapparel fits your thief.

speaker: Provost
dialog: Are you agreed?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Sir, I will serve him; for I do find your hangman isa more penitent trade than your bawd; he dothoftener ask forgiveness.

speaker: Provost
dialog: You, sirrah, provide your block and your axeto-morrow four o'clock.

speaker: ABHORSON
dialog: Come on, bawd; I will instruct thee in my trade; follow.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: I do desire to learn, sir: and I hope, if you haveoccasion to use me for your own turn, you shall findme yare; for truly, sir, for your kindness I owe youa good turn.

speaker: Provost
dialog: Call hither Barnardine and Claudio:The one has my pity; not a jot the other,Being a murderer, though he were my brother.Look, here's the warrant, Claudio, for thy death:'Tis now dead midnight, and by eight to-morrowThou must be made immortal. Where's Barnardine?

speaker: CLAUDIO
dialog: As fast lock'd up in sleep as guiltless labourWhen it lies starkly in the traveller's bones:He will not wake.

speaker: Provost
dialog: Who can do good on him?Well, go, prepare yourself.But, hark, what noise?Heaven give your spirits comfort!By and by.I hope it is some pardon or reprieveFor the most gentle Claudio.Welcome father.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: The best and wholesomest spirts of the nightEnvelope you, good Provost! Who call'd here of late?

speaker: Provost
dialog: None, since the curfew rung.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Not Isabel?

speaker: Provost
dialog: No.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: They will, then, ere't be long.

speaker: Provost
dialog: What comfort is for Claudio?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: There's some in hope.

speaker: Provost
dialog: It is a bitter deputy.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Not so, not so; his life is parallel'dEven with the stroke and line of his great justice:He doth with holy abstinence subdueThat in himself which he spurs on his powerTo qualify in others: were he meal'd with thatWhich he corrects, then were he tyrannous;But this being so, he's just.Now are they come.This is a gentle provost: seldom whenThe steeled gaoler is the friend of men.How now! what noise? That spirit's possessed with hasteThat wounds the unsisting postern with these strokes.

speaker: Provost
dialog: There he must stay until the officerArise to let him in: he is call'd up.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Have you no countermand for Claudio yet,But he must die to-morrow?

speaker: Provost
dialog: None, sir, none.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: As near the dawning, provost, as it is,You shall hear more ere morning.

speaker: Provost
dialog: HappilyYou something know; yet I believe there comesNo countermand; no such example have we:Besides, upon the very siege of justiceLord Angelo hath to the public earProfess'd the contrary.This is his lordship's man.

speaker: Provost
dialog: I told you. Lord Angelo, belike thinking me remissin mine office, awakens me with this unwontedputting-on; methinks strangely, for he hath not used it before.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Pray you, let's hear.

speaker: Provost
dialog: A Bohemian born, but here nursed un and bred; onethat is a prisoner nine years old.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: How came it that the absent duke had not eitherdelivered him to his liberty or executed him? Ihave heard it was ever his manner to do so.

speaker: Provost
dialog: His friends still wrought reprieves for him: and,indeed, his fact, till now in the government of LordAngelo, came not to an undoubtful proof.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: It is now apparent?

speaker: Provost
dialog: Most manifest, and not denied by himself.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Hath he born himself penitently in prison? howseems he to be touched?

speaker: Provost
dialog: A man that apprehends death no more dreadfully butas a drunken sleep; careless, reckless, and fearlessof what's past, present, or to come; insensible ofmortality, and desperately mortal.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: He wants advice.

speaker: Provost
dialog: He will hear none: he hath evermore had the libertyof the prison; give him leave to escape hence, hewould not: drunk many times a day, if not many daysentirely drunk. We have very oft awaked him, as ifto carry him to execution, and showed him a seemingwarrant for it: it hath not moved him at all.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: More of him anon. There is written in your brow,provost, honesty and constancy: if I read it nottruly, my ancient skill beguiles me; but, in theboldness of my cunning, I will lay myself in hazard.Claudio, whom here you have warrant to execute, isno greater forfeit to the law than Angelo who hathsentenced him. To make you understand this in amanifested effect, I crave but four days' respite;for the which you are to do me both a present and adangerous courtesy.

speaker: Provost
dialog: Pray, sir, in what?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: In the delaying death.

speaker: Provost
dialog: A lack, how may I do it, having the hour limited,and an express command, under penalty, to deliverhis head in the view of Angelo? I may make my caseas Claudio's, to cross this in the smallest.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: By the vow of mine order I warrant you, if myinstructions may be your guide. Let this Barnardinebe this morning executed, and his head born to Angelo.

speaker: Provost
dialog: Angelo hath seen them both, and will discover the favour.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: O, death's a great disguiser; and you may add to it.Shave the head, and tie the beard; and say it wasthe desire of the penitent to be so bared before hisdeath: you know the course is common. If any thingfall to you upon this, more than thanks and goodfortune, by the saint whom I profess, I will pleadagainst it with my life.

speaker: Provost
dialog: Pardon me, good father; it is against my oath.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Were you sworn to the duke, or to the deputy?

speaker: Provost
dialog: To him, and to his substitutes.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: You will think you have made no offence, if the dukeavouch the justice of your dealing?

speaker: Provost
dialog: But what likelihood is in that?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Not a resemblance, but a certainty. Yet since I seeyou fearful, that neither my coat, integrity, norpersuasion can with ease attempt you, I will gofurther than I meant, to pluck all fears out of you.Look you, sir, here is the hand and seal of theduke: you know the character, I doubt not; and thesignet is not strange to you.

speaker: Provost
dialog: I know them both.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: The contents of this is the return of the duke: youshall anon over-read it at your pleasure; where youshall find, within these two days he will be here.This is a thing that Angelo knows not; for he thisvery day receives letters of strange tenor;perchance of the duke's death; perchance enteringinto some monastery; but, by chance, nothing of whatis writ. Look, the unfolding star calls up theshepherd. Put not yourself into amazement how thesethings should be: all difficulties are but easywhen they are known. Call your executioner, and offwith Barnardine's head: I will give him a presentshrift and advise him for a better place. Yet youare amazed; but this shall absolutely resolve you.Come away; it is almost clear dawn.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: I am as well acquainted here as I was in our houseof profession: one would think it were MistressOverdone's own house, for here be many of her oldcustomers. First, here's young Master Rash; he's infor a commodity of brown paper and old ginger,ninescore and seventeen pounds; of which he madefive marks, ready money: marry, then ginger was notmuch in request, for the old women were all dead.Then is there here one Master Caper, at the suit ofMaster Three-pile the mercer, for some four suits ofpeach-coloured satin, which now peaches him abeggar. Then have we here young Dizy, and youngMaster Deep-vow, and Master Copperspur, and MasterStarve-lackey the rapier and dagger man, and youngDrop-heir that killed lusty Pudding, and MasterForthlight the tilter, and brave Master Shooty thegreat traveller, and wild Half-can that stabbedPots, and, I think, forty more; all great doers inour trade, and are now 'for the Lord's sake.'

speaker: ABHORSON
dialog: Sirrah, bring Barnardine hither.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Master Barnardine! you must rise and be hanged.Master Barnardine!

speaker: ABHORSON
dialog: What, ho, Barnardine!

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Pray, Master Barnardine, awake till you areexecuted, and sleep afterwards.

speaker: ABHORSON
dialog: Go in to him, and fetch him out.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: He is coming, sir, he is coming; I hear his straw rustle.

speaker: ABHORSON
dialog: Is the axe upon the block, sirrah?

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: Very ready, sir.

speaker: BARNARDINE
dialog: How now, Abhorson? what's the news with you?

speaker: ABHORSON
dialog: Truly, sir, I would desire you to clap into yourprayers; for, look you, the warrant's come.

speaker: BARNARDINE
dialog: You rogue, I have been drinking all night; I am notfitted for 't.

speaker: POMPEY
dialog: O, the better, sir; for he that drinks all night,and is hanged betimes in the morning, may sleep thesounder all the next day.

speaker: ABHORSON
dialog: Look you, sir; here comes your ghostly father: dowe jest now, think you?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Sir, induced by my charity, and hearing how hastilyyou are to depart, I am come to advise you, comfortyou and pray with you.

speaker: BARNARDINE
dialog: Friar, not I I have been drinking hard all night,and I will have more time to prepare me, or theyshall beat out my brains with billets: I will notconsent to die this day, that's certain.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: O, sir, you must: and therefore I beseech youLook forward on the journey you shall go.

speaker: BARNARDINE
dialog: I swear I will not die to-day for any man'spersuasion.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: But hear you.

speaker: BARNARDINE
dialog: Not a word: if you have any thing to say to me,come to my ward; for thence will not I to-day.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Unfit to live or die: O gravel heart!After him, fellows; bring him to the block.

speaker: Provost
dialog: Now, sir, how do you find the prisoner?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: A creature unprepared, unmeet for death;And to transport him in the mind he isWere damnable.

speaker: Provost
dialog: Here in the prison, father,There died this morning of a cruel feverOne Ragozine, a most notorious pirate,A man of Claudio's years; his beard and headJust of his colour. What if we do omitThis reprobate till he were well inclined;And satisfy the deputy with the visageOf Ragozine, more like to Claudio?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: O, 'tis an accident that heaven provides!Dispatch it presently; the hour draws onPrefix'd by Angelo: see this be done,And sent according to command; whiles IPersuade this rude wretch willingly to die.

speaker: Provost
dialog: This shall be done, good father, presently.But Barnardine must die this afternoon:And how shall we continue Claudio,To save me from the danger that might comeIf he were known alive?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Let this be done.Put them in secret holds, both Barnardine and Claudio:Ere twice the sun hath made his journal greetingTo the under generation, you shall findYour safety manifested.

speaker: Provost
dialog: I am your free dependant.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Quick, dispatch, and send the head to Angelo.Now will I write letters to Angelo,--The provost, he shall bear them, whose contentsShall witness to him I am near at home,And that, by great injunctions, I am boundTo enter publicly: him I'll desireTo meet me at the consecrated fountA league below the city; and from thence,By cold gradation and well-balanced form,We shall proceed with Angelo.

speaker: Provost
dialog: Here is the head; I'll carry it myself.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Convenient is it. Make a swift return;For I would commune with you of such thingsThat want no ear but yours.

speaker: Provost
dialog: I'll make all speed.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Ho, by your leave!

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Good morning to you, fair and gracious daughter.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: The better, given me by so holy a man.Hath yet the deputy sent my brother's pardon?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: He hath released him, Isabel, from the world:His head is off and sent to Angelo.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Nay, but it is not so.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: It is no other: show your wisdom, daughter,In your close patience.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: O, I will to him and pluck out his eyes!

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: You shall not be admitted to his sight.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Unhappy Claudio! wretched Isabel!Injurious world! most damned Angelo!

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: This nor hurts him nor profits you a jot;Forbear it therefore; give your cause to heaven.Mark what I say, which you shall findBy every syllable a faithful verity:The duke comes home to-morrow; nay, dry your eyes;One of our convent, and his confessor,Gives me this instance: already he hath carriedNotice to Escalus and Angelo,Who do prepare to meet him at the gates,There to give up their power. If you can, pace your wisdomIn that good path that I would wish it go,And you shall have your bosom on this wretch,Grace of the duke, revenges to your heart,And general honour.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: I am directed by you.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: This letter, then, to Friar Peter give;'Tis that he sent me of the duke's return:Say, by this token, I desire his companyAt Mariana's house to-night. Her cause and yoursI'll perfect him withal, and he shall bring youBefore the duke, and to the head of AngeloAccuse him home and home. For my poor self,I am combined by a sacred vowAnd shall be absent. Wend you with this letter:Command these fretting waters from your eyesWith a light heart; trust not my holy order,If I pervert your course. Who's here?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Good even. Friar, where's the provost?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Not within, sir.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: O pretty Isabella, I am pale at mine heart to seethine eyes so red: thou must be patient. I am fainto dine and sup with water and bran; I dare not formy head fill my belly; one fruitful meal would setme to 't. But they say the duke will be hereto-morrow. By my troth, Isabel, I loved thy brother:if the old fantastical duke of dark corners had beenat home, he had lived.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Sir, the duke is marvellous little beholding to yourreports; but the best is, he lives not in them.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Friar, thou knowest not the duke so well as I do:he's a better woodman than thou takest him for.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Well, you'll answer this one day. Fare ye well.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Nay, tarry; I'll go along with theeI can tell thee pretty tales of the duke.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: You have told me too many of him already, sir, ifthey be true; if not true, none were enough.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: I was once before him for getting a wench with child.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Did you such a thing?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Yes, marry, did I but I was fain to forswear it;they would else have married me to the rotten medlar.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Sir, your company is fairer than honest. Rest you well.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: By my troth, I'll go with thee to the lane's end:if bawdy talk offend you, we'll have very little ofit. Nay, friar, I am a kind of burr; I shall stick.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Every letter he hath writ hath disvouched other.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: In most uneven and distracted manner. His actionsshow much like to madness: pray heaven his wisdom benot tainted! And why meet him at the gates, andredeliver our authorities there

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: I guess not.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: And why should we proclaim it in an hour before hisentering, that if any crave redress of injustice,they should exhibit their petitions in the street?

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: He shows his reason for that: to have a dispatch ofcomplaints, and to deliver us from deviceshereafter, which shall then have no power to standagainst us.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Well, I beseech you, let it be proclaimed betimesi' the morn; I'll call you at your house: givenotice to such men of sort and suit as are to meethim.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: I shall, sir. Fare you well.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Good night.This deed unshapes me quite, makes me unpregnantAnd dull to all proceedings. A deflower'd maid!And by an eminent body that enforcedThe law against it! But that her tender shameWill not proclaim against her maiden loss,How might she tongue me! Yet reason dares her no;For my authority bears of a credent bulk,That no particular scandal once can touchBut it confounds the breather. He should have lived,Save that riotous youth, with dangerous sense,Might in the times to come have ta'en revenge,By so receiving a dishonour'd lifeWith ransom of such shame. Would yet he had lived!A lack, when once our grace we have forgot,Nothing goes right: we would, and we would not.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: These letters at fit time deliver meThe provost knows our purpose and our plot.The matter being afoot, keep your instruction,And hold you ever to our special drift;Though sometimes you do blench from this to that,As cause doth minister. Go call at Flavius' house,And tell him where I stay: give the like noticeTo Valentinus, Rowland, and to Crassus,And bid them bring the trumpets to the gate;But send me Flavius first.

speaker: FRIAR PETER
dialog: It shall be speeded well.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: I thank thee, Varrius; thou hast made good haste:Come, we will walk. There's other of our friendsWill greet us here anon, my gentle Varrius.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: To speak so indirectly I am loath:I would say the truth; but to accuse him so,That is your part: yet I am advised to do it;He says, to veil full purpose.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: Be ruled by him.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Besides, he tells me that, if peradventureHe speak against me on the adverse side,I should not think it strange; for 'tis a physicThat's bitter to sweet end.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: I would Friar Peter--

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: O, peace! the friar is come.

speaker: FRIAR PETER
dialog: Come, I have found you out a stand most fit,Where you may have such vantage on the duke,He shall not pass you. Twice have the trumpets sounded;The generous and gravest citizensHave hent the gates, and very near uponThe duke is entering: therefore, hence, away!

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: My very worthy cousin, fairly met!Our old and faithful friend, we are glad to see you.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Happy return be to your royal grace!

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Many and hearty thankings to you both.We have made inquiry of you; and we hearSuch goodness of your justice, that our soulCannot but yield you forth to public thanks,Forerunning more requital.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: You make my bonds still greater.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: O, your desert speaks loud; and I should wrong it,To lock it in the wards of covert bosom,When it deserves, with characters of brass,A forted residence 'gainst the tooth of timeAnd razure of oblivion. Give me your hand,And let the subject see, to make them knowThat outward courtesies would fain proclaimFavours that keep within. Come, Escalus,You must walk by us on our other hand;And good supporters are you.

speaker: FRIAR PETER
dialog: Now is your time: speak loud and kneel before him.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Justice, O royal duke! Vail your regardUpon a wrong'd, I would fain have said, a maid!O worthy prince, dishonour not your eyeBy throwing it on any other objectTill you have heard me in my true complaintAnd given me justice, justice, justice, justice!

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Relate your wrongs; in what? by whom? be brief.Here is Lord Angelo shall give you justice:Reveal yourself to him.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: O worthy duke,You bid me seek redemption of the devil:Hear me yourself; for that which I must speakMust either punish me, not being believed,Or wring redress from you. Hear me, O hear me, here!

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: My lord, her wits, I fear me, are not firm:She hath been a suitor to me for her brotherCut off by course of justice,--

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: By course of justice!

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: And she will speak most bitterly and strange.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Most strange, but yet most truly, will I speak:That Angelo's forsworn; is it not strange?That Angelo's a murderer; is 't not strange?That Angelo is an adulterous thief,An hypocrite, a virgin-violator;Is it not strange and strange?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Nay, it is ten times strange.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: It is not truer he is AngeloThan this is all as true as it is strange:Nay, it is ten times true; for truth is truthTo the end of reckoning.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Away with her! Poor soul,She speaks this in the infirmity of sense.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: O prince, I conjure thee, as thou believestThere is another comfort than this world,That thou neglect me not, with that opinionThat I am touch'd with madness! Make not impossibleThat which but seems unlike: 'tis not impossibleBut one, the wicked'st caitiff on the ground,May seem as shy, as grave, as just, as absoluteAs Angelo; even so may Angelo,In all his dressings, characts, titles, forms,Be an arch-villain; believe it, royal prince:If he be less, he's nothing; but he's more,Had I more name for badness.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: By mine honesty,If she be mad,--as I believe no other,--Her madness hath the oddest frame of sense,Such a dependency of thing on thing,As e'er I heard in madness.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: O gracious duke,Harp not on that, nor do not banish reasonFor inequality; but let your reason serveTo make the truth appear where it seems hid,And hide the false seems true.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Many that are not madHave, sure, more lack of reason. What would you say?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: I am the sister of one Claudio,Condemn'd upon the act of fornicationTo lose his head; condemn'd by Angelo:I, in probation of a sisterhood,Was sent to by my brother; one LucioAs then the messenger,--

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: That's I, an't like your grace:I came to her from Claudio, and desired herTo try her gracious fortune with Lord AngeloFor her poor brother's pardon.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: That's he indeed.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: You were not bid to speak.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: No, my good lord;Nor wish'd to hold my peace.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: I wish you now, then;Pray you, take note of it: and when you haveA business for yourself, pray heaven you thenBe perfect.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: I warrant your honour.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: The warrants for yourself; take heed to't.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: This gentleman told somewhat of my tale,--

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Right.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: It may be right; but you are i' the wrongTo speak before your time. Proceed.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: I wentTo this pernicious caitiff deputy,--

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: That's somewhat madly spoken.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Pardon it;The phrase is to the matter.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Mended again. The matter; proceed.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: In brief, to set the needless process by,How I persuaded, how I pray'd, and kneel'd,How he refell'd me, and how I replied,--For this was of much length,--the vile conclusionI now begin with grief and shame to utter:He would not, but by gift of my chaste bodyTo his concupiscible intemperate lust,Release my brother; and, after much debatement,My sisterly remorse confutes mine honour,And I did yield to him: but the next morn betimes,His purpose surfeiting, he sends a warrantFor my poor brother's head.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: This is most likely!

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: O, that it were as like as it is true!

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: By heaven, fond wretch, thou knowist not what thou speak'st,Or else thou art suborn'd against his honourIn hateful practise. First, his integrityStands without blemish. Next, it imports no reasonThat with such vehemency he should pursueFaults proper to himself: if he had so offended,He would have weigh'd thy brother by himselfAnd not have cut him off. Some one hath set you on:Confess the truth, and say by whose adviceThou camest here to complain.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: And is this all?Then, O you blessed ministers above,Keep me in patience, and with ripen'd timeUnfold the evil which is here wrapt upIn countenance! Heaven shield your grace from woe,As I, thus wrong'd, hence unbelieved go!

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: I know you'ld fain be gone. An officer!To prison with her! Shall we thus permitA blasting and a scandalous breath to fallOn him so near us? This needs must be a practise.Who knew of Your intent and coming hither?

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: One that I would were here, Friar Lodowick.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: A ghostly father, belike. Who knows that Lodowick?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: My lord, I know him; 'tis a meddling friar;I do not like the man: had he been lay, my lordFor certain words he spake against your graceIn your retirement, I had swinged him soundly.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Words against me? this is a good friar, belike!And to set on this wretched woman hereAgainst our substitute! Let this friar be found.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: But yesternight, my lord, she and that friar,I saw them at the prison: a saucy friar,A very scurvy fellow.

speaker: FRIAR PETER
dialog: Blessed be your royal grace!I have stood by, my lord, and I have heardYour royal ear abused. First, hath this womanMost wrongfully accused your substitute,Who is as free from touch or soil with herAs she from one ungot.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: We did believe no less.Know you that Friar Lodowick that she speaks of?

speaker: FRIAR PETER
dialog: I know him for a man divine and holy;Not scurvy, nor a temporary meddler,As he's reported by this gentleman;And, on my trust, a man that never yetDid, as he vouches, misreport your grace.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: My lord, most villanously; believe it.

speaker: FRIAR PETER
dialog: Well, he in time may come to clear himself;But at this instant he is sick my lord,Of a strange fever. Upon his mere request,Being come to knowledge that there was complaintIntended 'gainst Lord Angelo, came I hither,To speak, as from his mouth, what he doth knowIs true and false; and what he with his oathAnd all probation will make up full clear,Whensoever he's convented. First, for this woman.To justify this worthy nobleman,So vulgarly and personally accused,Her shall you hear disproved to her eyes,Till she herself confess it.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Good friar, let's hear it.Do you not smile at this, Lord Angelo?O heaven, the vanity of wretched fools!Give us some seats. Come, cousin Angelo;In this I'll be impartial; be you judgeOf your own cause. Is this the witness, friar?First, let her show her face, and after speak.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: Pardon, my lord; I will not show my faceUntil my husband bid me.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: What, are you married?

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: No, my lord.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Are you a maid?

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: No, my lord.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: A widow, then?

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: Neither, my lord.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Why, you are nothing then: neither maid, widow, nor wife?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: My lord, she may be a punk; for many of them areneither maid, widow, nor wife.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Silence that fellow: I would he had some causeTo prattle for himself.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Well, my lord.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: My lord; I do confess I ne'er was married;And I confess besides I am no maid:I have known my husband; yet my husbandKnows not that ever he knew me.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: He was drunk then, my lord: it can be no better.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: For the benefit of silence, would thou wert so too!

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Well, my lord.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: This is no witness for Lord Angelo.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: Now I come to't my lordShe that accuses him of fornication,In self-same manner doth accuse my husband,And charges him my lord, with such a timeWhen I'll depose I had him in mine armsWith all the effect of love.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Charges she more than me?

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: Not that I know.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: No? you say your husband.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: Why, just, my lord, and that is Angelo,Who thinks he knows that he ne'er knew my body,But knows he thinks that he knows Isabel's.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: This is a strange abuse. Let's see thy face.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: My husband bids me; now I will unmask.This is that face, thou cruel Angelo,Which once thou sworest was worth the looking on;This is the hand which, with a vow'd contract,Was fast belock'd in thine; this is the bodyThat took away the match from Isabel,And did supply thee at thy garden-houseIn her imagined person.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Know you this woman?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Carnally, she says.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Sirrah, no more!

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Enough, my lord.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: My lord, I must confess I know this woman:And five years since there was some speech of marriageBetwixt myself and her; which was broke off,Partly for that her promised proportionsCame short of composition, but in chiefFor that her reputation was disvaluedIn levity: since which time of five yearsI never spake with her, saw her, nor heard from her,Upon my faith and honour.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: Noble prince,As there comes light from heaven and words from breath,As there is sense in truth and truth in virtue,I am affianced this man's wife as stronglyAs words could make up vows: and, my good lord,But Tuesday night last gone in's garden-houseHe knew me as a wife. As this is true,Let me in safety raise me from my kneesOr else for ever be confixed here,A marble monument!

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: I did but smile till now:Now, good my lord, give me the scope of justiceMy patience here is touch'd. I do perceiveThese poor informal women are no moreBut instruments of some more mightier memberThat sets them on: let me have way, my lord,To find this practise out.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Ay, with my heartAnd punish them to your height of pleasure.Thou foolish friar, and thou pernicious woman,Compact with her that's gone, think'st thou thy oaths,Though they would swear down each particular saint,Were testimonies against his worth and creditThat's seal'd in approbation? You, Lord Escalus,Sit with my cousin; lend him your kind painsTo find out this abuse, whence 'tis derived.There is another friar that set them on;Let him be sent for.

speaker: FRIAR PETER
dialog: Would he were here, my lord! for he indeedHath set the women on to this complaint:Your provost knows the place where he abidesAnd he may fetch him.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Go do it instantly.And you, my noble and well-warranted cousin,Whom it concerns to hear this matter forth,Do with your injuries as seems you best,In any chastisement: I for a while will leave you;But stir not you till you have well determinedUpon these slanderers.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: My lord, we'll do it throughly.Signior Lucio, did not you say you knew thatFriar Lodowick to be a dishonest person?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: 'Cucullus non facit monachum:' honest in nothingbut in his clothes; and one that hath spoke mostvillanous speeches of the duke.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: We shall entreat you to abide here till he come andenforce them against him: we shall find this friar anotable fellow.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: As any in Vienna, on my word.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Call that same Isabel here once again; I would speak with her.Pray you, my lord, give me leave to question; youshall see how I'll handle her.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Not better than he, by her own report.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Say you?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Marry, sir, I think, if you handled her privately,she would sooner confess: perchance, publicly,she'll be ashamed.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: I will go darkly to work with her.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: That's the way; for women are light at midnight.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Come on, mistress: here's a gentlewoman denies allthat you have said.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: My lord, here comes the rascal I spoke of; here withthe provost.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: In very good time: speak not you to him till wecall upon you.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Mum.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Come, sir: did you set these women on to slanderLord Angelo? they have confessed you did.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: 'Tis false.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: How! know you where you are?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Respect to your great place! and let the devilBe sometime honour'd for his burning throne!Where is the duke? 'tis he should hear me speak.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: The duke's in us; and we will hear you speak:Look you speak justly.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Boldly, at least. But, O, poor souls,Come you to seek the lamb here of the fox?Good night to your redress! Is the duke gone?Then is your cause gone too. The duke's unjust,Thus to retort your manifest appeal,And put your trial in the villain's mouthWhich here you come to accuse.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: This is the rascal; this is he I spoke of.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Why, thou unreverend and unhallow'd friar,Is't not enough thou hast suborn'd these womenTo accuse this worthy man, but, in foul mouthAnd in the witness of his proper ear,To call him villain? and then to glance from himTo the duke himself, to tax him with injustice?Take him hence; to the rack with him! We'll touse youJoint by joint, but we will know his purpose.What 'unjust'!

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Be not so hot; the dukeDare no more stretch this finger of mine than heDare rack his own: his subject am I not,Nor here provincial. My business in this stateMade me a looker on here in Vienna,Where I have seen corruption boil and bubbleTill it o'er-run the stew; laws for all faults,But faults so countenanced, that the strong statutesStand like the forfeits in a barber's shop,As much in mock as mark.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Slander to the state! Away with him to prison!

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: What can you vouch against him, Signior Lucio?Is this the man that you did tell us of?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: 'Tis he, my lord. Come hither, goodman baldpate:do you know me?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: I remember you, sir, by the sound of your voice: Imet you at the prison, in the absence of the duke.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: O, did you so? And do you remember what you said of the duke?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Most notedly, sir.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Do you so, sir? And was the duke a fleshmonger, afool, and a coward, as you then reported him to be?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: You must, sir, change persons with me, ere you makethat my report: you, indeed, spoke so of him; andmuch more, much worse.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: O thou damnable fellow! Did not I pluck thee by thenose for thy speeches?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: I protest I love the duke as I love myself.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: Hark, how the villain would close now, after histreasonable abuses!

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: Such a fellow is not to be talked withal. Away withhim to prison! Where is the provost? Away with himto prison! lay bolts enough upon him: let himspeak no more. Away with those giglots too, andwith the other confederate companion!

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Come, sir; come, sir; come, sir; foh, sir! Why, youbald-pated, lying rascal, you must be hooded, mustyou? Show your knave's visage, with a pox to you!show your sheep-biting face, and be hanged an hour!Will't not off?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Thou art the first knave that e'er madest a duke.First, provost, let me bail these gentle three.Sneak not away, sir; for the friar and youMust have a word anon. Lay hold on him.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: O my dread lord,I should be guiltier than my guiltiness,To think I can be undiscernible,When I perceive your grace, like power divine,Hath look'd upon my passes. Then, good prince,No longer session hold upon my shame,But let my trial be mine own confession:Immediate sentence then and sequent deathIs all the grace I beg.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Come hither, Mariana.Say, wast thou e'er contracted to this woman?

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: I was, my lord.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Go take her hence, and marry her instantly.Do you the office, friar; which consummate,Return him here again. Go with him, provost.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: My lord, I am more amazed at his dishonourThan at the strangeness of it.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Come hither, Isabel.Your friar is now your prince: as I was thenAdvertising and holy to your business,Not changing heart with habit, I am stillAttorney'd at your service.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: O, give me pardon,That I, your vassal, have employ'd and pain'dYour unknown sovereignty!

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: You are pardon'd, Isabel:And now, dear maid, be you as free to us.Your brother's death, I know, sits at your heart;And you may marvel why I obscured myself,Labouring to save his life, and would not ratherMake rash remonstrance of my hidden powerThan let him so be lost. O most kind maid,It was the swift celerity of his death,Which I did think with slower foot came on,That brain'd my purpose. But, peace be with him!That life is better life, past fearing death,Than that which lives to fear: make it your comfort,So happy is your brother.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: I do, my lord.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: For this new-married man approaching here,Whose salt imagination yet hath wrong'dYour well defended honour, you must pardonFor Mariana's sake: but as he adjudged your brother,--Being criminal, in double violationOf sacred chastity and of promise-breachThereon dependent, for your brother's life,--The very mercy of the law cries outMost audible, even from his proper tongue,'An Angelo for Claudio, death for death!'Haste still pays haste, and leisure answers leisure;Like doth quit like, and MEASURE still FOR MEASURE.Then, Angelo, thy fault's thus manifested;Which, though thou wouldst deny, denies thee vantage.We do condemn thee to the very blockWhere Claudio stoop'd to death, and with like haste.Away with him!

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: O my most gracious lord,I hope you will not mock me with a husband.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: It is your husband mock'd you with a husband.Consenting to the safeguard of your honour,I thought your marriage fit; else imputation,For that he knew you, might reproach your lifeAnd choke your good to come; for his possessions,Although by confiscation they are ours,We do instate and widow you withal,To buy you a better husband.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: O my dear lord,I crave no other, nor no better man.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Never crave him; we are definitive.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: Gentle my liege,--

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: You do but lose your labour.Away with him to death!Now, sir, to you.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: O my good lord! Sweet Isabel, take my part;Lend me your knees, and all my life to comeI'll lend you all my life to do you service.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Against all sense you do importune her:Should she kneel down in mercy of this fact,Her brother's ghost his paved bed would break,And take her hence in horror.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: Isabel,Sweet Isabel, do yet but kneel by me;Hold up your hands, say nothing; I'll speak all.They say, best men are moulded out of faults;And, for the most, become much more the betterFor being a little bad: so may my husband.O Isabel, will you not lend a knee?

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: He dies for Claudio's death.

speaker: ISABELLA
dialog: Most bounteous sir,Look, if it please you, on this man condemn'd,As if my brother lived: I partly thinkA due sincerity govern'd his deeds,Till he did look on me: since it is so,Let him not die. My brother had but justice,In that he did the thing for which he died:For Angelo,His act did not o'ertake his bad intent,And must be buried but as an intentThat perish'd by the way: thoughts are no subjects;Intents but merely thoughts.

speaker: MARIANA
dialog: Merely, my lord.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Your suit's unprofitable; stand up, I say.I have bethought me of another fault.Provost, how came it Claudio was beheadedAt an unusual hour?

speaker: Provost
dialog: It was commanded so.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Had you a special warrant for the deed?

speaker: Provost
dialog: No, my good lord; it was by private message.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: For which I do discharge you of your office:Give up your keys.

speaker: Provost
dialog: Pardon me, noble lord:I thought it was a fault, but knew it not;Yet did repent me, after more advice;For testimony whereof, one in the prison,That should by private order else have died,I have reserved alive.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: What's he?

speaker: Provost
dialog: His name is Barnardine.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: I would thou hadst done so by Claudio.Go fetch him hither; let me look upon him.

speaker: ESCALUS
dialog: I am sorry, one so learned and so wiseAs you, Lord Angelo, have still appear'd,Should slip so grossly, both in the heat of blood.And lack of temper'd judgment afterward.

speaker: ANGELO
dialog: I am sorry that such sorrow I procure:And so deep sticks it in my penitent heartThat I crave death more willingly than mercy;'Tis my deserving, and I do entreat it.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Which is that Barnardine?

speaker: Provost
dialog: This, my lord.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: There was a friar told me of this man.Sirrah, thou art said to have a stubborn soul.That apprehends no further than this world,And squarest thy life according. Thou'rt condemn'd:But, for those earthly faults, I quit them all;And pray thee take this mercy to provideFor better times to come. Friar, advise him;I leave him to your hand. What muffled fellow's that?

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: 'Faith, my lord. I spoke it but according to thetrick. If you will hang me for it, you may; but Ihad rather it would please you I might be whipt.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Whipt first, sir, and hanged after.Proclaim it, provost, round about the city.Is any woman wrong'd by this lewd fellow,As I have heard him swear himself there's oneWhom he begot with child, let her appear,And he shall marry her: the nuptial finish'd,Let him be whipt and hang'd.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: I beseech your highness, do not marry me to a whore.Your highness said even now, I made you a duke:good my lord, do not recompense me in making me a cuckold.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Upon mine honour, thou shalt marry her.Thy slanders I forgive; and therewithalRemit thy other forfeits. Take him to prison;And see our pleasure herein executed.

speaker: LUCIO
dialog: Marrying a punk, my lord, is pressing to death,whipping, and hanging.

speaker: DUKE VINCENTIO
dialog: Slandering a prince deserves it.She, Claudio, that you wrong'd, look you restore.Joy to you, Mariana! Love her, Angelo:I have confess'd her and I know her virtue.Thanks, good friend Escalus, for thy much goodness:There's more behind that is more gratulate.Thanks, provost, for thy care and secrecy:We shill employ thee in a worthier place.Forgive him, Angelo, that brought you homeThe head of Ragozine for Claudio's:The offence pardons itself. Dear Isabel,I have a motion much imports your good;Whereto if you'll a willing ear incline,What's mine is yours and what is yours is mine.So, bring us to our palace; where we'll showWhat's yet behind, that's meet you all should know.

speaker: SLY
dialog: I'll pheeze you, in faith.

speaker: Hostess
dialog: A pair of stocks, you rogue!

speaker: SLY
dialog: Ye are a baggage: the Slys are no rogues; look inthe chronicles; we came in with Richard Conqueror.Therefore paucas pallabris; let the world slide: sessa!

speaker: Hostess
dialog: You will not pay for the glasses you have burst?

speaker: SLY
dialog: No, not a denier. Go by, Jeronimy: go to thy coldbed, and warm thee.

speaker: Hostess
dialog: I know my remedy; I must go fetch thethird--borough.

speaker: SLY
dialog: Third, or fourth, or fifth borough, I'll answer himby law: I'll not budge an inch, boy: let him come,and kindly.

speaker: Lord
dialog: Huntsman, I charge thee, tender well my hounds:Brach Merriman, the poor cur is emboss'd;And couple Clowder with the deep--mouth'd brach.Saw'st thou not, boy, how Silver made it goodAt the hedge-corner, in the coldest fault?I would not lose the dog for twenty pound.

speaker: First Huntsman
dialog: Why, Belman is as good as he, my lord;He cried upon it at the merest lossAnd twice to-day pick'd out the dullest scent:Trust me, I take him for the better dog.

speaker: Lord
dialog: Thou art a fool: if Echo were as fleet,I would esteem him worth a dozen such.But sup them well and look unto them all:To-morrow I intend to hunt again.

speaker: First Huntsman
dialog: I will, my lord.

speaker: Lord
dialog: What's here? one dead, or drunk? See, doth he breathe?

speaker: Second Huntsman
dialog: He breathes, my lord. Were he not warm'd with ale,This were a bed but cold to sleep so soundly.

speaker: Lord
dialog: O monstrous beast! how like a swine he lies!Grim death, how foul and loathsome is thine image!Sirs, I will practise on this drunken man.What think you, if he were convey'd to bed,Wrapp'd in sweet clothes, rings put upon his fingers,A most delicious banquet by his bed,And brave attendants near him when he wakes,Would not the beggar then forget himself?

speaker: First Huntsman
dialog: Believe me, lord, I think he cannot choose.

speaker: Second Huntsman
dialog: It would seem strange unto him when he waked.

speaker: Lord
dialog: Even as a flattering dream or worthless fancy.Then take him up and manage well the jest:Carry him gently to my fairest chamberAnd hang it round with all my wanton pictures:Balm his foul head in warm distilled watersAnd burn sweet wood to make the lodging sweet:Procure me music ready when he wakes,To make a dulcet and a heavenly sound;And if he chance to speak, be ready straightAnd with a low submissive reverenceSay 'What is it your honour will command?'Let one attend him with a silver basinFull of rose-water and bestrew'd with flowers,Another bear the ewer, the third a diaper,And say 'Will't please your lordship cool your hands?'Some one be ready with a costly suitAnd ask him what apparel he will wear;Another tell him of his hounds and horse,And that his lady mourns at his disease:Persuade him that he hath been lunatic;And when he says he is, say that he dreams,For he is nothing but a mighty lord.This do and do it kindly, gentle sirs:It will be pastime passing excellent,If it be husbanded with modesty.

speaker: First Huntsman
dialog: My lord, I warrant you we will play our part,As he shall think by our true diligenceHe is no less than what we say he is.

speaker: Lord
dialog: Take him up gently and to bed with him;And each one to his office when he wakes.Sirrah, go see what trumpet 'tis that sounds:Belike, some noble gentleman that means,Travelling some journey, to repose him here.How now! who is it?

speaker: Servant
dialog: An't please your honour, playersThat offer service to your lordship.

speaker: Lord
dialog: Bid them come near.Now, fellows, you are welcome.

speaker: Players
dialog: We thank your honour.

speaker: Lord
dialog: Do you intend to stay with me tonight?

speaker: A Player
dialog: So please your lordship to accept our duty.

speaker: Lord
dialog: With all my heart. This fellow I remember,Since once he play'd a farmer's eldest son:'Twas where you woo'd the gentlewoman so well:I have forgot your name; but, sure, that partWas aptly fitted and naturally perform'd.

speaker: A Player
dialog: I think 'twas Soto that your honour means.

speaker: Lord
dialog: 'Tis very true: thou didst it excellent.Well, you are come to me in a happy time;The rather for I have some sport in handWherein your cunning can assist me much.There is a lord will hear you play to-night:But I am doubtful of your modesties;Lest over-eyeing of his odd behavior,--For yet his honour never heard a play--You break into some merry passionAnd so offend him; for I tell you, sirs,If you should smile he grows impatient.

speaker: A Player
dialog: Fear not, my lord: we can contain ourselves,Were he the veriest antic in the world.

speaker: Lord
dialog: Go, sirrah, take them to the buttery,And give them friendly welcome every one:Let them want nothing that my house affords.Sirrah, go you to Barthol'mew my page,And see him dress'd in all suits like a lady:That done, conduct him to the drunkard's chamber;And call him 'madam,' do him obeisance.Tell him from me, as he will win my love,He bear himself with honourable action,Such as he hath observed in noble ladiesUnto their lords, by them accomplished:Such duty to the drunkard let him doWith soft low tongue and lowly courtesy,And say 'What is't your honour will command,Wherein your lady and your humble wifeMay show her duty and make known her love?'And then with kind embracements, tempting kisses,And with declining head into his bosom,Bid him shed tears, as being overjoy'dTo see her noble lord restored to health,Who for this seven years hath esteem'd himNo better than a poor and loathsome beggar:And if the boy have not a woman's giftTo rain a shower of commanded tears,An onion will do well for such a shift,Which in a napkin being close convey'dShall in despite enforce a watery eye.See this dispatch'd with all the haste thou canst:Anon I'll give thee more instructions.I know the boy will well usurp the grace,Voice, gait and action of a gentlewoman:I long to hear him call the drunkard husband,And how my men will stay themselves from laughterWhen they do homage to this simple peasant.I'll in to counsel them; haply my presenceMay well abate the over-merry spleenWhich otherwise would grow into extremes.

speaker: SLY
dialog: For God's sake, a pot of small ale.

speaker: First Servant
dialog: Will't please your lordship drink a cup of sack?

speaker: Second Servant
dialog: Will't please your honour taste of these conserves?

speaker: Third Servant
dialog: What raiment will your honour wear to-day?

speaker: SLY
dialog: I am Christophero Sly; call not me 'honour' nor'lordship:' I ne'er drank sack in my life; and ifyou give me any conserves, give me conserves ofbeef: ne'er ask me what raiment I'll wear; for Ihave no more doublets than backs, no more stockingsthan legs, nor no more shoes than feet; nay,sometimes more feet than shoes, or such shoes as mytoes look through the over-leather.

speaker: Lord
dialog: Heaven cease this idle humour in your honour!O, that a mighty man of such descent,Of such possessions and so high esteem,Should be infused with so foul a spirit!

speaker: SLY
dialog: What, would you make me mad? Am not I ChristopherSly, old Sly's son of Burtonheath, by birth apedlar, by education a cardmaker, by transmutation abear-herd, and now by present profession a tinker?Ask Marian Hacket, the fat ale-wife of Wincot, ifshe know me not: if she say I am not fourteen penceon the score for sheer ale, score me up for thelyingest knave in Christendom. What! I am notbestraught: here's--

speaker: Third Servant
dialog: O, this it is that makes your lady mourn!

speaker: Second Servant
dialog: O, this is it that makes your servants droop!

speaker: Lord
dialog: Hence comes it that your kindred shuns your house,As beaten hence by your strange lunacy.O noble lord, bethink thee of thy birth,Call home thy ancient thoughts from banishmentAnd banish hence these abject lowly dreams.Look how thy servants do attend on thee,Each in his office ready at thy beck.Wilt thou have music? hark! Apollo plays,And twenty caged nightingales do sing:Or wilt thou sleep? we'll have thee to a couchSofter and sweeter than the lustful bedOn purpose trimm'd up for Semiramis.Say thou wilt walk; we will bestrew the ground:Or wilt thou ride? thy horses shall be trapp'd,Their harness studded all with gold and pearl.Dost thou love hawking? thou hast hawks will soarAbove the morning lark or wilt thou hunt?Thy hounds shall make the welkin answer themAnd fetch shrill echoes from the hollow earth.

speaker: First Servant
dialog: Say thou wilt course; thy greyhounds are as swiftAs breathed stags, ay, fleeter than the roe.

speaker: Second Servant
dialog: Dost thou love pictures? we will fetch thee straightAdonis painted by a running brook,And Cytherea all in sedges hid,Which seem to move and wanton with her breath,Even as the waving sedges play with wind.

speaker: Lord
dialog: We'll show thee Io as she was a maid,And how she was beguiled and surprised,As lively painted as the deed was done.

speaker: Third Servant
dialog: Or Daphne roaming through a thorny wood,Scratching her legs that one shall swear she bleeds,And at that sight shall sad Apollo weep,So workmanly the blood and tears are drawn.

speaker: Lord
dialog: Thou art a lord, and nothing but a lord:Thou hast a lady far more beautifulThan any woman in this waning age.

speaker: First Servant
dialog: And till the tears that she hath shed for theeLike envious floods o'er-run her lovely face,She was the fairest creature in the world;And yet she is inferior to none.

speaker: SLY
dialog: Am I a lord? and have I such a lady?Or do I dream? or have I dream'd till now?I do not sleep: I see, I hear, I speak;I smell sweet savours and I feel soft things:Upon my life, I am a lord indeedAnd not a tinker nor Christophero Sly.Well, bring our lady hither to our sight;And once again, a pot o' the smallest ale.

speaker: Second Servant
