dialog: Will't please your mightiness to wash your hands?O, how we joy to see your wit restored!O, that once more you knew but what you are!These fifteen years you have been in a dream;Or when you waked, so waked as if you slept.

speaker: SLY
dialog: These fifteen years! by my fay, a goodly nap.But did I never speak of all that time?

speaker: First Servant
dialog: O, yes, my lord, but very idle words:For though you lay here in this goodly chamber,Yet would you say ye were beaten out of door;And rail upon the hostess of the house;And say you would present her at the leet,Because she brought stone jugs and no seal'd quarts:Sometimes you would call out for Cicely Hacket.

speaker: SLY
dialog: Ay, the woman's maid of the house.

speaker: Third Servant
dialog: Why, sir, you know no house nor no such maid,Nor no such men as you have reckon'd up,As Stephen Sly and did John Naps of GreeceAnd Peter Turph and Henry PimpernellAnd twenty more such names and men as theseWhich never were nor no man ever saw.

speaker: SLY
dialog: Now Lord be thanked for my good amends!

speaker: ALL
dialog: Amen.

speaker: SLY
dialog: I thank thee: thou shalt not lose by it.

speaker: Page
dialog: How fares my noble lord?

speaker: SLY
dialog: Marry, I fare well for here is cheer enough.Where is my wife?

speaker: Page
dialog: Here, noble lord: what is thy will with her?

speaker: SLY
dialog: Are you my wife and will not call me husband?My men should call me 'lord:' I am your goodman.

speaker: Page
dialog: My husband and my lord, my lord and husband;I am your wife in all obedience.

speaker: SLY
dialog: I know it well. What must I call her?

speaker: Lord
dialog: Madam.

speaker: SLY
dialog: Al'ce madam, or Joan madam?

speaker: Lord
dialog: 'Madam,' and nothing else: so lordscall ladies.

speaker: SLY
dialog: Madam wife, they say that I have dream'dAnd slept above some fifteen year or more.

speaker: Page
dialog: Ay, and the time seems thirty unto me,Being all this time abandon'd from your bed.

speaker: SLY
dialog: 'Tis much. Servants, leave me and her alone.Madam, undress you and come now to bed.

speaker: Page
dialog: Thrice noble lord, let me entreat of youTo pardon me yet for a night or two,Or, if not so, until the sun be set:For your physicians have expressly charged,In peril to incur your former malady,That I should yet absent me from your bed:I hope this reason stands for my excuse.

speaker: SLY
dialog: Ay, it stands so that I may hardlytarry so long. But I would be loath to fall intomy dreams again: I will therefore tarry indespite of the flesh and the blood.

speaker: Messenger
dialog: Your honour's players, heating your amendment,Are come to play a pleasant comedy;For so your doctors hold it very meet,Seeing too much sadness hath congeal'd your blood,And melancholy is the nurse of frenzy:Therefore they thought it good you hear a playAnd frame your mind to mirth and merriment,Which bars a thousand harms and lengthens life.

speaker: SLY
dialog: Marry, I will, let them play it. Is not acomondy a Christmas gambold or a tumbling-trick?

speaker: Page
dialog: No, my good lord; it is more pleasing stuff.

speaker: SLY
dialog: What, household stuff?

speaker: Page
dialog: It is a kind of history.

speaker: SLY
dialog: Well, well see't. Come, madam wife, sit by my sideand let the world slip: we shall ne'er be younger.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Tranio, since for the great desire I hadTo see fair Padua, nursery of arts,I am arrived for fruitful Lombardy,The pleasant garden of great Italy;And by my father's love and leave am arm'dWith his good will and thy good company,My trusty servant, well approved in all,Here let us breathe and haply instituteA course of learning and ingenious studies.Pisa renown'd for grave citizensGave me my being and my father first,A merchant of great traffic through the world,Vincetino come of Bentivolii.Vincetino's son brought up in FlorenceIt shall become to serve all hopes conceived,To deck his fortune with his virtuous deeds:And therefore, Tranio, for the time I study,Virtue and that part of philosophyWill I apply that treats of happinessBy virtue specially to be achieved.Tell me thy mind; for I have Pisa leftAnd am to Padua come, as he that leavesA shallow plash to plunge him in the deepAnd with satiety seeks to quench his thirst.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Mi perdonato, gentle master mine,I am in all affected as yourself;Glad that you thus continue your resolveTo suck the sweets of sweet philosophy.Only, good master, while we do admireThis virtue and this moral discipline,Let's be no stoics nor no stocks, I pray;Or so devote to Aristotle's chequesAs Ovid be an outcast quite abjured:Balk logic with acquaintance that you haveAnd practise rhetoric in your common talk;Music and poesy use to quicken you;The mathematics and the metaphysics,Fall to them as you find your stomach serves you;No profit grows where is no pleasure ta'en:In brief, sir, study what you most affect.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Gramercies, Tranio, well dost thou advise.If, Biondello, thou wert come ashore,We could at once put us in readiness,And take a lodging fit to entertainSuch friends as time in Padua shall beget.But stay a while: what company is this?

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Master, some show to welcome us to town.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: I pray you, sir, is it your willTo make a stale of me amongst these mates?

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Mates, maid! how mean you that? no mates for you,Unless you were of gentler, milder mould.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: I'faith, sir, you shall never need to fear:I wis it is not half way to her heart;But if it were, doubt not her care should beTo comb your noddle with a three-legg'd stoolAnd paint your face and use you like a fool.

speaker: HORTENSIA
dialog: From all such devils, good Lord deliver us!

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: And me too, good Lord!

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Hush, master! here's some good pastime toward:That wench is stark mad or wonderful froward.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: But in the other's silence do I seeMaid's mild behavior and sobriety.Peace, Tranio!

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Well said, master; mum! and gaze your fill.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Gentlemen, that I may soon make goodWhat I have said, Bianca, get you in:And let it not displease thee, good Bianca,For I will love thee ne'er the less, my girl.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: A pretty peat! it is bestPut finger in the eye, an she knew why.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Sister, content you in my discontent.Sir, to your pleasure humbly I subscribe:My books and instruments shall be my company,On them to took and practise by myself.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Hark, Tranio! thou may'st hear Minerva speak.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Signior Baptista, will you be so strange?Sorry am I that our good will effectsBianca's grief.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Why will you mew her up,Signior Baptista, for this fiend of hell,And make her bear the penance of her tongue?

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Gentlemen, content ye; I am resolved:Go in, Bianca:And for I know she taketh most delightIn music, instruments and poetry,Schoolmasters will I keep within my house,Fit to instruct her youth. If you, Hortensio,Or Signior Gremio, you, know any such,Prefer them hither; for to cunning menI will be very kind, and liberalTo mine own children in good bringing up:And so farewell. Katharina, you may stay;For I have more to commune with Bianca.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Why, and I trust I may go too, may I not? What,shall I be appointed hours; as though, belike, Iknew not what to take and what to leave, ha?

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: You may go to the devil's dam: your gifts are sogood, here's none will hold you. Their love is notso great, Hortensio, but we may blow our nailstogether, and fast it fairly out: our cakes dough onboth sides. Farewell: yet for the love I bear mysweet Bianca, if I can by any means light on a fitman to teach her that wherein she delights, I willwish him to her father.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: So will I, Signior Gremio: but a word, I pray.Though the nature of our quarrel yet never brookedparle, know now, upon advice, it toucheth us both,that we may yet again have access to our fairmistress and be happy rivals in Bianco's love, tolabour and effect one thing specially.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: What's that, I pray?

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Marry, sir, to get a husband for her sister.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: A husband! a devil.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: I say, a husband.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: I say, a devil. Thinkest thou, Hortensio, thoughher father be very rich, any man is so very a foolto be married to hell?

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Tush, Gremio, though it pass your patience and mineto endure her loud alarums, why, man, there be goodfellows in the world, an a man could light on them,would take her with all faults, and money enough.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: I cannot tell; but I had as lief take her dowry withthis condition, to be whipped at the high crossevery morning.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Faith, as you say, there's small choice in rottenapples. But come; since this bar in law makes usfriends, it shall be so far forth friendlymaintained all by helping Baptista's eldest daughterto a husband we set his youngest free for a husband,and then have to't a fresh. Sweet Bianca! Happy manbe his dole! He that runs fastest gets the ring.How say you, Signior Gremio?

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: I am agreed; and would I had given him the besthorse in Padua to begin his wooing that wouldthoroughly woo her, wed her and bed her and rid thehouse of her! Come on.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: I pray, sir, tell me, is it possibleThat love should of a sudden take such hold?

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: O Tranio, till I found it to be true,I never thought it possible or likely;But see, while idly I stood looking on,I found the effect of love in idleness:And now in plainness do confess to thee,That art to me as secret and as dearAs Anna to the queen of Carthage was,Tranio, I burn, I pine, I perish, Tranio,If I achieve not this young modest girl.Counsel me, Tranio, for I know thou canst;Assist me, Tranio, for I know thou wilt.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Master, it is no time to chide you now;Affection is not rated from the heart:If love have touch'd you, nought remains but so,'Redime te captum quam queas minimo.'

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Gramercies, lad, go forward; this contents:The rest will comfort, for thy counsel's sound.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Master, you look'd so longly on the maid,Perhaps you mark'd not what's the pith of all.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: O yes, I saw sweet beauty in her face,Such as the daughter of Agenor had,That made great Jove to humble him to her hand.When with his knees he kiss'd the Cretan strand.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Saw you no more? mark'd you not how her sisterBegan to scold and raise up such a stormThat mortal ears might hardly endure the din?

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Tranio, I saw her coral lips to moveAnd with her breath she did perfume the air:Sacred and sweet was all I saw in her.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Nay, then, 'tis time to stir him from his trance.I pray, awake, sir: if you love the maid,Bend thoughts and wits to achieve her. Thus it stands:Her eldest sister is so curst and shrewdThat till the father rid his hands of her,Master, your love must live a maid at home;And therefore has he closely mew'd her up,Because she will not be annoy'd with suitors.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Ah, Tranio, what a cruel father's he!But art thou not advised, he took some careTo get her cunning schoolmasters to instruct her?

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Ay, marry, am I, sir; and now 'tis plotted.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: I have it, Tranio.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Master, for my hand,Both our inventions meet and jump in one.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Tell me thine first.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: You will be schoolmasterAnd undertake the teaching of the maid:That's your device.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: It is: may it be done?

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Not possible; for who shall bear your part,And be in Padua here Vincentio's son,Keep house and ply his book, welcome his friends,Visit his countrymen and banquet them?

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Basta; content thee, for I have it full.We have not yet been seen in any house,Nor can we lie distinguish'd by our facesFor man or master; then it follows thus;Thou shalt be master, Tranio, in my stead,Keep house and port and servants as I should:I will some other be, some Florentine,Some Neapolitan, or meaner man of Pisa.'Tis hatch'd and shall be so: Tranio, at onceUncase thee; take my colour'd hat and cloak:When Biondello comes, he waits on thee;But I will charm him first to keep his tongue.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: So had you need.In brief, sir, sith it your pleasure is,And I am tied to be obedient;For so your father charged me at our parting,'Be serviceable to my son,' quoth he,Although I think 'twas in another sense;I am content to be Lucentio,Because so well I love Lucentio.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Tranio, be so, because Lucentio loves:And let me be a slave, to achieve that maidWhose sudden sight hath thrall'd my wounded eye.Here comes the rogue.Sirrah, where have you been?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Where have I been! Nay, how now! where are you?Master, has my fellow Tranio stolen your clothes? Oryou stolen his? or both? pray, what's the news?

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Sirrah, come hither: 'tis no time to jest,And therefore frame your manners to the time.Your fellow Tranio here, to save my life,Puts my apparel and my countenance on,And I for my escape have put on his;For in a quarrel since I came ashoreI kill'd a man and fear I was descried:Wait you on him, I charge you, as becomes,While I make way from hence to save my life:You understand me?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: I, sir! ne'er a whit.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: And not a jot of Tranio in your mouth:Tranio is changed into Lucentio.

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: The better for him: would I were so too!

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: So could I, faith, boy, to have the next wish after,That Lucentio indeed had Baptista's youngest daughter.But, sirrah, not for my sake, but your master's, I adviseYou use your manners discreetly in all kind of companies:When I am alone, why, then I am Tranio;But in all places else your master Lucentio.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Tranio, let's go: one thing more rests, thatthyself execute, to make one among these wooers: ifthou ask me why, sufficeth, my reasons are both goodand weighty.

speaker: First Servant
dialog: My lord, you nod; you do not mind the play.

speaker: SLY
dialog: Yes, by Saint Anne, do I. A good matter, surely:comes there any more of it?

speaker: Page
dialog: My lord, 'tis but begun.

speaker: SLY
dialog: 'Tis a very excellent piece of work, madam lady:would 'twere done!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Verona, for a while I take my leave,To see my friends in Padua, but of allMy best beloved and approved friend,Hortensio; and I trow this is his house.Here, sirrah Grumio; knock, I say.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Knock, sir! whom should I knock? is there man hasrebused your worship?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Villain, I say, knock me here soundly.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Knock you here, sir! why, sir, what am I, sir, thatI should knock you here, sir?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Villain, I say, knock me at this gateAnd rap me well, or I'll knock your knave's pate.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: My master is grown quarrelsome. I should knockyou first,And then I know after who comes by the worst.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Will it not be?Faith, sirrah, an you'll not knock, I'll ring it;I'll try how you can sol, fa, and sing it.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Help, masters, help! my master is mad.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Now, knock when I bid you, sirrah villain!

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: How now! what's the matter? My old friend Grumio!and my good friend Petruchio! How do you all at Verona?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Signior Hortensio, come you to part the fray?'Con tutto il cuore, ben trovato,' may I say.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: 'Alla nostra casa ben venuto, molto honorato signormio Petruchio.' Rise, Grumio, rise: we will compoundthis quarrel.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Nay, 'tis no matter, sir, what he 'leges in Latin.if this be not a lawful case for me to leave hisservice, look you, sir, he bid me knock him and raphim soundly, sir: well, was it fit for a servant touse his master so, being perhaps, for aught I see,two and thirty, a pip out? Whom would to God I hadwell knock'd at first, Then had not Grumio come by the worst.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: A senseless villain! Good Hortensio,I bade the rascal knock upon your gateAnd could not get him for my heart to do it.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Knock at the gate! O heavens! Spake you not thesewords plain, 'Sirrah, knock me here, rap me here,knock me well, and knock me soundly'? And come younow with, 'knocking at the gate'?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Sirrah, be gone, or talk not, I advise you.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Petruchio, patience; I am Grumio's pledge:Why, this's a heavy chance 'twixt him and you,Your ancient, trusty, pleasant servant Grumio.And tell me now, sweet friend, what happy galeBlows you to Padua here from old Verona?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Such wind as scatters young men through the world,To seek their fortunes farther than at homeWhere small experience grows. But in a few,Signior Hortensio, thus it stands with me:Antonio, my father, is deceased;And I have thrust myself into this maze,Haply to wive and thrive as best I may:Crowns in my purse I have and goods at home,And so am come abroad to see the world.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Petruchio, shall I then come roundly to theeAnd wish thee to a shrewd ill-favour'd wife?Thou'ldst thank me but a little for my counsel:And yet I'll promise thee she shall be richAnd very rich: but thou'rt too much my friend,And I'll not wish thee to her.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Signior Hortensio, 'twixt such friends as weFew words suffice; and therefore, if thou knowOne rich enough to be Petruchio's wife,As wealth is burden of my wooing dance,Be she as foul as was Florentius' love,As old as Sibyl and as curst and shrewdAs Socrates' Xanthippe, or a worse,She moves me not, or not removes, at least,Affection's edge in me, were she as roughAs are the swelling Adriatic seas:I come to wive it wealthily in Padua;If wealthily, then happily in Padua.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Nay, look you, sir, he tells you flatly what hismind is: Why give him gold enough and marry him toa puppet or an aglet-baby; or an old trot with ne'era tooth in her head, though she have as many diseasesas two and fifty horses: why, nothing comes amiss,so money comes withal.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Petruchio, since we are stepp'd thus far in,I will continue that I broach'd in jest.I can, Petruchio, help thee to a wifeWith wealth enough and young and beauteous,Brought up as best becomes a gentlewoman:Her only fault, and that is faults enough,Is that she is intolerable curstAnd shrewd and froward, so beyond all measureThat, were my state far worser than it is,I would not wed her for a mine of gold.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Hortensio, peace! thou know'st not gold's effect:Tell me her father's name and 'tis enough;For I will board her, though she chide as loudAs thunder when the clouds in autumn crack.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Her father is Baptista Minola,An affable and courteous gentleman:Her name is Katharina Minola,Renown'd in Padua for her scolding tongue.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: I know her father, though I know not her;And he knew my deceased father well.I will not sleep, Hortensio, till I see her;And therefore let me be thus bold with youTo give you over at this first encounter,Unless you will accompany me thither.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: I pray you, sir, let him go while the humour lasts.O' my word, an she knew him as well as I do, shewould think scolding would do little good upon him:she may perhaps call him half a score knaves or so:why, that's nothing; an he begin once, he'll rail inhis rope-tricks. I'll tell you what sir, an shestand him but a little, he will throw a figure inher face and so disfigure her with it that sheshall have no more eyes to see withal than a cat.You know him not, sir.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Tarry, Petruchio, I must go with thee,For in Baptista's keep my treasure is:He hath the jewel of my life in hold,His youngest daughter, beautiful Binaca,And her withholds from me and other more,Suitors to her and rivals in my love,Supposing it a thing impossible,For those defects I have before rehearsed,That ever Katharina will be woo'd;Therefore this order hath Baptista ta'en,That none shall have access unto BiancaTill Katharina the curst have got a husband.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Katharina the curst!A title for a maid of all titles the worst.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Now shall my friend Petruchio do me grace,And offer me disguised in sober robesTo old Baptista as a schoolmasterWell seen in music, to instruct Bianca;That so I may, by this device, at leastHave leave and leisure to make love to herAnd unsuspected court her by herself.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Here's no knavery! See, to beguile the old folks,how the young folks lay their heads together!Master, master, look about you: who goes there, ha?

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Peace, Grumio! it is the rival of my love.Petruchio, stand by a while.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: A proper stripling and an amorous!

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: O, very well; I have perused the note.Hark you, sir: I'll have them very fairly bound:All books of love, see that at any hand;And see you read no other lectures to her:You understand me: over and besideSignior Baptista's liberality,I'll mend it with a largess. Take your paper too,And let me have them very well perfumedFor she is sweeter than perfume itselfTo whom they go to. What will you read to her?

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Whate'er I read to her, I'll plead for youAs for my patron, stand you so assured,As firmly as yourself were still in place:Yea, and perhaps with more successful wordsThan you, unless you were a scholar, sir.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: O this learning, what a thing it is!

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: O this woodcock, what an ass it is!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Peace, sirrah!

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Grumio, mum! God save you, Signior Gremio.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: And you are well met, Signior Hortensio.Trow you whither I am going? To Baptista Minola.I promised to inquire carefullyAbout a schoolmaster for the fair Bianca:And by good fortune I have lighted wellOn this young man, for learning and behaviorFit for her turn, well read in poetryAnd other books, good ones, I warrant ye.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: 'Tis well; and I have met a gentlemanHath promised me to help me to another,A fine musician to instruct our mistress;So shall I no whit be behind in dutyTo fair Bianca, so beloved of me.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Beloved of me; and that my deeds shall prove.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: And that his bags shall prove.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Gremio, 'tis now no time to vent our love:Listen to me, and if you speak me fair,I'll tell you news indifferent good for either.Here is a gentleman whom by chance I met,Upon agreement from us to his liking,Will undertake to woo curst Katharina,Yea, and to marry her, if her dowry please.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: So said, so done, is well.Hortensio, have you told him all her faults?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: I know she is an irksome brawling scold:If that be all, masters, I hear no harm.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: No, say'st me so, friend? What countryman?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Born in Verona, old Antonio's son:My father dead, my fortune lives for me;And I do hope good days and long to see.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: O sir, such a life, with such a wife, were strange!But if you have a stomach, to't i' God's name:You shall have me assisting you in all.But will you woo this wild-cat?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Will I live?

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Will he woo her? ay, or I'll hang her.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Why came I hither but to that intent?Think you a little din can daunt mine ears?Have I not in my time heard lions roar?Have I not heard the sea puff'd up with windsRage like an angry boar chafed with sweat?Have I not heard great ordnance in the field,And heaven's artillery thunder in the skies?Have I not in a pitched battle heardLoud 'larums, neighing steeds, and trumpets' clang?And do you tell me of a woman's tongue,That gives not half so great a blow to hearAs will a chestnut in a farmer's fire?Tush, tush! fear boys with bugs.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: For he fears none.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Hortensio, hark:This gentleman is happily arrived,My mind presumes, for his own good and ours.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: I promised we would be contributorsAnd bear his charging of wooing, whatsoe'er.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: And so we will, provided that he win her.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: I would I were as sure of a good dinner.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Gentlemen, God save you. If I may be bold,Tell me, I beseech you, which is the readiest wayTo the house of Signior Baptista Minola?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: He that has the two fair daughters: is't he you mean?

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Even he, Biondello.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Hark you, sir; you mean not her to--

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Perhaps, him and her, sir: what have you to do?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Not her that chides, sir, at any hand, I pray.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: I love no chiders, sir. Biondello, let's away.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Well begun, Tranio.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Sir, a word ere you go;Are you a suitor to the maid you talk of, yea or no?

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: And if I be, sir, is it any offence?

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: No; if without more words you will get you hence.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Why, sir, I pray, are not the streets as freeFor me as for you?

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: But so is not she.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: For what reason, I beseech you?

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: For this reason, if you'll know,That she's the choice love of Signior Gremio.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: That she's the chosen of Signior Hortensio.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Softly, my masters! if you be gentlemen,Do me this right; hear me with patience.Baptista is a noble gentleman,To whom my father is not all unknown;And were his daughter fairer than she is,She may more suitors have and me for one.Fair Leda's daughter had a thousand wooers;Then well one more may fair Bianca have:And so she shall; Lucentio shall make one,Though Paris came in hope to speed alone.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: What! this gentleman will out-talk us all.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Sir, give him head: I know he'll prove a jade.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Hortensio, to what end are all these words?

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Sir, let me be so bold as ask you,Did you yet ever see Baptista's daughter?

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: No, sir; but hear I do that he hath two,The one as famous for a scolding tongueAs is the other for beauteous modesty.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Sir, sir, the first's for me; let her go by.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Yea, leave that labour to great Hercules;And let it be more than Alcides' twelve.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Sir, understand you this of me in sooth:The youngest daughter whom you hearken forHer father keeps from all access of suitors,And will not promise her to any manUntil the elder sister first be wed:The younger then is free and not before.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: If it be so, sir, that you are the manMust stead us all and me amongst the rest,And if you break the ice and do this feat,Achieve the elder, set the younger freeFor our access, whose hap shall be to have herWill not so graceless be to be ingrate.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Sir, you say well and well you do conceive;And since you do profess to be a suitor,You must, as we do, gratify this gentleman,To whom we all rest generally beholding.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Sir, I shall not be slack: in sign whereof,Please ye we may contrive this afternoon,And quaff carouses to our mistress' health,And do as adversaries do in law,Strive mightily, but eat and drink as friends.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: O excellent motion! Fellows, let's be gone.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: The motion's good indeed and be it so,Petruchio, I shall be your ben venuto.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Good sister, wrong me not, nor wrong yourself,To make a bondmaid and a slave of me;That I disdain: but for these other gawds,Unbind my hands, I'll pull them off myself,Yea, all my raiment, to my petticoat;Or what you will command me will I do,So well I know my duty to my elders.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Of all thy suitors, here I charge thee, tellWhom thou lovest best: see thou dissemble not.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Believe me, sister, of all the men aliveI never yet beheld that special faceWhich I could fancy more than any other.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Minion, thou liest. Is't not Hortensio?

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: If you affect him, sister, here I swearI'll plead for you myself, but you shall havehim.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: O then, belike, you fancy riches more:You will have Gremio to keep you fair.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Is it for him you do envy me so?Nay then you jest, and now I well perceiveYou have but jested with me all this while:I prithee, sister Kate, untie my hands.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: If that be jest, then all the rest was so.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Why, how now, dame! whence grows this insolence?Bianca, stand aside. Poor girl! she weeps.Go ply thy needle; meddle not with her.For shame, thou helding of a devilish spirit,Why dost thou wrong her that did ne'er wrong thee?When did she cross thee with a bitter word?

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Her silence flouts me, and I'll be revenged.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: What, in my sight? Bianca, get thee in.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: What, will you not suffer me? Nay, now I seeShe is your treasure, she must have a husband;I must dance bare-foot on her wedding dayAnd for your love to her lead apes in hell.Talk not to me: I will go sit and weepTill I can find occasion of revenge.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Was ever gentleman thus grieved as I?But who comes here?

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Good morrow, neighbour Baptista.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Good morrow, neighbour Gremio.God save you, gentlemen!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: And you, good sir! Pray, have you not a daughterCall'd Katharina, fair and virtuous?

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: I have a daughter, sir, called Katharina.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: You are too blunt: go to it orderly.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: You wrong me, Signior Gremio: give me leave.I am a gentleman of Verona, sir,That, hearing of her beauty and her wit,Her affability and bashful modesty,Her wondrous qualities and mild behavior,Am bold to show myself a forward guestWithin your house, to make mine eye the witnessOf that report which I so oft have heard.And, for an entrance to my entertainment,I do present you with a man of mine,Cunning in music and the mathematics,To instruct her fully in those sciences,Whereof I know she is not ignorant:Accept of him, or else you do me wrong:His name is Licio, born in Mantua.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: You're welcome, sir; and he, for your good sake.But for my daughter Katharina, this I know,She is not for your turn, the more my grief.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: I see you do not mean to part with her,Or else you like not of my company.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Mistake me not; I speak but as I find.Whence are you, sir? what may I call your name?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Petruchio is my name; Antonio's son,A man well known throughout all Italy.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: I know him well: you are welcome for his sake.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Saving your tale, Petruchio, I pray,Let us, that are poor petitioners, speak too:Baccare! you are marvellous forward.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: O, pardon me, Signior Gremio; I would fain be doing.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: I doubt it not, sir; but you will curse yourwooing. Neighbour, this is a gift very grateful, I amsure of it. To express the like kindness, myself,that have been more kindly beholding to you thanany, freely give unto you this young scholar,that hath been long studying at Rheims; as cunningin Greek, Latin, and other languages, as the otherin music and mathematics: his name is Cambio; pray,accept his service.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: A thousand thanks, Signior Gremio.Welcome, good Cambio.But, gentle sir, methinks you walk like a stranger:may I be so bold to know the cause of your coming?

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Pardon me, sir, the boldness is mine own,That, being a stranger in this city here,Do make myself a suitor to your daughter,Unto Bianca, fair and virtuous.Nor is your firm resolve unknown to me,In the preferment of the eldest sister.This liberty is all that I request,That, upon knowledge of my parentage,I may have welcome 'mongst the rest that wooAnd free access and favour as the rest:And, toward the education of your daughters,I here bestow a simple instrument,And this small packet of Greek and Latin books:If you accept them, then their worth is great.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Lucentio is your name; of whence, I pray?

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Of Pisa, sir; son to Vincentio.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: A mighty man of Pisa; by reportI know him well: you are very welcome, sir,Take you the lute, and you the set of books;You shall go see your pupils presently.Holla, within!Sirrah, lead these gentlemenTo my daughters; and tell them both,These are their tutors: bid them use them well.We will go walk a little in the orchard,And then to dinner. You are passing welcome,And so I pray you all to think yourselves.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Signior Baptista, my business asketh haste,And every day I cannot come to woo.You knew my father well, and in him me,Left solely heir to all his lands and goods,Which I have better'd rather than decreased:Then tell me, if I get your daughter's love,What dowry shall I have with her to wife?

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: After my death the one half of my lands,And in possession twenty thousand crowns.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: And, for that dowry, I'll assure her ofHer widowhood, be it that she survive me,In all my lands and leases whatsoever:Let specialties be therefore drawn between us,That covenants may be kept on either hand.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Ay, when the special thing is well obtain'd,That is, her love; for that is all in all.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Why, that is nothing: for I tell you, father,I am as peremptory as she proud-minded;And where two raging fires meet togetherThey do consume the thing that feeds their fury:Though little fire grows great with little wind,Yet extreme gusts will blow out fire and all:So I to her and so she yields to me;For I am rough and woo not like a babe.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Well mayst thou woo, and happy be thy speed!But be thou arm'd for some unhappy words.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Ay, to the proof; as mountains are for winds,That shake not, though they blow perpetually.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: How now, my friend! why dost thou look so pale?

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: For fear, I promise you, if I look pale.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: What, will my daughter prove a good musician?

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: I think she'll sooner prove a soldierIron may hold with her, but never lutes.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Why, then thou canst not break her to the lute?

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Why, no; for she hath broke the lute to me.I did but tell her she mistook her frets,And bow'd her hand to teach her fingering;When, with a most impatient devilish spirit,'Frets, call you these?' quoth she; 'I'll fumewith them:'And, with that word, she struck me on the head,And through the instrument my pate made way;And there I stood amazed for a while,As on a pillory, looking through the lute;While she did call me rascal fiddlerAnd twangling Jack; with twenty such vile terms,As had she studied to misuse me so.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Now, by the world, it is a lusty wench;I love her ten times more than e'er I did:O, how I long to have some chat with her!

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Well, go with me and be not so discomfited:Proceed in practise with my younger daughter;She's apt to learn and thankful for good turns.Signior Petruchio, will you go with us,Or shall I send my daughter Kate to you?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: I pray you do.I will attend her here,And woo her with some spirit when she comes.Say that she rail; why then I'll tell her plainShe sings as sweetly as a nightingale:Say that she frown, I'll say she looks as clearAs morning roses newly wash'd with dew:Say she be mute and will not speak a word;Then I'll commend her volubility,And say she uttereth piercing eloquence:If she do bid me pack, I'll give her thanks,As though she bid me stay by her a week:If she deny to wed, I'll crave the dayWhen I shall ask the banns and when be married.But here she comes; and now, Petruchio, speak.Good morrow, Kate; for that's your name, I hear.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Well have you heard, but something hard of hearing:They call me Katharina that do talk of me.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: You lie, in faith; for you are call'd plain Kate,And bonny Kate and sometimes Kate the curst;But Kate, the prettiest Kate in ChristendomKate of Kate Hall, my super-dainty Kate,For dainties are all Kates, and therefore, Kate,Take this of me, Kate of my consolation;Hearing thy mildness praised in every town,Thy virtues spoke of, and thy beauty sounded,Yet not so deeply as to thee belongs,Myself am moved to woo thee for my wife.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Moved! in good time: let him that moved you hitherRemove you hence: I knew you at the firstYou were a moveable.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Why, what's a moveable?

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: A join'd-stool.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Thou hast hit it: come, sit on me.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Asses are made to bear, and so are you.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Women are made to bear, and so are you.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: No such jade as you, if me you mean.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Alas! good Kate, I will not burden thee;For, knowing thee to be but young and light--

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Too light for such a swain as you to catch;And yet as heavy as my weight should be.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Should be! should--buzz!

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Well ta'en, and like a buzzard.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: O slow-wing'd turtle! shall a buzzard take thee?

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Ay, for a turtle, as he takes a buzzard.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Come, come, you wasp; i' faith, you are too angry.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: If I be waspish, best beware my sting.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: My remedy is then, to pluck it out.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Ay, if the fool could find it where it lies,

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Who knows not where a wasp doeswear his sting? In his tail.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: In his tongue.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Whose tongue?

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Yours, if you talk of tails: and so farewell.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: What, with my tongue in your tail? nay, come again,Good Kate; I am a gentleman.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: That I'll try.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: I swear I'll cuff you, if you strike again.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: So may you lose your arms:If you strike me, you are no gentleman;And if no gentleman, why then no arms.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: A herald, Kate? O, put me in thy books!

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: What is your crest? a coxcomb?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: A combless cock, so Kate will be my hen.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: No cock of mine; you crow too like a craven.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Nay, come, Kate, come; you must not look so sour.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: It is my fashion, when I see a crab.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Why, here's no crab; and therefore look not sour.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: There is, there is.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Then show it me.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Had I a glass, I would.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: What, you mean my face?

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Well aim'd of such a young one.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Now, by Saint George, I am too young for you.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Yet you are wither'd.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: 'Tis with cares.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: I care not.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Nay, hear you, Kate: in sooth you scape not so.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: I chafe you, if I tarry: let me go.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: No, not a whit: I find you passing gentle.'Twas told me you were rough and coy and sullen,And now I find report a very liar;For thou are pleasant, gamesome, passing courteous,But slow in speech, yet sweet as spring-time flowers:Thou canst not frown, thou canst not look askance,Nor bite the lip, as angry wenches will,Nor hast thou pleasure to be cross in talk,But thou with mildness entertain'st thy wooers,With gentle conference, soft and affable.Why does the world report that Kate doth limp?O slanderous world! Kate like the hazel-twigIs straight and slender and as brown in hueAs hazel nuts and sweeter than the kernels.O, let me see thee walk: thou dost not halt.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Go, fool, and whom thou keep'st command.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Did ever Dian so become a groveAs Kate this chamber with her princely gait?O, be thou Dian, and let her be Kate;And then let Kate be chaste and Dian sportful!

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Where did you study all this goodly speech?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: It is extempore, from my mother-wit.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: A witty mother! witless else her son.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Am I not wise?

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Yes; keep you warm.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Marry, so I mean, sweet Katharina, in thy bed:And therefore, setting all this chat aside,Thus in plain terms: your father hath consentedThat you shall be my wife; your dowry 'greed on;And, Will you, nill you, I will marry you.Now, Kate, I am a husband for your turn;For, by this light, whereby I see thy beauty,Thy beauty, that doth make me like thee well,Thou must be married to no man but me;For I am he am born to tame you Kate,And bring you from a wild Kate to a KateConformable as other household Kates.Here comes your father: never make denial;I must and will have Katharina to my wife.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: How but well, sir? how but well?It were impossible I should speed amiss.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Why, how now, daughter Katharina! in your dumps?

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Call you me daughter? now, I promise youYou have show'd a tender fatherly regard,To wish me wed to one half lunatic;A mad-cup ruffian and a swearing Jack,That thinks with oaths to face the matter out.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Father, 'tis thus: yourself and all the world,That talk'd of her, have talk'd amiss of her:If she be curst, it is for policy,For she's not froward, but modest as the dove;She is not hot, but temperate as the morn;For patience she will prove a second Grissel,And Roman Lucrece for her chastity:And to conclude, we have 'greed so well together,That upon Sunday is the wedding-day.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: I'll see thee hang'd on Sunday first.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Hark, Petruchio; she says she'll see theehang'd first.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Is this your speeding? nay, then, good night our part!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Be patient, gentlemen; I choose her for myself:If she and I be pleased, what's that to you?'Tis bargain'd 'twixt us twain, being alone,That she shall still be curst in company.I tell you, 'tis incredible to believeHow much she loves me: O, the kindest Kate!She hung about my neck; and kiss on kissShe vied so fast, protesting oath on oath,That in a twink she won me to her love.O, you are novices! 'tis a world to see,How tame, when men and women are alone,A meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew.Give me thy hand, Kate: I will unto Venice,To buy apparel 'gainst the wedding-day.Provide the feast, father, and bid the guests;I will be sure my Katharina shall be fine.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: I know not what to say: but give me your hands;God send you joy, Petruchio! 'tis a match.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Amen, say we: we will be witnesses.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu;I will to Venice; Sunday comes apace:We will have rings and things and fine array;And kiss me, Kate, we will be married o'Sunday.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Was ever match clapp'd up so suddenly?

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Faith, gentlemen, now I play a merchant's part,And venture madly on a desperate mart.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: 'Twas a commodity lay fretting by you:'Twill bring you gain, or perish on the seas.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: The gain I seek is, quiet in the match.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch.But now, Baptists, to your younger daughter:Now is the day we long have looked for:I am your neighbour, and was suitor first.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: And I am one that love Bianca moreThan words can witness, or your thoughts can guess.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Graybeard, thy love doth freeze.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: But thine doth fry.Skipper, stand back: 'tis age that nourisheth.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: But youth in ladies' eyes that flourisheth.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Content you, gentlemen: I will compound this strife:'Tis deeds must win the prize; and he of bothThat can assure my daughter greatest dowerShall have my Bianca's love.Say, Signior Gremio, What can you assure her?

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: First, as you know, my house within the cityIs richly furnished with plate and gold;Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands;My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry;In ivory coffers I have stuff'd my crowns;In cypress chests my arras counterpoints,Costly apparel, tents, and canopies,Fine linen, Turkey cushions boss'd with pearl,Valance of Venice gold in needlework,Pewter and brass and all things that belongTo house or housekeeping: then, at my farmI have a hundred milch-kine to the pail,Sixscore fat oxen standing in my stalls,And all things answerable to this portion.Myself am struck in years, I must confess;And if I die to-morrow, this is hers,If whilst I live she will be only mine.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: That 'only' came well in. Sir, list to me:I am my father's heir and only son:If I may have your daughter to my wife,I'll leave her houses three or four as good,Within rich Pisa walls, as any oneOld Signior Gremio has in Padua;Besides two thousand ducats by the yearOf fruitful land, all which shall be her jointure.What, have I pinch'd you, Signior Gremio?

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Two thousand ducats by the year of land!My land amounts not to so much in all:That she shall have; besides an argosyThat now is lying in Marseilles' road.What, have I choked you with an argosy?

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Gremio, 'tis known my father hath no lessThan three great argosies; besides two galliases,And twelve tight galleys: these I will assure her,And twice as much, whate'er thou offer'st next.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Nay, I have offer'd all, I have no more;And she can have no more than all I have:If you like me, she shall have me and mine.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Why, then the maid is mine from all the world,By your firm promise: Gremio is out-vied.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: I must confess your offer is the best;And, let your father make her the assurance,She is your own; else, you must pardon me,if you should die before him, where's her dower?

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: That's but a cavil: he is old, I young.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: And may not young men die, as well as old?

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Well, gentlemen,I am thus resolved: on Sunday next you knowMy daughter Katharina is to be married:Now, on the Sunday following, shall BiancaBe bride to you, if you this assurance;If not, Signior Gremio:And so, I take my leave, and thank you both.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Adieu, good neighbour.Now I fear thee not:Sirrah young gamester, your father were a foolTo give thee all, and in his waning ageSet foot under thy table: tut, a toy!An old Italian fox is not so kind, my boy.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: A vengeance on your crafty wither'd hide!Yet I have faced it with a card of ten.'Tis in my head to do my master good:I see no reason but supposed LucentioMust get a father, call'd 'supposed Vincentio;'And that's a wonder: fathers commonlyDo get their children; but in this case of wooing,A child shall get a sire, if I fail not of my cunning.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Fiddler, forbear; you grow too forward, sir:Have you so soon forgot the entertainmentHer sister Katharina welcomed you withal?

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: But, wrangling pedant, this isThe patroness of heavenly harmony:Then give me leave to have prerogative;And when in music we have spent an hour,Your lecture shall have leisure for as much.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Preposterous ass, that never read so farTo know the cause why music was ordain'd!Was it not to refresh the mind of manAfter his studies or his usual pain?Then give me leave to read philosophy,And while I pause, serve in your harmony.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Sirrah, I will not bear these braves of thine.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Why, gentlemen, you do me double wrong,To strive for that which resteth in my choice:I am no breeching scholar in the schools;I'll not be tied to hours nor 'pointed times,But learn my lessons as I please myself.And, to cut off all strife, here sit we down:Take you your instrument, play you the whiles;His lecture will be done ere you have tuned.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: You'll leave his lecture when I am in tune?

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: That will be never: tune your instrument.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Where left we last?

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Here, madam:'Hic ibat Simois; hic est Sigeia tellus;Hic steterat Priami regia celsa senis.'

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Construe them.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: 'Hic ibat,' as I told you before, 'Simois,' I amLucentio, 'hic est,' son unto Vincentio of Pisa,'Sigeia tellus,' disguised thus to get your love;'Hic steterat,' and that Lucentio that comesa-wooing, 'Priami,' is my man Tranio, 'regia,'bearing my port, 'celsa senis,' that we mightbeguile the old pantaloon.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Madam, my instrument's in tune.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Let's hear. O fie! the treble jars.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Spit in the hole, man, and tune again.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Now let me see if I can construe it: 'Hic ibatSimois,' I know you not, 'hic est Sigeia tellus,' Itrust you not; 'Hic steterat Priami,' take heedhe hear us not, 'regia,' presume not, 'celsa senis,'despair not.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Madam, 'tis now in tune.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: All but the base.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: The base is right; 'tis the base knave that jars.How fiery and forward our pedant is!Now, for my life, the knave doth court my love:Pedascule, I'll watch you better yet.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: In time I may believe, yet I mistrust.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Mistrust it not: for, sure, AEacidesWas Ajax, call'd so from his grandfather.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: I must believe my master; else, I promise you,I should be arguing still upon that doubt:But let it rest. Now, Licio, to you:Good masters, take it not unkindly, pray,That I have been thus pleasant with you both.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: You may go walk, and give me leave a while:My lessons make no music in three parts.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Are you so formal, sir? well, I must wait,And watch withal; for, but I be deceived,Our fine musician groweth amorous.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Madam, before you touch the instrument,To learn the order of my fingering,I must begin with rudiments of art;To teach you gamut in a briefer sort,More pleasant, pithy and effectual,Than hath been taught by any of my trade:And there it is in writing, fairly drawn.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Why, I am past my gamut long ago.

speaker: Servant
dialog: Mistress, your father prays you leave your booksAnd help to dress your sister's chamber up:You know to-morrow is the wedding-day.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Farewell, sweet masters both; I must be gone.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Faith, mistress, then I have no cause to stay.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: But I have cause to pry into this pedant:Methinks he looks as though he were in love:Yet if thy thoughts, Bianca, be so humbleTo cast thy wandering eyes on every stale,Seize thee that list: if once I find thee ranging,Hortensio will be quit with thee by changing.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Patience, good Katharina, and Baptista too.Upon my life, Petruchio means but well,Whatever fortune stays him from his word:Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise;Though he be merry, yet withal he's honest.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Would Katharina had never seen him though!

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Go, girl; I cannot blame thee now to weep;For such an injury would vex a very saint,Much more a shrew of thy impatient humour.

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Master, master! news, old news, and such news asyou never heard of!

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Is it new and old too? how may that be?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Why, is it not news, to hear of Petruchio's coming?

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Is he come?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Why, no, sir.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: What then?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: He is coming.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: When will he be here?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: When he stands where I am and sees you there.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: But say, what to thine old news?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Why, Petruchio is coming in a new hat and an oldjerkin, a pair of old breeches thrice turned, a pairof boots that have been candle-cases, one buckled,another laced, an old rusty sword ta'en out of thetown-armory, with a broken hilt, and chapeless;with two broken points: his horse hipped with anold mothy saddle and stirrups of no kindred;besides, possessed with the glanders and like to mosein the chine; troubled with the lampass, infectedwith the fashions, full of wingdalls, sped withspavins, rayed with yellows, past cure of the fives,stark spoiled with the staggers, begnawn with thebots, swayed in the back and shoulder-shotten;near-legged before and with, a half-chequed bitand a head-stall of sheeps leather which, beingrestrained to keep him from stumbling, hath beenoften burst and now repaired with knots; one girthsix time pieced and a woman's crupper of velure,which hath two letters for her name fairly set downin studs, and here and there pieced with packthread.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Who comes with him?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: O, sir, his lackey, for all the world caparisonedlike the horse; with a linen stock on one leg and akersey boot-hose on the other, gartered with a redand blue list; an old hat and 'the humour of fortyfancies' pricked in't for a feather: a monster, avery monster in apparel, and not like a Christianfootboy or a gentleman's lackey.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: 'Tis some odd humour pricks him to this fashion;Yet oftentimes he goes but mean-apparell'd.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: I am glad he's come, howsoe'er he comes.

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Why, sir, he comes not.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Didst thou not say he comes?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Who? that Petruchio came?

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Ay, that Petruchio came.

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: No, sir, I say his horse comes, with him on his back.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Why, that's all one.

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Nay, by Saint Jamy,I hold you a penny,A horse and a manIs more than one,And yet not many.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Come, where be these gallants? who's at home?

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: You are welcome, sir.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: And yet I come not well.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: And yet you halt not.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Not so well apparell'dAs I wish you were.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Were it better, I should rush in thus.But where is Kate? where is my lovely bride?How does my father? Gentles, methinks you frown:And wherefore gaze this goodly company,As if they saw some wondrous monument,Some comet or unusual prodigy?

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Why, sir, you know this is your wedding-day:First were we sad, fearing you would not come;Now sadder, that you come so unprovided.Fie, doff this habit, shame to your estate,An eye-sore to our solemn festival!

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: And tells us, what occasion of importHath all so long detain'd you from your wife,And sent you hither so unlike yourself?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Tedious it were to tell, and harsh to hear:Sufficeth I am come to keep my word,Though in some part enforced to digress;Which, at more leisure, I will so excuseAs you shall well be satisfied withal.But where is Kate? I stay too long from her:The morning wears, 'tis time we were at church.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: See not your bride in these unreverent robes:Go to my chamber; Put on clothes of mine.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Not I, believe me: thus I'll visit her.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: But thus, I trust, you will not marry her.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Good sooth, even thus; therefore ha' done with words:To me she's married, not unto my clothes:Could I repair what she will wear in me,As I can change these poor accoutrements,'Twere well for Kate and better for myself.But what a fool am I to chat with you,When I should bid good morrow to my bride,And seal the title with a lovely kiss!

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: He hath some meaning in his mad attire:We will persuade him, be it possible,To put on better ere he go to church.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: I'll after him, and see the event of this.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: But to her love concerneth us to addHer father's liking: which to bring to pass,As I before unparted to your worship,I am to get a man,--whate'er he be,It skills not much. we'll fit him to our turn,--And he shall be Vincentio of Pisa;And make assurance here in PaduaOf greater sums than I have promised.So shall you quietly enjoy your hope,And marry sweet Bianca with consent.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Were it not that my fellow-school-masterDoth watch Bianca's steps so narrowly,'Twere good, methinks, to steal our marriage;Which once perform'd, let all the world say no,I'll keep mine own, despite of all the world.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: That by degrees we mean to look into,And watch our vantage in this business:We'll over-reach the greybeard, Gremio,The narrow-prying father, Minola,The quaint musician, amorous Licio;All for my master's sake, Lucentio.Signior Gremio, came you from the church?

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: As willingly as e'er I came from school.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: And is the bride and bridegroom coming home?

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: A bridegroom say you? 'tis a groom indeed,A grumbling groom, and that the girl shall find.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Curster than she? why, 'tis impossible.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Why he's a devil, a devil, a very fiend.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Why, she's a devil, a devil, the devil's dam.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Tut, she's a lamb, a dove, a fool to him!I'll tell you, Sir Lucentio: when the priestShould ask, if Katharina should be his wife,'Ay, by gogs-wouns,' quoth he; and swore so loud,That, all-amazed, the priest let fall the book;And, as he stoop'd again to take it up,The mad-brain'd bridegroom took him such a cuffThat down fell priest and book and book and priest:'Now take them up,' quoth he, 'if any list.'

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: What said the wench when he rose again?

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Trembled and shook; for why, he stamp'd and swore,As if the vicar meant to cozen him.But after many ceremonies done,He calls for wine: 'A health!' quoth he, as ifHe had been aboard, carousing to his matesAfter a storm; quaff'd off the muscadelAnd threw the sops all in the sexton's face;Having no other reasonBut that his beard grew thin and hungerlyAnd seem'd to ask him sops as he was drinking.This done, he took the bride about the neckAnd kiss'd her lips with such a clamorous smackThat at the parting all the church did echo:And I seeing this came thence for very shame;And after me, I know, the rout is coming.Such a mad marriage never was before:Hark, hark! I hear the minstrels play.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Gentlemen and friends, I thank you for your pains:I know you think to dine with me to-day,And have prepared great store of wedding cheer;But so it is, my haste doth call me hence,And therefore here I mean to take my leave.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Is't possible you will away to-night?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: I must away to-day, before night come:Make it no wonder; if you knew my business,You would entreat me rather go than stay.And, honest company, I thank you all,That have beheld me give away myselfTo this most patient, sweet and virtuous wife:Dine with my father, drink a health to me;For I must hence; and farewell to you all.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Let us entreat you stay till after dinner.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: It may not be.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Let me entreat you.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: It cannot be.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Let me entreat you.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: I am content.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Are you content to stay?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: I am content you shall entreat me stay;But yet not stay, entreat me how you can.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Now, if you love me, stay.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Grumio, my horse.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Ay, sir, they be ready: the oats have eaten the horses.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Nay, then,Do what thou canst, I will not go to-day;No, nor to-morrow, not till I please myself.The door is open, sir; there lies your way;You may be jogging whiles your boots are green;For me, I'll not be gone till I please myself:'Tis like you'll prove a jolly surly groom,That take it on you at the first so roundly.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: O Kate, content thee; prithee, be not angry.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: I will be angry: what hast thou to do?Father, be quiet; he shall stay my leisure.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Ay, marry, sir, now it begins to work.

speaker: KATARINA
dialog: Gentlemen, forward to the bridal dinner:I see a woman may be made a fool,If she had not a spirit to resist.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: They shall go forward, Kate, at thy command.Obey the bride, you that attend on her;Go to the feast, revel and domineer,Carouse full measure to her maidenhead,Be mad and merry, or go hang yourselves:But for my bonny Kate, she must with me.Nay, look not big, nor stamp, nor stare, nor fret;I will be master of what is mine own:She is my goods, my chattels; she is my house,My household stuff, my field, my barn,My horse, my ox, my ass, my any thing;And here she stands, touch her whoever dare;I'll bring mine action on the proudest heThat stops my way in Padua. Grumio,Draw forth thy weapon, we are beset with thieves;Rescue thy mistress, if thou be a man.Fear not, sweet wench, they shall not touchthee, Kate:I'll buckler thee against a million.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Nay, let them go, a couple of quiet ones.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Went they not quickly, I should die with laughing.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Of all mad matches never was the like.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Mistress, what's your opinion of your sister?

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: That, being mad herself, she's madly mated.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: I warrant him, Petruchio is Kated.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Neighbours and friends, though bride andbridegroom wantsFor to supply the places at the table,You know there wants no junkets at the feast.Lucentio, you shall supply the bridegroom's place:And let Bianca take her sister's room.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Shall sweet Bianca practise how to bride it?

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: She shall, Lucentio. Come, gentlemen, let's go.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Fie, fie on all tired jades, on all mad masters, andall foul ways! Was ever man so beaten? was everman so rayed? was ever man so weary? I am sentbefore to make a fire, and they are coming after towarm them. Now, were not I a little pot and soonhot, my very lips might freeze to my teeth, mytongue to the roof of my mouth, my heart in mybelly, ere I should come by a fire to thaw me: butI, with blowing the fire, shall warm myself; for,considering the weather, a taller man than I willtake cold. Holla, ho! Curtis.

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: Who is that calls so coldly?

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: A piece of ice: if thou doubt it, thou mayst slidefrom my shoulder to my heel with no greater a runbut my head and my neck. A fire good Curtis.

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: Is my master and his wife coming, Grumio?

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: O, ay, Curtis, ay: and therefore fire, fire; caston no water.

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: Is she so hot a shrew as she's reported?

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: She was, good Curtis, before this frost: but, thouknowest, winter tames man, woman and beast; for ithath tamed my old master and my new mistress andmyself, fellow Curtis.

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: Away, you three-inch fool! I am no beast.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Am I but three inches? why, thy horn is a foot; andso long am I at the least. But wilt thou make afire, or shall I complain on thee to our mistress,whose hand, she being now at hand, thou shalt soonfeel, to thy cold comfort, for being slow in thy hot office?

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: I prithee, good Grumio, tell me, how goes the world?

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: A cold world, Curtis, in every office but thine; andtherefore fire: do thy duty, and have thy duty; formy master and mistress are almost frozen to death.

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: There's fire ready; and therefore, good Grumio, the news.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Why, 'Jack, boy! ho! boy!' and as much news aswill thaw.

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: Come, you are so full of cony-catching!

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Why, therefore fire; for I have caught extreme cold.Where's the cook? is supper ready, the housetrimmed, rushes strewed, cobwebs swept; theserving-men in their new fustian, their whitestockings, and every officer his wedding-garment on?Be the jacks fair within, the jills fair without,the carpets laid, and every thing in order?

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: All ready; and therefore, I pray thee, news.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: First, know, my horse is tired; my master andmistress fallen out.

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: How?

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Out of their saddles into the dirt; and therebyhangs a tale.

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: Let's ha't, good Grumio.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Lend thine ear.

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: Here.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: There.

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: This is to feel a tale, not to hear a tale.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: And therefore 'tis called a sensible tale: and thiscuff was but to knock at your ear, and beseechlistening. Now I begin: Imprimis, we came down afoul hill, my master riding behind my mistress,--

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: Both of one horse?

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: What's that to thee?

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: Why, a horse.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Tell thou the tale: but hadst thou not crossed me,thou shouldst have heard how her horse fell and sheunder her horse; thou shouldst have heard in howmiry a place, how she was bemoiled, how he left herwith the horse upon her, how he beat me becauseher horse stumbled, how she waded through the dirtto pluck him off me, how he swore, how she prayed,that never prayed before, how I cried, how thehorses ran away, how her bridle was burst, how Ilost my crupper, with many things of worthy memory,which now shall die in oblivion and thou returnunexperienced to thy grave.

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: By this reckoning he is more shrew than she.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Ay; and that thou and the proudest of you all shallfind when he comes home. But what talk I of this?Call forth Nathaniel, Joseph, Nicholas, Philip,Walter, Sugarsop and the rest: let their heads besleekly combed their blue coats brushed and theirgarters of an indifferent knit: let them curtsywith their left legs and not presume to touch a hairof my master's horse-tail till they kiss theirhands. Are they all ready?

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: They are.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Call them forth.

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: Do you hear, ho? you must meet my master tocountenance my mistress.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Why, she hath a face of her own.

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: Who knows not that?

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Thou, it seems, that calls for company tocountenance her.

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: I call them forth to credit her.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Why, she comes to borrow nothing of them.

speaker: NATHANIEL
dialog: Welcome home, Grumio!

speaker: PHILIP
dialog: How now, Grumio!

speaker: JOSEPH
dialog: What, Grumio!

speaker: NICHOLAS
dialog: Fellow Grumio!

speaker: NATHANIEL
dialog: How now, old lad?

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Welcome, you;--how now, you;-- what, you;--fellow,you;--and thus much for greeting. Now, my sprucecompanions, is all ready, and all things neat?

speaker: NATHANIEL
dialog: All things is ready. How near is our master?

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: E'en at hand, alighted by this; and therefore benot--Cock's passion, silence! I hear my master.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Where be these knaves? What, no man at doorTo hold my stirrup nor to take my horse!Where is Nathaniel, Gregory, Philip?

speaker: ALL SERVING-MEN
dialog: Here, here, sir; here, sir.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Here, sir! here, sir! here, sir! here, sir!You logger-headed and unpolish'd grooms!What, no attendance? no regard? no duty?Where is the foolish knave I sent before?

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Here, sir; as foolish as I was before.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: You peasant swain! you whoreson malt-horse drudge!Did I not bid thee meet me in the park,And bring along these rascal knaves with thee?

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Nathaniel's coat, sir, was not fully made,And Gabriel's pumps were all unpink'd i' the heel;There was no link to colour Peter's hat,And Walter's dagger was not come from sheathing:There were none fine but Adam, Ralph, and Gregory;The rest were ragged, old, and beggarly;Yet, as they are, here are they come to meet you.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Go, rascals, go, and fetch my supper in.Where is the life that late I led--Where are those--Sit down, Kate, and welcome.--Sound, sound, sound, sound!Why, when, I say? Nay, good sweet Kate, be merry.Off with my boots, you rogues! you villains, when?It was the friar of orders grey,As he forth walked on his way:--Out, you rogue! you pluck my foot awry:Take that, and mend the plucking off the other.Be merry, Kate. Some water, here; what, ho!Where's my spaniel Troilus? Sirrah, get you hence,And bid my cousin Ferdinand come hither:One, Kate, that you must kiss, and be acquainted with.Where are my slippers? Shall I have some water?Come, Kate, and wash, and welcome heartily.You whoreson villain! will you let it fall?

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Patience, I pray you; 'twas a fault unwilling.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: A whoreson beetle-headed, flap-ear'd knave!Come, Kate, sit down; I know you have a stomach.Will you give thanks, sweet Kate; or else shall I?What's this? mutton?

speaker: First Servant
dialog: Ay.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Who brought it?

speaker: PETER
dialog: I.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: 'Tis burnt; and so is all the meat.What dogs are these! Where is the rascal cook?How durst you, villains, bring it from the dresser,And serve it thus to me that love it not?Theretake it to you, trenchers, cups, and all;You heedless joltheads and unmanner'd slaves!What, do you grumble? I'll be with you straight.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: I pray you, husband, be not so disquiet:The meat was well, if you were so contented.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: I tell thee, Kate, 'twas burnt and dried away;And I expressly am forbid to touch it,For it engenders choler, planteth anger;And better 'twere that both of us did fast,Since, of ourselves, ourselves are choleric,Than feed it with such over-roasted flesh.Be patient; to-morrow 't shall be mended,And, for this night, we'll fast for company:Come, I will bring thee to thy bridal chamber.

speaker: NATHANIEL
dialog: Peter, didst ever see the like?

speaker: PETER
dialog: He kills her in her own humour.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Where is he?

speaker: CURTIS
dialog: In her chamber, making a sermon of continency to her;And rails, and swears, and rates, that she, poor soul,Knows not which way to stand, to look, to speak,And sits as one new-risen from a dream.Away, away! for he is coming hither.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Thus have I politicly begun my reign,And 'tis my hope to end successfully.My falcon now is sharp and passing empty;And till she stoop she must not be full-gorged,For then she never looks upon her lure.Another way I have to man my haggard,To make her come and know her keeper's call,That is, to watch her, as we watch these kitesThat bate and beat and will not be obedient.She eat no meat to-day, nor none shall eat;Last night she slept not, nor to-night she shall not;As with the meat, some undeserved faultI'll find about the making of the bed;And here I'll fling the pillow, there the bolster,This way the coverlet, another way the sheets:Ay, and amid this hurly I intendThat all is done in reverend care of her;And in conclusion she shall watch all night:And if she chance to nod I'll rail and brawlAnd with the clamour keep her still awake.This is a way to kill a wife with kindness;And thus I'll curb her mad and headstrong humour.He that knows better how to tame a shrew,Now let him speak: 'tis charity to show.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Is't possible, friend Licio, that Mistress BiancaDoth fancy any other but Lucentio?I tell you, sir, she bears me fair in hand.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Sir, to satisfy you in what I have said,Stand by and mark the manner of his teaching.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Now, mistress, profit you in what you read?

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: What, master, read you? first resolve me that.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: I read that I profess, the Art to Love.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: And may you prove, sir, master of your art!

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: While you, sweet dear, prove mistress of my heart!

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Quick proceeders, marry! Now, tell me, I pray,You that durst swear at your mistress BiancaLoved none in the world so well as Lucentio.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: O despiteful love! unconstant womankind!I tell thee, Licio, this is wonderful.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Mistake no more: I am not Licio,Nor a musician, as I seem to be;But one that scorn to live in this disguise,For such a one as leaves a gentleman,And makes a god of such a cullion:Know, sir, that I am call'd Hortensio.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Signior Hortensio, I have often heardOf your entire affection to Bianca;And since mine eyes are witness of her lightness,I will with you, if you be so contented,Forswear Bianca and her love for ever.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: See, how they kiss and court! Signior Lucentio,Here is my hand, and here I firmly vowNever to woo her no more, but do forswear her,As one unworthy all the former favoursThat I have fondly flatter'd her withal.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: And here I take the unfeigned oath,Never to marry with her though she would entreat:Fie on her! see, how beastly she doth court him!

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Would all the world but he had quite forsworn!For me, that I may surely keep mine oath,I will be married to a wealthy widow,Ere three days pass, which hath as long loved meAs I have loved this proud disdainful haggard.And so farewell, Signior Lucentio.Kindness in women, not their beauteous looks,Shall win my love: and so I take my leave,In resolution as I swore before.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Mistress Bianca, bless you with such graceAs 'longeth to a lover's blessed case!Nay, I have ta'en you napping, gentle love,And have forsworn you with Hortensio.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Tranio, you jest: but have you both forsworn me?

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Mistress, we have.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Then we are rid of Licio.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: I' faith, he'll have a lusty widow now,That shall be wood and wedded in a day.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: God give him joy!

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Ay, and he'll tame her.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: He says so, Tranio.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Faith, he is gone unto the taming-school.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: The taming-school! what, is there such a place?

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Ay, mistress, and Petruchio is the master;That teacheth tricks eleven and twenty long,To tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue.

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: O master, master, I have watch'd so longThat I am dog-weary: but at last I spiedAn ancient angel coming down the hill,Will serve the turn.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: What is he, Biondello?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Master, a mercatante, or a pedant,I know not what; but format in apparel,In gait and countenance surely like a father.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: And what of him, Tranio?

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: If he be credulous and trust my tale,I'll make him glad to seem Vincentio,And give assurance to Baptista Minola,As if he were the right VincentioTake in your love, and then let me alone.

speaker: Pedant
dialog: God save you, sir!

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: And you, sir! you are welcome.Travel you far on, or are you at the farthest?

speaker: Pedant
dialog: Sir, at the farthest for a week or two:But then up farther, and as for as Rome;And so to Tripoli, if God lend me life.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: What countryman, I pray?

speaker: Pedant
dialog: Of Mantua.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Of Mantua, sir? marry, God forbid!And come to Padua, careless of your life?

speaker: Pedant
dialog: My life, sir! how, I pray? for that goes hard.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: 'Tis death for any one in MantuaTo come to Padua. Know you not the cause?Your ships are stay'd at Venice, and the duke,For private quarrel 'twixt your duke and him,Hath publish'd and proclaim'd it openly:'Tis, marvel, but that you are but newly come,You might have heard it else proclaim'd about.

speaker: Pedant
dialog: Alas! sir, it is worse for me than so;For I have bills for money by exchangeFrom Florence and must here deliver them.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Well, sir, to do you courtesy,This will I do, and this I will advise you:First, tell me, have you ever been at Pisa?

speaker: Pedant
dialog: Ay, sir, in Pisa have I often been,Pisa renowned for grave citizens.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Among them know you one Vincentio?

speaker: Pedant
dialog: I know him not, but I have heard of him;A merchant of incomparable wealth.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: He is my father, sir; and, sooth to say,In countenance somewhat doth resemble you.

speaker: Pedant
dialog: O sir, I do; and will repute you everThe patron of my life and liberty.

speaker: TRANIO
