dialog: Then go with me to make the matter good.This, by the way, I let you understand;my father is here look'd for every day,To pass assurance of a dower in marriage'Twixt me and one Baptista's daughter here:In all these circumstances I'll instruct you:Go with me to clothe you as becomes you.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: No, no, forsooth; I dare not for my life.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: The more my wrong, the more his spite appears:What, did he marry me to famish me?Beggars, that come unto my father's door,Upon entreaty have a present aims;If not, elsewhere they meet with charity:But I, who never knew how to entreat,Nor never needed that I should entreat,Am starved for meat, giddy for lack of sleep,With oath kept waking and with brawling fed:And that which spites me more than all these wants,He does it under name of perfect love;As who should say, if I should sleep or eat,'Twere deadly sickness or else present death.I prithee go and get me some repast;I care not what, so it be wholesome food.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: What say you to a neat's foot?

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: 'Tis passing good: I prithee let me have it.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: I fear it is too choleric a meat.How say you to a fat tripe finely broil'd?

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: I like it well: good Grumio, fetch it me.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: I cannot tell; I fear 'tis choleric.What say you to a piece of beef and mustard?

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: A dish that I do love to feed upon.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Ay, but the mustard is too hot a little.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Why then, the beef, and let the mustard rest.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Nay then, I will not: you shall have the mustard,Or else you get no beef of Grumio.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Then both, or one, or any thing thou wilt.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Why then, the mustard without the beef.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Go, get thee gone, thou false deluding slave,That feed'st me with the very name of meat:Sorrow on thee and all the pack of you,That triumph thus upon my misery!Go, get thee gone, I say.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: How fares my Kate? What, sweeting, all amort?

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Mistress, what cheer?

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Faith, as cold as can be.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Pluck up thy spirits; look cheerfully upon me.Here love; thou see'st how diligent I amTo dress thy meat myself and bring it thee:I am sure, sweet Kate, this kindness merits thanks.What, not a word? Nay, then thou lovest it not;And all my pains is sorted to no proof.Here, take away this dish.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: I pray you, let it stand.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: The poorest service is repaid with thanks;And so shall mine, before you touch the meat.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: I thank you, sir.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Signior Petruchio, fie! you are to blame.Come, mistress Kate, I'll bear you company.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Why, this was moulded on a porringer;A velvet dish: fie, fie! 'tis lewd and filthy:Why, 'tis a cockle or a walnut-shell,A knack, a toy, a trick, a baby's cap:Away with it! come, let me have a bigger.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: I'll have no bigger: this doth fit the time,And gentlewomen wear such caps as these

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Why, sir, I trust I may have leave to speak;And speak I will; I am no child, no babe:Your betters have endured me say my mind,And if you cannot, best you stop your ears.My tongue will tell the anger of my heart,Or else my heart concealing it will break,And rather than it shall, I will be freeEven to the uttermost, as I please, in words.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Why, thou say'st true; it is a paltry cap,A custard-coffin, a bauble, a silken pie:I love thee well, in that thou likest it not.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Love me or love me not, I like the cap;And it I will have, or I will have none.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Thy gown? why, ay: come, tailor, let us see't.O mercy, God! what masquing stuff is here?What's this? a sleeve? 'tis like a demi-cannon:What, up and down, carved like an apple-tart?Here's snip and nip and cut and slish and slash,Like to a censer in a barber's shop:Why, what, i' devil's name, tailor, call'st thou this?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Marry, and did; but if you be remember'd,I did not bid you mar it to the time.Go, hop me over every kennel home,For you shall hop without my custom, sir:I'll none of it: hence! make your best of it.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: I never saw a better-fashion'd gown,More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable:Belike you mean to make a puppet of me.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Why, true; he means to make a puppet of thee.

speaker: Tailor
dialog: She says your worship means to makea puppet of her.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: O monstrous arrogance! Thou liest, thou thread,thou thimble,Thou yard, three-quarters, half-yard, quarter, nail!Thou flea, thou nit, thou winter-cricket thou!Braved in mine own house with a skein of thread?Away, thou rag, thou quantity, thou remnant;Or I shall so be-mete thee with thy yardAs thou shalt think on prating whilst thou livest!I tell thee, I, that thou hast marr'd her gown.

speaker: Tailor
dialog: Your worship is deceived; the gown is madeJust as my master had direction:Grumio gave order how it should be done.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: I gave him no order; I gave him the stuff.

speaker: Tailor
dialog: But how did you desire it should be made?

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Marry, sir, with needle and thread.

speaker: Tailor
dialog: But did you not request to have it cut?

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Thou hast faced many things.

speaker: Tailor
dialog: I have.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Face not me: thou hast braved many men; brave notme; I will neither be faced nor braved. I say untothee, I bid thy master cut out the gown; but I didnot bid him cut it to pieces: ergo, thou liest.

speaker: Tailor
dialog: Why, here is the note of the fashion to testify

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Read it.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: The note lies in's throat, if he say I said so.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Ay, there's the villany.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Error i' the bill, sir; error i' the bill.I commanded the sleeves should be cut out andsewed up again; and that I'll prove upon thee,though thy little finger be armed in a thimble.

speaker: Tailor
dialog: This is true that I say: an I had theein place where, thou shouldst know it.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: I am for thee straight: take thou thebill, give me thy mete-yard, and spare not me.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: God-a-mercy, Grumio! then he shall have no odds.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Well, sir, in brief, the gown is not for me.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: You are i' the right, sir: 'tis for my mistress.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Go, take it up unto thy master's use.

speaker: GRUMIO
dialog: Villain, not for thy life: take up my mistress'gown for thy master's use!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Why, sir, what's your conceit in that?

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Tailor, I'll pay thee for thy gown tomorrow:Take no unkindness of his hasty words:Away! I say; commend me to thy master.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Well, come, my Kate; we will unto your father'sEven in these honest mean habiliments:Our purses shall be proud, our garments poor;For 'tis the mind that makes the body rich;And as the sun breaks through the darkest clouds,So honour peereth in the meanest habit.What is the jay more precious than the lark,Because his fathers are more beautiful?Or is the adder better than the eel,Because his painted skin contents the eye?O, no, good Kate; neither art thou the worseFor this poor furniture and mean array.if thou account'st it shame. lay it on me;And therefore frolic: we will hence forthwith,To feast and sport us at thy father's house.Go, call my men, and let us straight to him;And bring our horses unto Long-lane end;There will we mount, and thither walk on footLet's see; I think 'tis now some seven o'clock,And well we may come there by dinner-time.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: I dare assure you, sir, 'tis almost two;And 'twill be supper-time ere you come there.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: It shall be seven ere I go to horse:Look, what I speak, or do, or think to do,You are still crossing it. Sirs, let't alone:I will not go to-day; and ere I do,It shall be what o'clock I say it is.

speaker: Pedant
dialog: Ay, what else? and but I be deceivedSignior Baptista may remember me,Near twenty years ago, in Genoa,Where we were lodgers at the Pegasus.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: 'Tis well; and hold your own, in any case,With such austerity as 'longeth to a father.

speaker: Pedant
dialog: I warrant you.But, sir, here comes your boy;'Twere good he were school'd.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Fear you not him. Sirrah Biondello,Now do your duty throughly, I advise you:Imagine 'twere the right Vincentio.

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Tut, fear not me.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: But hast thou done thy errand to Baptista?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: I told him that your father was at Venice,And that you look'd for him this day in Padua.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Thou'rt a tall fellow: hold thee that to drink.Here comes Baptista: set your countenance, sir.Signior Baptista, you are happily met.Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of:I pray you stand good father to me now,Give me Bianca for my patrimony.

speaker: Pedant
dialog: Soft son!Sir, by your leave: having come to PaduaTo gather in some debts, my son LucentioMade me acquainted with a weighty causeOf love between your daughter and himself:And, for the good report I hear of youAnd for the love he beareth to your daughterAnd she to him, to stay him not too long,I am content, in a good father's care,To have him match'd; and if you please to likeNo worse than I, upon some agreementMe shall you find ready and willingWith one consent to have her so bestow'd;For curious I cannot be with you,Signior Baptista, of whom I hear so well.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Sir, pardon me in what I have to say:Your plainness and your shortness please me well.Right true it is, your son Lucentio hereDoth love my daughter and she loveth him,Or both dissemble deeply their affections:And therefore, if you say no more than this,That like a father you will deal with himAnd pass my daughter a sufficient dower,The match is made, and all is done:Your son shall have my daughter with consent.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: I thank you, sir. Where then do you know bestWe be affied and such assurance ta'enAs shall with either part's agreement stand?

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Not in my house, Lucentio; for, you know,Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants:Besides, old Gremio is hearkening still;And happily we might be interrupted.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Then at my lodging, an it like you:There doth my father lie; and there, this night,We'll pass the business privately and well.Send for your daughter by your servant here:My boy shall fetch the scrivener presently.The worst is this, that, at so slender warning,You are like to have a thin and slender pittance.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: It likes me well. Biondello, hie you home,And bid Bianca make her ready straight;And, if you will, tell what hath happened,Lucentio's father is arrived in Padua,And how she's like to be Lucentio's wife.

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: I pray the gods she may with all my heart!

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Dally not with the gods, but get thee gone.Signior Baptista, shall I lead the way?Welcome! one mess is like to be your cheer:Come, sir; we will better it in Pisa.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: I follow you.

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Cambio!

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: What sayest thou, Biondello?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Biondello, what of that?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Faith, nothing; but has left me here behind, toexpound the meaning or moral of his signs and tokens.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: I pray thee, moralize them.

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Then thus. Baptista is safe, talking with thedeceiving father of a deceitful son.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: And what of him?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: And then?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: The old priest of Saint Luke's church is at yourcommand at all hours.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: And what of all this?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: I cannot tell; expect they are busied about acounterfeit assurance: take you assurance of her,'cum privilegio ad imprimendum solum:' to thechurch; take the priest, clerk, and some sufficienthonest witnesses: If this be not that you look for,I have no more to say, But bid Bianca farewell forever and a day.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Hearest thou, Biondello?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: I cannot tarry: I knew a wench married in anafternoon as she went to the garden for parsley tostuff a rabbit; and so may you, sir: and so, adieu,sir. My master hath appointed me to go to SaintLuke's, to bid the priest be ready to come againstyou come with your appendix.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: I may, and will, if she be so contented:She will be pleased; then wherefore should I doubt?Hap what hap may, I'll roundly go about her:It shall go hard if Cambio go without her.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Come on, i' God's name; once more toward our father's.Good Lord, how bright and goodly shines the moon!

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: The moon! the sun: it is not moonlight now.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: I say it is the moon that shines so bright.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: I know it is the sun that shines so bright.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Now, by my mother's son, and that's myself,It shall be moon, or star, or what I list,Or ere I journey to your father's house.Go on, and fetch our horses back again.Evermore cross'd and cross'd; nothing but cross'd!

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Say as he says, or we shall never go.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Forward, I pray, since we have come so far,And be it moon, or sun, or what you please:An if you please to call it a rush-candle,Henceforth I vow it shall be so for me.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: I say it is the moon.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: I know it is the moon.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Nay, then you lie: it is the blessed sun.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Then, God be bless'd, it is the blessed sun:But sun it is not, when you say it is not;And the moon changes even as your mind.What you will have it named, even that it is;And so it shall be so for Katharina.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Petruchio, go thy ways; the field is won.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Well, forward, forward! thus the bowl should run,And not unluckily against the bias.But, soft! company is coming here.Good morrow, gentle mistress: where away?Tell me, sweet Kate, and tell me truly too,Hast thou beheld a fresher gentlewoman?Such war of white and red within her cheeks!What stars do spangle heaven with such beauty,As those two eyes become that heavenly face?Fair lovely maid, once more good day to thee.Sweet Kate, embrace her for her beauty's sake.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: A' will make the man mad, to make a woman of him.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet,Whither away, or where is thy abode?Happy the parents of so fair a child;Happier the man, whom favourable starsAllot thee for his lovely bed-fellow!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Why, how now, Kate! I hope thou art not mad:This is a man, old, wrinkled, faded, wither'd,And not a maiden, as thou say'st he is.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Pardon, old father, my mistaking eyes,That have been so bedazzled with the sunThat everything I look on seemeth green:Now I perceive thou art a reverend father;Pardon, I pray thee, for my mad mistaking.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Do, good old grandsire; and withal make knownWhich way thou travellest: if along with us,We shall be joyful of thy company.

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: Fair sir, and you my merry mistress,That with your strange encounter much amazed me,My name is call'd Vincentio; my dwelling Pisa;And bound I am to Padua; there to visitA son of mine, which long I have not seen.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: What is his name?

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: Lucentio, gentle sir.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Happily we met; the happier for thy son.And now by law, as well as reverend age,I may entitle thee my loving father:The sister to my wife, this gentlewoman,Thy son by this hath married. Wonder not,Nor be grieved: she is of good esteem,Her dowery wealthy, and of worthy birth;Beside, so qualified as may beseemThe spouse of any noble gentleman.Let me embrace with old Vincentio,And wander we to see thy honest son,Who will of thy arrival be full joyous.

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: But is it true? or else is it your pleasure,Like pleasant travellers, to break a jestUpon the company you overtake?

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: I do assure thee, father, so it is.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Come, go along, and see the truth hereof;For our first merriment hath made thee jealous.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Well, Petruchio, this has put me in heart.Have to my widow! and if she be froward,Then hast thou taught Hortensio to be untoward.

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Softly and swiftly, sir; for the priest is ready.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: I fly, Biondello: but they may chance to need theeat home; therefore leave us.

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Nay, faith, I'll see the church o' your back; andthen come back to my master's as soon as I can.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: I marvel Cambio comes not all this while.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Sir, here's the door, this is Lucentio's house:My father's bears more toward the market-place;Thither must I, and here I leave you, sir.

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: You shall not choose but drink before you go:I think I shall command your welcome here,And, by all likelihood, some cheer is toward.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: They're busy within; you were best knock louder.

speaker: Pedant
dialog: What's he that knocks as he would beat down the gate?

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?

speaker: Pedant
dialog: He's within, sir, but not to be spoken withal.

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two, tomake merry withal?

speaker: Pedant
dialog: Keep your hundred pounds to yourself: he shallneed none, so long as I live.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Nay, I told you your son was well beloved in Padua.Do you hear, sir? To leave frivolous circumstances,I pray you, tell Signior Lucentio that his father iscome from Pisa, and is here at the door to speak with him.

speaker: Pedant
dialog: Thou liest: his father is come from Padua and herelooking out at the window.

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: Art thou his father?

speaker: Pedant
dialog: Lay hands on the villain: I believe a' means tocozen somebody in this city under my countenance.

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: I have seen them in the church together: God send'em good shipping! But who is here? mine oldmaster Vincentio! now we are undone and brought to nothing.

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: Come hither, you rogue. What, have you forgot me?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Forgot you! no, sir: I could not forget you, for Inever saw you before in all my life.

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: What, you notorious villain, didst thou never seethy master's father, Vincentio?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: What, my old worshipful old master? yes, marry, sir:see where he looks out of the window.

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: Is't so, indeed.

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Help, help, help! here's a madman will murder me.

speaker: Pedant
dialog: Help, son! help, Signior Baptista!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Prithee, Kate, let's stand aside and see the end ofthis controversy.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Sir, what are you that offer to beat my servant?

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: What am I, sir! nay, what are you, sir? O immortalgods! O fine villain! A silken doublet! a velvethose! a scarlet cloak! and a copatain hat! O, Iam undone! I am undone! while I play the goodhusband at home, my son and my servant spend all atthe university.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: How now! what's the matter?

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: What, is the man lunatic?

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Sir, you seem a sober ancient gentleman by yourhabit, but your words show you a madman. Why, sir,what 'cerns it you if I wear pearl and gold? Ithank my good father, I am able to maintain it.

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: Thy father! O villain! he is a sailmaker in Bergamo.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: You mistake, sir, you mistake, sir. Pray, what doyou think is his name?

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: His name! as if I knew not his name: I have broughthim up ever since he was three years old, and hisname is Tranio.

speaker: Pedant
dialog: Away, away, mad ass! his name is Lucentio and he ismine only son, and heir to the lands of me, Signior Vincentio.

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: Lucentio! O, he hath murdered his master! Lay holdon him, I charge you, in the duke's name. O, myson, my son! Tell me, thou villain, where is my son Lucentio?

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Call forth an officer.Carry this mad knave to the gaol. Father Baptista,I charge you see that he be forthcoming.

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: Carry me to the gaol!

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Stay, officer: he shall not go to prison.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Talk not, Signior Gremio: I say he shall go to prison.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you becony-catched in this business: I dare swear thisis the right Vincentio.

speaker: Pedant
dialog: Swear, if thou darest.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Nay, I dare not swear it.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: Then thou wert best say that I am not Lucentio.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Away with the dotard! to the gaol with him!

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: Thus strangers may be hailed and abused: Omonstrous villain!

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: O! we are spoiled and--yonder he is: deny him,forswear him, or else we are all undone.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Pardon, dear father.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: How hast thou offended?Where is Lucentio?

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Here's Lucentio,Right son to the right Vincentio;That have by marriage made thy daughter mine,While counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyne.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Here's packing, with a witness to deceive us all!

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: Where is that damned villain Tranio,That faced and braved me in this matter so?

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Cambio is changed into Lucentio.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Love wrought these miracles. Bianca's loveMade me exchange my state with Tranio,While he did bear my countenance in the town;And happily I have arrived at the lastUnto the wished haven of my bliss.What Tranio did, myself enforced him to;Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: I'll slit the villain's nose, that would have sentme to the gaol.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: But do you hear, sir? have you married my daughterwithout asking my good will?

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: Fear not, Baptista; we will content you, go to: butI will in, to be revenged for this villany.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: And I, to sound the depth of this knavery.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Look not pale, Bianca; thy father will not frown.

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: My cake is dough; but I'll in among the rest,Out of hope of all, but my share of the feast.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Husband, let's follow, to see the end of this ado.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: First kiss me, Kate, and we will.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: What, in the midst of the street?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: What, art thou ashamed of me?

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: No, sir, God forbid; but ashamed to kiss.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Why, then let's home again. Come, sirrah, let's away.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Nay, I will give thee a kiss: now pray thee, love, stay.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Is not this well? Come, my sweet Kate:Better once than never, for never too late.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: At last, though long, our jarring notes agree:And time it is, when raging war is done,To smile at scapes and perils overblown.My fair Bianca, bid my father welcome,While I with self-same kindness welcome thine.Brother Petruchio, sister Katharina,And thou, Hortensio, with thy loving widow,Feast with the best, and welcome to my house:My banquet is to close our stomachs up,After our great good cheer. Pray you, sit down;For now we sit to chat as well as eat.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Padua affords this kindness, son Petruchio.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Padua affords nothing but what is kind.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: For both our sakes, I would that word were true.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.

speaker: Widow
dialog: Then never trust me, if I be afeard.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: You are very sensible, and yet you miss my sense:I mean, Hortensio is afeard of you.

speaker: Widow
dialog: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Roundly replied.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Mistress, how mean you that?

speaker: Widow
dialog: Thus I conceive by him.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Conceives by me! How likes Hortensio that?

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: My widow says, thus she conceives her tale.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Very well mended. Kiss him for that, good widow.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: 'He that is giddy thinks the world turns round:'I pray you, tell me what you meant by that.

speaker: Widow
dialog: Your husband, being troubled with a shrew,Measures my husband's sorrow by his woe:And now you know my meaning,

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: A very mean meaning.

speaker: Widow
dialog: Right, I mean you.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: And I am mean indeed, respecting you.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: To her, Kate!

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: To her, widow!

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: That's my office.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Spoke like an officer; ha' to thee, lad!

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Believe me, sir, they butt together well.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Head, and butt! an hasty-witted bodyWould say your head and butt were head and horn.

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: Ay, mistress bride, hath that awaken'd you?

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Ay, but not frighted me; therefore I'll sleep again.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Nay, that you shall not: since you have begun,Have at you for a bitter jest or two!

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Am I your bird? I mean to shift my bush;And then pursue me as you draw your bow.You are welcome all.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: She hath prevented me. Here, Signior Tranio.This bird you aim'd at, though you hit her not;Therefore a health to all that shot and miss'd.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: O, sir, Lucentio slipp'd me like his greyhound,Which runs himself and catches for his master.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: A good swift simile, but something currish.

speaker: TRANIO
dialog: 'Tis well, sir, that you hunted for yourself:'Tis thought your deer does hold you at a bay.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: O ho, Petruchio! Tranio hits you now.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Confess, confess, hath he not hit you here?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: A' has a little gall'd me, I confess;And, as the jest did glance away from me,'Tis ten to one it maim'd you two outright.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio,I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Well, I say no: and therefore for assuranceLet's each one send unto his wife;And he whose wife is most obedientTo come at first when he doth send for her,Shall win the wager which we will propose.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Content. What is the wager?

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Twenty crowns.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Twenty crowns!I'll venture so much of my hawk or hound,But twenty times so much upon my wife.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: A hundred then.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Content.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: A match! 'tis done.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Who shall begin?

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: That will I.Go, Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: I go.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Son, I'll be your half, Bianca comes.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: I'll have no halves; I'll bear it all myself.How now! what news?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: Sir, my mistress sends you wordThat she is busy and she cannot come.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: How! she is busy and she cannot come!Is that an answer?

speaker: GREMIO
dialog: Ay, and a kind one too:Pray God, sir, your wife send you not a worse.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: I hope better.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Sirrah Biondello, go and entreat my wifeTo come to me forthwith.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: O, ho! entreat her!Nay, then she must needs come.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: I am afraid, sir,Do what you can, yours will not be entreated.Now, where's my wife?

speaker: BIONDELLO
dialog: She says you have some goodly jest in hand:She will not come: she bids you come to her.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Worse and worse; she will not come! O vile,Intolerable, not to be endured!Sirrah Grumio, go to your mistress;Say, I command her to come to me.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: I know her answer.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: What?

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: She will not.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Now, by my holidame, here comes Katharina!

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: What is your will, sir, that you send for me?

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Where is your sister, and Hortensio's wife?

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: They sit conferring by the parlor fire.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Go fetch them hither: if they deny to come.Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands:Away, I say, and bring them hither straight.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: And so it is: I wonder what it bodes.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Marry, peace it bodes, and love and quiet life,And awful rule and right supremacy;And, to be short, what not, that's sweet and happy?

speaker: BAPTISTA
dialog: Now, fair befal thee, good Petruchio!The wager thou hast won; and I will addUnto their losses twenty thousand crowns;Another dowry to another daughter,For she is changed, as she had never been.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Nay, I will win my wager better yetAnd show more sign of her obedience,Her new-built virtue and obedience.See where she comes and brings your froward wivesAs prisoners to her womanly persuasion.Katharina, that cap of yours becomes you not:Off with that bauble, throw it under-foot.

speaker: Widow
dialog: Lord, let me never have a cause to sigh,Till I be brought to such a silly pass!

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: Fie! what a foolish duty call you this?

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: I would your duty were as foolish too:The wisdom of your duty, fair Bianca,Hath cost me an hundred crowns since supper-time.

speaker: BIANCA
dialog: The more fool you, for laying on my duty.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Katharina, I charge thee, tell these headstrong womenWhat duty they do owe their lords and husbands.

speaker: Widow
dialog: Come, come, you're mocking: we will have no telling.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Come on, I say; and first begin with her.

speaker: Widow
dialog: She shall not.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: I say she shall: and first begin with her.

speaker: KATHARINA
dialog: Fie, fie! unknit that threatening unkind brow,And dart not scornful glances from those eyes,To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor:It blots thy beauty as frosts do bite the meads,Confounds thy fame as whirlwinds shake fair buds,And in no sense is meet or amiable.A woman moved is like a fountain troubled,Muddy, ill-seeming, thick, bereft of beauty;And while it is so, none so dry or thirstyWill deign to sip or touch one drop of it.Thy husband is thy lord, thy life, thy keeper,Thy head, thy sovereign; one that cares for thee,And for thy maintenance commits his bodyTo painful labour both by sea and land,To watch the night in storms, the day in cold,Whilst thou liest warm at home, secure and safe;And craves no other tribute at thy handsBut love, fair looks and true obedience;Too little payment for so great a debt.Such duty as the subject owes the princeEven such a woman oweth to her husband;And when she is froward, peevish, sullen, sour,And not obedient to his honest will,What is she but a foul contending rebelAnd graceless traitor to her loving lord?I am ashamed that women are so simpleTo offer war where they should kneel for peace;Or seek for rule, supremacy and sway,When they are bound to serve, love and obey.Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth,Unapt to toil and trouble in the world,But that our soft conditions and our heartsShould well agree with our external parts?Come, come, you froward and unable worms!My mind hath been as big as one of yours,My heart as great, my reason haply more,To bandy word for word and frown for frown;But now I see our lances are but straws,Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare,That seeming to be most which we indeed least are.Then vail your stomachs, for it is no boot,And place your hands below your husband's foot:In token of which duty, if he please,My hand is ready; may it do him ease.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Why, there's a wench! Come on, and kiss me, Kate.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: Well, go thy ways, old lad; for thou shalt ha't.

speaker: VINCENTIO
dialog: 'Tis a good hearing when children are toward.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: But a harsh hearing when women are froward.

speaker: PETRUCHIO
dialog: Come, Kate, we'll to bed.We three are married, but you two are sped.'Twas I won the wager, though you hit the white;And, being a winner, God give you good night!

speaker: HORTENSIO
dialog: Now, go thy ways; thou hast tamed a curst shrew.

speaker: LUCENTIO
dialog: 'Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tamed so.

speaker: Master
dialog: Boatswain!

speaker: Boatswain
dialog: Here, master: what cheer?

speaker: Master
dialog: Good, speak to the mariners: fall to't, yarely,or we run ourselves aground: bestir, bestir.

speaker: Boatswain
dialog: Heigh, my hearts! cheerly, cheerly, my hearts!yare, yare! Take in the topsail. Tend to themaster's whistle. Blow, till thou burst thy wind,if room enough!

speaker: ALONSO
dialog: Good boatswain, have care. Where's the master?Play the men.

speaker: Boatswain
dialog: I pray now, keep below.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: Where is the master, boatswain?

speaker: Boatswain
dialog: Do you not hear him? You mar our labour: keep yourcabins: you do assist the storm.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: Nay, good, be patient.

speaker: Boatswain
dialog: When the sea is. Hence! What cares these roarersfor the name of king? To cabin: silence! trouble us not.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.

speaker: Boatswain
dialog: None that I more love than myself. You are acounsellor; if you can command these elements tosilence, and work the peace of the present, we willnot hand a rope more; use your authority: if youcannot, give thanks you have lived so long, and makeyourself ready in your cabin for the mischance ofthe hour, if it so hap. Cheerly, good hearts! Outof our way, I say.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: I have great comfort from this fellow: methinks hehath no drowning mark upon him; his complexion isperfect gallows. Stand fast, good Fate, to hishanging: make the rope of his destiny our cable,for our own doth little advantage. If he be notborn to be hanged, our case is miserable.

speaker: Boatswain
dialog: Down with the topmast! yare! lower, lower! Bringher to try with main-course.A plague upon this howling! they are louder thanthe weather or our office.Yet again! what do you here? Shall we give o'erand drown? Have you a mind to sink?

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: A pox o' your throat, you bawling, blasphemous,incharitable dog!

speaker: Boatswain
dialog: Work you then.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: Hang, cur! hang, you whoreson, insolent noisemaker!We are less afraid to be drowned than thou art.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: I'll warrant him for drowning; though the ship wereno stronger than a nutshell and as leaky as anunstanched wench.

speaker: Boatswain
dialog: Lay her a-hold, a-hold! set her two courses off tosea again; lay her off.

speaker: Mariners
dialog: All lost! to prayers, to prayers! all lost!

speaker: Boatswain
dialog: What, must our mouths be cold?

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: The king and prince at prayers! let's assist them,For our case is as theirs.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: I'm out of patience.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: We are merely cheated of our lives by drunkards:This wide-chapp'd rascal--would thou mightst lie drowningThe washing of ten tides!

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: He'll be hang'd yet,Though every drop of water swear against itAnd gape at widest to glut him.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: Let's all sink with the king.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: Let's take leave of him.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for anacre of barren ground, long heath, brown furze, anything. The wills above be done! but I would faindie a dry death.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: If by your art, my dearest father, you havePut the wild waters in this roar, allay them.The sky, it seems, would pour down stinking pitch,But that the sea, mounting to the welkin's cheek,Dashes the fire out. O, I have sufferedWith those that I saw suffer: a brave vessel,Who had, no doubt, some noble creature in her,Dash'd all to pieces. O, the cry did knockAgainst my very heart. Poor souls, they perish'd.Had I been any god of power, I wouldHave sunk the sea within the earth or ereIt should the good ship so have swallow'd andThe fraughting souls within her.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Be collected:No more amazement: tell your piteous heartThere's no harm done.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: O, woe the day!

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: No harm.I have done nothing but in care of thee,Of thee, my dear one, thee, my daughter, whoArt ignorant of what thou art, nought knowingOf whence I am, nor that I am more betterThan Prospero, master of a full poor cell,And thy no greater father.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: More to knowDid never meddle with my thoughts.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: 'Tis timeI should inform thee farther. Lend thy hand,And pluck my magic garment from me. So:Lie there, my art. Wipe thou thine eyes; have comfort.The direful spectacle of the wreck, which touch'dThe very virtue of compassion in thee,I have with such provision in mine artSo safely ordered that there is no soul--No, not so much perdition as an hairBetid to any creature in the vesselWhich thou heard'st cry, which thou saw'st sink. Sit down;For thou must now know farther.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: You have oftenBegun to tell me what I am, but stopp'dAnd left me to a bootless inquisition,Concluding 'Stay: not yet.'

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: The hour's now come;The very minute bids thee ope thine ear;Obey and be attentive. Canst thou rememberA time before we came unto this cell?I do not think thou canst, for then thou wast notOut three years old.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: Certainly, sir, I can.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: By what? by any other house or person?Of any thing the image tell me thatHath kept with thy remembrance.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: 'Tis far offAnd rather like a dream than an assuranceThat my remembrance warrants. Had I notFour or five women once that tended me?

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Thou hadst, and more, Miranda. But how is itThat this lives in thy mind? What seest thou elseIn the dark backward and abysm of time?If thou remember'st aught ere thou camest here,How thou camest here thou mayst.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: But that I do not.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Twelve year since, Miranda, twelve year since,Thy father was the Duke of Milan andA prince of power.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: Sir, are not you my father?

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Thy mother was a piece of virtue, andShe said thou wast my daughter; and thy fatherWas Duke of Milan; and thou his only heirAnd princess no worse issued.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: O the heavens!What foul play had we, that we came from thence?Or blessed was't we did?

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Both, both, my girl:By foul play, as thou say'st, were we heaved thence,But blessedly holp hither.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: O, my heart bleedsTo think o' the teen that I have turn'd you to,Which is from my remembrance! Please you, farther.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: My brother and thy uncle, call'd Antonio--I pray thee, mark me--that a brother shouldBe so perfidious!--he whom next thyselfOf all the world I loved and to him putThe manage of my state; as at that timeThrough all the signories it was the firstAnd Prospero the prime duke, being so reputedIn dignity, and for the liberal artsWithout a parallel; those being all my study,The government I cast upon my brotherAnd to my state grew stranger, being transportedAnd rapt in secret studies. Thy false uncle--Dost thou attend me?

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: Sir, most heedfully.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Being once perfected how to grant suits,How to deny them, who to advance and whoTo trash for over-topping, new createdThe creatures that were mine, I say, or changed 'em,Or else new form'd 'em; having both the keyOf officer and office, set all hearts i' the stateTo what tune pleased his ear; that now he wasThe ivy which had hid my princely trunk,And suck'd my verdure out on't. Thou attend'st not.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: O, good sir, I do.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: I pray thee, mark me.I, thus neglecting worldly ends, all dedicatedTo closeness and the bettering of my mindWith that which, but by being so retired,O'er-prized all popular rate, in my false brotherAwaked an evil nature; and my trust,Like a good parent, did beget of himA falsehood in its contrary as greatAs my trust was; which had indeed no limit,A confidence sans bound. He being thus lorded,Not only with what my revenue yielded,But what my power might else exact, like oneWho having into truth, by telling of it,Made such a sinner of his memory,To credit his own lie, he did believeHe was indeed the duke; out o' the substitutionAnd executing the outward face of royalty,With all prerogative: hence his ambition growing--Dost thou hear?

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: Your tale, sir, would cure deafness.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: To have no screen between this part he play'dAnd him he play'd it for, he needs will beAbsolute Milan. Me, poor man, my libraryWas dukedom large enough: of temporal royaltiesHe thinks me now incapable; confederates--So dry he was for sway--wi' the King of NaplesTo give him annual tribute, do him homage,Subject his coronet to his crown and bendThe dukedom yet unbow'd--alas, poor Milan!--To most ignoble stooping.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: O the heavens!

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Mark his condition and the event; then tell meIf this might be a brother.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: I should sinTo think but nobly of my grandmother:Good wombs have borne bad sons.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Now the condition.The King of Naples, being an enemyTo me inveterate, hearkens my brother's suit;Which was, that he, in lieu o' the premisesOf homage and I know not how much tribute,Should presently extirpate me and mineOut of the dukedom and confer fair MilanWith all the honours on my brother: whereon,A treacherous army levied, one midnightFated to the purpose did Antonio openThe gates of Milan, and, i' the dead of darkness,The ministers for the purpose hurried thenceMe and thy crying self.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: Alack, for pity!I, not remembering how I cried out then,Will cry it o'er again: it is a hintThat wrings mine eyes to't.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Hear a little furtherAnd then I'll bring thee to the present businessWhich now's upon's; without the which this storyWere most impertinent.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: Wherefore did they notThat hour destroy us?

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Well demanded, wench:My tale provokes that question. Dear, they durst not,So dear the love my people bore me, nor setA mark so bloody on the business, butWith colours fairer painted their foul ends.In few, they hurried us aboard a bark,Bore us some leagues to sea; where they preparedA rotten carcass of a boat, not rigg'd,Nor tackle, sail, nor mast; the very ratsInstinctively had quit it: there they hoist us,To cry to the sea that roar'd to us, to sighTo the winds whose pity, sighing back again,Did us but loving wrong.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: Alack, what troubleWas I then to you!

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: O, a cherubimThou wast that did preserve me. Thou didst smile.Infused with a fortitude from heaven,When I have deck'd the sea with drops full salt,Under my burthen groan'd; which raised in meAn undergoing stomach, to bear upAgainst what should ensue.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: How came we ashore?

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: By Providence divine.Some food we had and some fresh water thatA noble Neapolitan, Gonzalo,Out of his charity, being then appointedMaster of this design, did give us, withRich garments, linens, stuffs and necessaries,Which since have steaded much; so, of his gentleness,Knowing I loved my books, he furnish'd meFrom mine own library with volumes thatI prize above my dukedom.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: Would I mightBut ever see that man!

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Now I arise:Sit still, and hear the last of our sea-sorrow.Here in this island we arrived; and hereHave I, thy schoolmaster, made thee more profitThan other princesses can that have more timeFor vainer hours and tutors not so careful.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: Heavens thank you for't! And now, I pray you, sir,For still 'tis beating in my mind, your reasonFor raising this sea-storm?

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Know thus far forth.By accident most strange, bountiful Fortune,Now my dear lady, hath mine enemiesBrought to this shore; and by my prescienceI find my zenith doth depend uponA most auspicious star, whose influenceIf now I court not but omit, my fortunesWill ever after droop. Here cease more questions:Thou art inclined to sleep; 'tis a good dulness,And give it way: I know thou canst not choose.Come away, servant, come. I am ready now.Approach, my Ariel, come.

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: All hail, great master! grave sir, hail! I comeTo answer thy best pleasure; be't to fly,To swim, to dive into the fire, to rideOn the curl'd clouds, to thy strong bidding taskAriel and all his quality.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Hast thou, spirit,Perform'd to point the tempest that I bade thee?

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: To every article.I boarded the king's ship; now on the beak,Now in the waist, the deck, in every cabin,I flamed amazement: sometime I'ld divide,And burn in many places; on the topmast,The yards and bowsprit, would I flame distinctly,Then meet and join. Jove's lightnings, the precursorsO' the dreadful thunder-claps, more momentaryAnd sight-outrunning were not; the fire and cracksOf sulphurous roaring the most mighty NeptuneSeem to besiege and make his bold waves tremble,Yea, his dread trident shake.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: My brave spirit!Who was so firm, so constant, that this coilWould not infect his reason?

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: Not a soulBut felt a fever of the mad and play'dSome tricks of desperation. All but marinersPlunged in the foaming brine and quit the vessel,Then all afire with me: the king's son, Ferdinand,With hair up-staring,--then like reeds, not hair,--Was the first man that leap'd; cried, 'Hell is emptyAnd all the devils are here.'

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Why that's my spirit!But was not this nigh shore?

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: Close by, my master.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: But are they, Ariel, safe?

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: Not a hair perish'd;On their sustaining garments not a blemish,But fresher than before: and, as thou badest me,In troops I have dispersed them 'bout the isle.The king's son have I landed by himself;Whom I left cooling of the air with sighsIn an odd angle of the isle and sitting,His arms in this sad knot.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Of the king's shipThe mariners say how thou hast disposedAnd all the rest o' the fleet.

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: Safely in harbourIs the king's ship; in the deep nook, where onceThou call'dst me up at midnight to fetch dewFrom the still-vex'd Bermoothes, there she's hid:The mariners all under hatches stow'd;Who, with a charm join'd to their suffer'd labour,I have left asleep; and for the rest o' the fleetWhich I dispersed, they all have met againAnd are upon the Mediterranean flote,Bound sadly home for Naples,Supposing that they saw the king's ship wreck'dAnd his great person perish.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Ariel, thy chargeExactly is perform'd: but there's more work.What is the time o' the day?

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: Past the mid season.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: At least two glasses. The time 'twixt six and nowMust by us both be spent most preciously.

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: Is there more toil? Since thou dost give me pains,Let me remember thee what thou hast promised,Which is not yet perform'd me.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: How now? moody?What is't thou canst demand?

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: My liberty.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Before the time be out? no more!

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: I prithee,Remember I have done thee worthy service;Told thee no lies, made thee no mistakings, servedWithout or grudge or grumblings: thou didst promiseTo bate me a full year.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Dost thou forgetFrom what a torment I did free thee?

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: No.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Thou dost, and think'st it much to tread the oozeOf the salt deep,To run upon the sharp wind of the north,To do me business in the veins o' the earthWhen it is baked with frost.

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: I do not, sir.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Thou liest, malignant thing! Hast thou forgotThe foul witch Sycorax, who with age and envyWas grown into a hoop? hast thou forgot her?

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: No, sir.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Thou hast. Where was she born? speak; tell me.

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: Sir, in Argier.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: O, was she so? I mustOnce in a month recount what thou hast been,Which thou forget'st. This damn'd witch Sycorax,For mischiefs manifold and sorceries terribleTo enter human hearing, from Argier,Thou know'st, was banish'd: for one thing she didThey would not take her life. Is not this true?

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: Ay, sir.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: This blue-eyed hag was hither brought with childAnd here was left by the sailors. Thou, my slave,As thou report'st thyself, wast then her servant;And, for thou wast a spirit too delicateTo act her earthy and abhorr'd commands,Refusing her grand hests, she did confine thee,By help of her more potent ministersAnd in her most unmitigable rage,Into a cloven pine; within which riftImprison'd thou didst painfully remainA dozen years; within which space she diedAnd left thee there; where thou didst vent thy groansAs fast as mill-wheels strike. Then was this island--Save for the son that she did litter here,A freckled whelp hag-born--not honour'd withA human shape.

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: Yes, Caliban her son.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Dull thing, I say so; he, that CalibanWhom now I keep in service. Thou best know'stWhat torment I did find thee in; thy groansDid make wolves howl and penetrate the breastsOf ever angry bears: it was a tormentTo lay upon the damn'd, which SycoraxCould not again undo: it was mine art,When I arrived and heard thee, that made gapeThe pine and let thee out.

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: I thank thee, master.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: If thou more murmur'st, I will rend an oakAnd peg thee in his knotty entrails tillThou hast howl'd away twelve winters.

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: Pardon, master;I will be correspondent to commandAnd do my spiriting gently.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Do so, and after two daysI will discharge thee.

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: That's my noble master!What shall I do? say what; what shall I do?

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Go make thyself like a nymph o' the sea: be subjectTo no sight but thine and mine, invisibleTo every eyeball else. Go take this shapeAnd hither come in't: go, hence with diligence!Awake, dear heart, awake! thou hast slept well; Awake!

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: The strangeness of your story putHeaviness in me.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Shake it off. Come on;We'll visit Caliban my slave, who neverYields us kind answer.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: 'Tis a villain, sir,I do not love to look on.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Come forth, I say! there's other business for thee:Come, thou tortoise! when?Fine apparition! My quaint Ariel,Hark in thine ear.

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: My lord it shall be done.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Thou poisonous slave, got by the devil himselfUpon thy wicked dam, come forth!

speaker: CALIBAN
dialog: As wicked dew as e'er my mother brush'dWith raven's feather from unwholesome fenDrop on you both! a south-west blow on yeAnd blister you all o'er!

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: For this, be sure, to-night thou shalt have cramps,Side-stitches that shall pen thy breath up; urchinsShall, for that vast of night that they may work,All exercise on thee; thou shalt be pinch'dAs thick as honeycomb, each pinch more stingingThan bees that made 'em.

speaker: CALIBAN
dialog: I must eat my dinner.This island's mine, by Sycorax my mother,Which thou takest from me. When thou camest first,Thou strokedst me and madest much of me, wouldst give meWater with berries in't, and teach me howTo name the bigger light, and how the less,That burn by day and night: and then I loved theeAnd show'd thee all the qualities o' the isle,The fresh springs, brine-pits, barren place and fertile:Cursed be I that did so! All the charmsOf Sycorax, toads, beetles, bats, light on you!For I am all the subjects that you have,Which first was mine own king: and here you sty meIn this hard rock, whiles you do keep from meThe rest o' the island.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Thou most lying slave,Whom stripes may move, not kindness! I have used thee,Filth as thou art, with human care, and lodged theeIn mine own cell, till thou didst seek to violateThe honour of my child.

speaker: CALIBAN
dialog: O ho, O ho! would't had been done!Thou didst prevent me; I had peopled elseThis isle with Calibans.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Abhorred slave,Which any print of goodness wilt not take,Being capable of all ill! I pitied thee,Took pains to make thee speak, taught thee each hourOne thing or other: when thou didst not, savage,Know thine own meaning, but wouldst gabble likeA thing most brutish, I endow'd thy purposesWith words that made them known. But thy vile race,Though thou didst learn, had that in't whichgood naturesCould not abide to be with; therefore wast thouDeservedly confined into this rock,Who hadst deserved more than a prison.

speaker: CALIBAN
dialog: You taught me language; and my profit on'tIs, I know how to curse. The red plague rid youFor learning me your language!

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Hag-seed, hence!Fetch us in fuel; and be quick, thou'rt best,To answer other business. Shrug'st thou, malice?If thou neglect'st or dost unwillinglyWhat I command, I'll rack thee with old cramps,Fill all thy bones with aches, make thee roarThat beasts shall tremble at thy din.

speaker: CALIBAN
dialog: No, pray thee.I must obey: his art is of such power,It would control my dam's god, Setebos,and make a vassal of him.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: So, slave; hence!Come unto these yellow sands,And then take hands:Courtsied when you have and kiss'dThe wild waves whist,Foot it featly here and there;And, sweet sprites, the burthen bear.Hark, hark!

speaker: FERDINAND
dialog: Where should this music be? i' the air or the earth?It sounds no more: and sure, it waits uponSome god o' the island. Sitting on a bank,Weeping again the king my father's wreck,This music crept by me upon the waters,Allaying both their fury and my passionWith its sweet air: thence I have follow'd it,Or it hath drawn me rather. But 'tis gone.No, it begins again.Full fathom five thy father lies;Of his bones are coral made;Those are pearls that were his eyes:Nothing of him that doth fadeBut doth suffer a sea-changeInto something rich and strange.Sea-nymphs hourly ring his knellHark! now I hear them,--Ding-dong, bell.

speaker: FERDINAND
dialog: The ditty does remember my drown'd father.This is no mortal business, nor no soundThat the earth owes. I hear it now above me.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: The fringed curtains of thine eye advanceAnd say what thou seest yond.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: What is't? a spirit?Lord, how it looks about! Believe me, sir,It carries a brave form. But 'tis a spirit.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: No, wench; it eats and sleeps and hath such sensesAs we have, such. This gallant which thou seestWas in the wreck; and, but he's something stain'dWith grief that's beauty's canker, thou mightst call himA goodly person: he hath lost his fellowsAnd strays about to find 'em.

speaker: FERDINAND
dialog: Most sure, the goddessOn whom these airs attend! Vouchsafe my prayerMay know if you remain upon this island;And that you will some good instruction giveHow I may bear me here: my prime request,Which I do last pronounce, is, O you wonder!If you be maid or no?

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: No wonder, sir;But certainly a maid.

speaker: FERDINAND
dialog: My language! heavens!I am the best of them that speak this speech,Were I but where 'tis spoken.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: How? the best?What wert thou, if the King of Naples heard thee?

speaker: FERDINAND
dialog: A single thing, as I am now, that wondersTo hear thee speak of Naples. He does hear me;And that he does I weep: myself am Naples,Who with mine eyes, never since at ebb, beheldThe king my father wreck'd.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: Alack, for mercy!

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: Why speaks my father so ungently? ThisIs the third man that e'er I saw, the firstThat e'er I sigh'd for: pity move my fatherTo be inclined my way!

speaker: FERDINAND
dialog: O, if a virgin,And your affection not gone forth, I'll make youThe queen of Naples.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Soft, sir! one word more.They are both in either's powers; but this swift businessI must uneasy make, lest too light winningMake the prize light.One word more; I charge theeThat thou attend me: thou dost here usurpThe name thou owest not; and hast put thyselfUpon this island as a spy, to win itFrom me, the lord on't.

speaker: FERDINAND
dialog: No, as I am a man.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: There's nothing ill can dwell in such a temple:If the ill spirit have so fair a house,Good things will strive to dwell with't.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Follow me.Speak not you for him; he's a traitor. Come;I'll manacle thy neck and feet together:Sea-water shalt thou drink; thy food shall beThe fresh-brook muscles, wither'd roots and husksWherein the acorn cradled. Follow.

speaker: FERDINAND
dialog: No;I will resist such entertainment tillMine enemy has more power.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: O dear father,Make not too rash a trial of him, forHe's gentle and not fearful.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: What? I say,My foot my tutor? Put thy sword up, traitor;Who makest a show but darest not strike, thy conscienceIs so possess'd with guilt: come from thy ward,For I can here disarm thee with this stickAnd make thy weapon drop.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: Beseech you, father.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Hence! hang not on my garments.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: Sir, have pity;I'll be his surety.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Silence! one word moreShall make me chide thee, if not hate thee. What!An advocate for an imposter! hush!Thou think'st there is no more such shapes as he,Having seen but him and Caliban: foolish wench!To the most of men this is a CalibanAnd they to him are angels.

speaker: MIRANDA
dialog: My affectionsAre then most humble; I have no ambitionTo see a goodlier man.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Come on; obey:Thy nerves are in their infancy againAnd have no vigour in them.

speaker: FERDINAND
dialog: So they are;My spirits, as in a dream, are all bound up.My father's loss, the weakness which I feel,The wreck of all my friends, nor this man's threats,To whom I am subdued, are but light to me,Might I but through my prison once a dayBehold this maid: all corners else o' the earthLet liberty make use of; space enoughHave I in such a prison.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Thou shalt be freeAs mountain winds: but then exactly doAll points of my command.

speaker: ARIEL
dialog: To the syllable.

speaker: PROSPERO
dialog: Come, follow. Speak not for him.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: Beseech you, sir, be merry; you have cause,So have we all, of joy; for our escapeIs much beyond our loss. Our hint of woeIs common; every day some sailor's wife,The masters of some merchant and the merchantHave just our theme of woe; but for the miracle,I mean our preservation, few in millionsCan speak like us: then wisely, good sir, weighOur sorrow with our comfort.

speaker: ALONSO
dialog: Prithee, peace.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: He receives comfort like cold porridge.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: The visitor will not give him o'er so.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: Look he's winding up the watch of his wit;by and by it will strike.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: Sir,--

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: One: tell.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: When every grief is entertain'd that's offer'd,Comes to the entertainer--

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: A dollar.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: Dolour comes to him, indeed: youhave spoken truer than you purposed.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: You have taken it wiselier than I meant you should.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: Therefore, my lord,--

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: Fie, what a spendthrift is he of his tongue!

speaker: ALONSO
dialog: I prithee, spare.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: Well, I have done: but yet,--

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: He will be talking.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: Which, of he or Adrian, for a goodwager, first begins to crow?

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: The old cock.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: The cockerel.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: Done. The wager?

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: A laughter.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: A match!

speaker: ADRIAN
dialog: Though this island seem to be desert,--

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: Ha, ha, ha! So, you're paid.

speaker: ADRIAN
dialog: Uninhabitable and almost inaccessible,--

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: Yet,--

speaker: ADRIAN
dialog: Yet,--

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: He could not miss't.

speaker: ADRIAN
dialog: It must needs be of subtle, tender and delicatetemperance.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: Temperance was a delicate wench.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: Ay, and a subtle; as he most learnedly delivered.

speaker: ADRIAN
dialog: The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: As if it had lungs and rotten ones.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: Or as 'twere perfumed by a fen.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: Here is everything advantageous to life.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: True; save means to live.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: Of that there's none, or little.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: How lush and lusty the grass looks! how green!

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: The ground indeed is tawny.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: With an eye of green in't.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: He misses not much.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: No; he doth but mistake the truth totally.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: But the rarity of it is,--which is indeed almostbeyond credit,--

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: As many vouched rarities are.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: That our garments, being, as they were, drenched inthe sea, hold notwithstanding their freshness andglosses, being rather new-dyed than stained withsalt water.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: If but one of his pockets could speak, would it notsay he lies?

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: Ay, or very falsely pocket up his report

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: Methinks our garments are now as fresh as when weput them on first in Afric, at the marriage ofthe king's fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: 'Twas a sweet marriage, and we prosper well in our return.

speaker: ADRIAN
dialog: Tunis was never graced before with such a paragon totheir queen.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: Not since widow Dido's time.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: Widow! a pox o' that! How came that widow in?widow Dido!

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: What if he had said 'widower AEneas' too? Good Lord,how you take it!

speaker: ADRIAN
dialog: 'Widow Dido' said you? you make me study of that:she was of Carthage, not of Tunis.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: This Tunis, sir, was Carthage.

speaker: ADRIAN
dialog: Carthage?

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: I assure you, Carthage.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: His word is more than the miraculous harp; he hathraised the wall and houses too.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: What impossible matter will he make easy next?

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: I think he will carry this island home in his pocketand give it his son for an apple.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: And, sowing the kernels of it in the sea, bringforth more islands.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: Ay.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: Why, in good time.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: Sir, we were talking that our garments seem nowas fresh as when we were at Tunis at the marriageof your daughter, who is now queen.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: And the rarest that e'er came there.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: Bate, I beseech you, widow Dido.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: O, widow Dido! ay, widow Dido.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: Is not, sir, my doublet as fresh as the first day Iwore it? I mean, in a sort.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: That sort was well fished for.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: When I wore it at your daughter's marriage?

speaker: ALONSO
dialog: You cram these words into mine ears againstThe stomach of my sense. Would I had neverMarried my daughter there! for, coming thence,My son is lost and, in my rate, she too,Who is so far from Italy removedI ne'er again shall see her. O thou mine heirOf Naples and of Milan, what strange fishHath made his meal on thee?

speaker: FRANCISCO
dialog: Sir, he may live:I saw him beat the surges under him,And ride upon their backs; he trod the water,Whose enmity he flung aside, and breastedThe surge most swoln that met him; his bold head'Bove the contentious waves he kept, and oar'dHimself with his good arms in lusty strokeTo the shore, that o'er his wave-worn basis bow'd,As stooping to relieve him: I not doubtHe came alive to land.

speaker: ALONSO
dialog: No, no, he's gone.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: Sir, you may thank yourself for this great loss,That would not bless our Europe with your daughter,But rather lose her to an African;Where she at least is banish'd from your eye,Who hath cause to wet the grief on't.

speaker: ALONSO
dialog: Prithee, peace.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: You were kneel'd to and importuned otherwiseBy all of us, and the fair soul herselfWeigh'd between loathness and obedience, atWhich end o' the beam should bow. We have lost yourson,I fear, for ever: Milan and Naples haveMore widows in them of this business' makingThan we bring men to comfort them:The fault's your own.

speaker: ALONSO
dialog: So is the dear'st o' the loss.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: My lord Sebastian,The truth you speak doth lack some gentlenessAnd time to speak it in: you rub the sore,When you should bring the plaster.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: Very well.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: And most chirurgeonly.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: It is foul weather in us all, good sir,When you are cloudy.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: Foul weather?

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: Very foul.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: Had I plantation of this isle, my lord,--

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: He'ld sow't with nettle-seed.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: Or docks, or mallows.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: And were the king on't, what would I do?

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: 'Scape being drunk for want of wine.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: I' the commonwealth I would by contrariesExecute all things; for no kind of trafficWould I admit; no name of magistrate;Letters should not be known; riches, poverty,And use of service, none; contract, succession,Bourn, bound of land, tilth, vineyard, none;No use of metal, corn, or wine, or oil;No occupation; all men idle, all;And women too, but innocent and pure;No sovereignty;--

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: Yet he would be king on't.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: The latter end of his commonwealth forgets thebeginning.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: All things in common nature should produceWithout sweat or endeavour: treason, felony,Sword, pike, knife, gun, or need of any engine,Would I not have; but nature should bring forth,Of its own kind, all foison, all abundance,To feed my innocent people.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: No marrying 'mong his subjects?

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: None, man; all idle: whores and knaves.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: I would with such perfection govern, sir,To excel the golden age.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: God save his majesty!

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: Long live Gonzalo!

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: And,--do you mark me, sir?

speaker: ALONSO
dialog: Prithee, no more: thou dost talk nothing to me.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: I do well believe your highness; anddid it to minister occasion to these gentlemen,who are of such sensible and nimble lungs thatthey always use to laugh at nothing.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: 'Twas you we laughed at.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: Who in this kind of merry fooling am nothingto you: so you may continue and laugh atnothing still.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: What a blow was there given!

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: An it had not fallen flat-long.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: You are gentlemen of brave metal; you would liftthe moon out of her sphere, if she would continuein it five weeks without changing.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: We would so, and then go a bat-fowling.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: Nay, good my lord, be not angry.

speaker: GONZALO
dialog: No, I warrant you; I will not adventuremy discretion so weakly. Will you laughme asleep, for I am very heavy?

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: Go sleep, and hear us.

speaker: ALONSO
dialog: What, all so soon asleep! I wish mine eyesWould, with themselves, shut up my thoughts: I findThey are inclined to do so.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: Please you, sir,Do not omit the heavy offer of it:It seldom visits sorrow; when it doth,It is a comforter.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: We two, my lord,Will guard your person while you take your rest,And watch your safety.

speaker: ALONSO
dialog: Thank you. Wondrous heavy.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: What a strange drowsiness possesses them!

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: It is the quality o' the climate.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: WhyDoth it not then our eyelids sink? I find notMyself disposed to sleep.

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: Nor I; my spirits are nimble.They fell together all, as by consent;They dropp'd, as by a thunder-stroke. What might,Worthy Sebastian? O, what might?--No more:--And yet me thinks I see it in thy face,What thou shouldst be: the occasion speaks thee, andMy strong imagination sees a crownDropping upon thy head.

speaker: SEBASTIAN
dialog: What, art thou waking?

speaker: ANTONIO
dialog: Do you not hear me speak?
